sp.p: Thou haſt nick'd it. Ay, the very ſame.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: That very ſame's nothing by this Light, truſt me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Prithee good Boy, without any more ado rid me from my Fears.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: So I will, Sir, in a trice. Imprimis, Mr Chremes parts with no Daughter to day.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: How d'ye know that?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I know't well enough, Sir— Your Father juſt now took me aſide, and told me, You muſt be Marry'd to day, with a long Story at the tail on't, not worth telling you now. Upon this I ran full ſpeed to the Change, to acquaint you with't, where when I found ye not, I gets me up on high, then ſtares me round about, but no Pamphilus appears. By chance I eſpy'd Byrrhie, ask'd him if he had ſeen ye, but no tidings yet. This fretted my very Guts. To work goes my Noddle, to know what to do. Mean while on my return I began to ſmell the whole Buſineſs out. A • , ha! there's not a Bit extraordinary for a Treat, the old Man out of Tune too. A Wedding clapt up in a trice. Theſe things don't hang well together.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Well, what of all this?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Away march'd I to Neighbour Chremes's; when I got there, not a Creature ſtirring before the Door did I ſee, which made me laugh in my ſleeve.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: On with your Story.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: There ſtaid I ſome time, but the De • l a Perſon ſaw I going out or in, never an old Governante; nor the leaſt preparations or hurry in all the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I grant this is a good ſign.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Does this look like a Wedding?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Indeed, Davus, I think not.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Marry come up with your think nots— Ye know nothing I ſee, why 'tis as plain as a Pack Staff. As I was beating the Hoof homewards, who ſhou'd I meet but Mr. Chremes's Boy, coming from the Market with a Bunch of Herbs, and Three ha perth of little little Fiſhes, for the old Man's Supper.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: God-a-mercy Davus This day haſt thou ſet me upo • my Legs again.
hear

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: What a plaguy Miſtake you lie under?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Why ſo? You're Maſter isn't like to have her

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well done Logick! As if there were ne'er another Man i' th' World, but your Worſhip and my Maſter. If ye don t look about ye, make Friends to the old Gentleman, and ply the Lady briskly, ye may ſnap ſhort for all that tho.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Your Councels good, I ll follow't. Tho in troth my hopes have often jilted me, and ſo farewel.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Prithee Davus, what does my Father propoſe to himſelf? what makes him double thus?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, Sir. If he ſhould take pet now that Mr. Chremes won't part with his Daughter, he cou'dn't but blame himſelf for't, and right enough too, till he finds how you ſtand affected to the Wedding. But if it goes off on your ſide, the blame will be laid all at your door; and there will be the Devil to do then.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: What? Shall I truckle?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why, Sir, he's your Father, and you'll have a hard task on't Beſides your Miſtreſs has no body to ſtand by her, upon the leaſt occaſion he'll quickly make the Town too hot for her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Too hot for her?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: In the turning of a Hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Prithee, honeſt Davus, what ſhall I do in this caſe

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why e'en tell him you'll have her.

sp.speaker: Pam
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: VVhy that Sigh now?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: VVhat tell him a thing ſo far from my Heart?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: VVhy not, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: O Davus, never, never—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Never deny't man.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Don't put me upon't.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Conſider well what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Yes, that 'twill put me out of the one and in with the other.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No, no, you're wide.— Now I fancy that your Father will ſay ſome ſuch thing as this. Come Son I muſt needs ha' ye Marry to day. With all my Heart, ſay you— VVell; And what can he quarrel at now? This will ruine all his Deſigns, and you in a whole Skin all this while. For 'tis as certain as certainty it ſelf, that Mr. Chremes won't give ye his Daughter. So that you needn't break a jot of your own Meaſures for fear of his altering his mind. Do but tell your Father you'll marry, and let him be angry if he can. As for your flattering your ſelf, that no body elſe will part with his Daughter to one in your Circumſtances. I'll anſwer that in a word, your Father will tye a Beggar Wench upon your Back, rather than let ye whore o'this rate— Look ye, if he find ye once indifferent: He'll ſleep over it, and look ye out another no body knows when. In the mean time ſomething may happen on our ſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Think ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No doubt on't, I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Have a care where thou leadſt me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What will ye never ha' done?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Well I ll ſay as you'd have me. But you muſt take ſpecial care it don't come to my Father's Ear that I've a Child, and that I'm in for Maintenance.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: O Confident Devil.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why ſhe bound me upon my Oath to take care on't, as a Token I wou'd ne're forſake her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well, we'll take care on't—

p.stage: Enter Simo at a great diſtance.

sp.p: Yonder comes your Father, put on your t'other Face quick.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: to himſelf. Theſe Blades are conferring Notes; I have a mind to ſee what they'd be at.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The good old Man takes it for granted, that you'll refuſe to marry. He comes ſo cogitabund from ſome by corner or another; he queſtions not but he has that in his Head which will put ye to a confounded Nonplus— Be ſure to have all your Brains about ye.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'll do what I can Davus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Come, Sir, tell him but you'll marry her, and if ever he opens his Mouth to ye again upon that Buſineſs, never believe Davus.

p.stage: Enter Byrrhie at another part of the Stage watching them.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: to himſelf. This Maſter o' mine has diſcharg'd me a while from all other Services, to make me a Spy upon Mr Pamphilus's Deſigns about this Wedding. For this purpoſe have I dogg'd Father Greybeard upon the heel— O here they are all together.— Faith I'll play at Bo-peep here.
sp.stage: Withdraws to the ſide of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: coming nearer. O here are the Gentlemen I want.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: 'S't! mind your Cue.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: ſoftly Turn quick as tho you hadn't ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: turning haſtily about. Hah my dear Father!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Excellent I' Faith.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I muſt ha' ye marry to day as I told ye.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: Now I am plaguely afraid whether his anſwer will be for us. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be ready to obey ye in this and all other Commands.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: Say ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: The old Man's Mouth is ſtopp'd.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: What anſwer'd he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why this is like a Son, when ye chearfully do as your Father wou'd ha' ye

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Will ye believe me another time?

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: For ought I perceive, my poor Maſter may go whiſtle for a Wife.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Go in Pamphilus, that you may be at hand when you're wanted.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'm going, Sir.

sp.speaker: Byr.
sp.p: coming from his covert. Is there no Faith in Man? well I find the old Saying ſtands good, Every Man for his own ends. I remember once I had a glimps of this Laſs; 'Sbobs! a charming Creature! And Mr Pamphilus is i'th' right on't, if he had rather lye by ſuch a one himſelf than my Maſter ſhou'd.— I'll go tell him all; 'tis but venturing a few hard words for a little hard News. Ex. Byr.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now this old Mumpſimus concludes I ve got ſome notable Intrigue in my Budget, and that I planted my ſelf here upon the ſame account.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What ſays Davus to the World?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: There's no News ſtirring, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: None ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: None at all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly but I look'd for ſomething tho.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He has loſt his Aim I percieve, and that nettles him too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sirrah, can ye ſpeak without a Lye in your Mouth?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Moſt fluently, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Come, Do'sn't this Match ſtick in my Son's Stomach, becauſe of his Amours with the Stranger?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, no,— or were it ſo, that uneaſineſs wou'd off in a day or two's time, (D ye underſtand me, Sir?) then all would be well again. But now he has fairly taken the Point by the right handle.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I commend him for't.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Indeed when you wink'd at it, and his Age bore him out in't, he did wench a little, but then he did it ſecretly, and like a Man of Honour took care it ſhou'd be no Blot to his Scutcheon.— Now 'tis time to look out for a VVife, he has his thoughts wholly upon Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Methought he lookt a little downiſh upon it tho.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Not at all for that, but there's ſomething elſe he didn't take ſo well at your hands.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVhat's that pray?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: A meer trifle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVhat is't, for a trifle?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay nothing at all to ſpeak on.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVell, well, I muſt know what it is.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: He ſays, You're too ſparing of your Purſe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVho I?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes, you Sir.— For, ſays he, my Father has laid out but Ten Groats for a Supper, And is that to be my Wedding Treat forſooth? Which of my Companions can I invite at ſuch a time as this? And under the Roſe, Sir, I think you are a little too cloſefiſted: I cou'd wiſh it were otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Leave your prating Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I ve ſtung him I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Let me alone to ſee that all be well.—

sp.speaker: Simo
sp.p: alone. What's the meaning of all this?— What wou'd this old Hocus be at?— If there be any piece of Roguery here on foot, I ll lay my Life he's chief Actor in't. Exit after him.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Myſis and Lesbia on one part of the Stage; on another Simo and Davus obſerving them.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: TRuly Lesbia, you're much i'th' the right on't. A faithful Lover is a very great rarity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This Maid belongs to the Andrian; What ſay you to't?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: to Lesbia But this Mr. Pamphilus—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVhat ſays ſhe?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: — Has ſign'd and ſeal'd over again;—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So, ſo!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: VVou'd the old Man's Ears were ſtopp'd, or her Tongue out for me.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: — For whate're God ſends her, he has order'd to be brought up.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Confuſion! VVhat do I hear? If what ſhe ſays be true, all's paſt recovery.
Leſ. A ſweet natur'd young Gentleman I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Oh a moſt ſweet natur'd— But come along, for you'll be too late elſe

sp.speaker: Leſ.
sp.p: VVell let's in then. Exeunt Myſis and Lesbia.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How ſhall we recover our ſelves out of this Relapſe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: walking aſide. VVhat means all this?— Is my Son ſo mad then? And for a ſtranger too? But hold! Now I ſee which way the Hare goes.— That I cou'dn't find it before, like a ſenſeleſs Sot as I was.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: partly overhearing. VVhat's that he has found out, ſays he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Oh here begins the Rogues tricks; they pretend a great Belly among 'em to beat off Mr. Chremes from the Match.

sp.speaker: Glycerie
sp.p: within Oh!— Oh!— Help kind Heavens and free me from my Pains.— I beſeech ye. Oh—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: ſoftly. Ha, ha, ha,— ſo nimble! A very good Jeſt! After ſhe heard of my being at the Door, ſhe preſently falls in Labour forſooth.— Your Farce wasn't well tim'd Mr. Rogue. [to Dav.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Meaning me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ah Sirrah, were your Actors out in their Parts?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I don't underſtand ye, Sir, in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If this Raſcal had ſerv'd me ſo in a real wedding here wou'd ha' been fine work with a vengeance. But now he makes a Rod for his own Back; for my part I'm ſafe enough.
sp.stage: Enter Lesbia from Glycerie's Houſe, not ſeeing Simo and Davus.

sp.speaker: Leſ.
sp.p: to Archillis at the Door. For what's paſt Archillis, and for a VVoman in her Condition every thing is as well as a Body cou'd wiſh. In the firſt place let her be well bath'd; and then let h • take the Doſe I preſcribe her to drink, and juſt the quantity. I ſhall be back again in a minute.— Archillis retires, Lesbia ſpeaks to her ſelf. Heart o' my Body! Pamphilus has got a very pretty Boy. I hope in Heaven he'll live to make as good a Man as his Father, who ſcorn'd to wrong this innocent Creature.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVhat Man alive that knew thee, wou'dn't ſwear that this was one of thy Rogues tricks?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: VVhat Rogues tricks, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
VVithin Doors there were no Orders given
about the big-bellied woman; but when ſhe was once out, ſhe ſets up a bawling in the Streets to thoſe within, that the whole Town might ring on't.— Why Davus am I to be made a Property; or what doſt thou ſee in my Face, to think of making ſo palpable an Aſs of me? If it had been more artificial, it wou'd ha' look'd like ſomewhat of Reverence for me, if I ſhou'd have found it out.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Faith the old Fool cheats himſelf, not I.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Didn't I charge ye ſtrictly? Nay didn't I threaten ye too? But what car'd you? 'Twas all but ſo much Breath loſt. Can ye think me ſo mad, as to believe this woman's brought to Bed?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Oh have I found out his blind-ſide? I know my Cue then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Have ye never a Tongue in your Head Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why what wou'd ye believe? As if you hadn't an Item of this before-hand.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Who ſhou'd give me an Item?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Strange! Did you find out this Impoſture, and your ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Very fine! I'm laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'm ſure 'twas told ye Sir; How ſhou'd you ſuſpect it elſe?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How? cauſe I knew thee for a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: As much as to ſay I was the Contriver on't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nothing ſo certain. I knew't.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Sir you're mightily miſtaken in your Man;

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Miſtaken in my Man!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
For if I go about to ſpeak a Word, you pre
•• ly think that I put upon ye.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Belike I lye then.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Troth at this rate I dare ſcarce move my • ips to ye.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This I'm certain of, that there has been no h •• ly laid here.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Are ye very certain of't? Yet for all that you'll have a Child laid at your door before you're aware on't. This, Sir, will certainly be, and remember that I told ye on't now, that if there ſhou'd happen any Roguery i'th' Caſe, it mightn't be laid to Davus's charge. I wou'd feign have ye believe better things of Davus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But how d'ye know they'll trick a Child upon us?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I heard it, and believe it too. And there are a thouſand Circumſtances which make me be of that mind. For firſt the Gentlewoman cry'd ſhe was with Child by your Son, which is found to be a meer ſham. As ſoon as ſhe heard of a Wedding on foot; her Maid forſooth is poſted away preſently for the Midwife; and for a Child over and above. But if it chance that you ſhou'd not ſee the Child at your door, the Wedding may go on for all this.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How's this?— As ſoon as ye heard of theſe Plots, Pray why cou'dn't Pamphilus ha' been acquainted withal.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And who waſt d'ye think but I that parted them? For the whole Town knew that he was up to the Ears in Love. Now he has ſet his Mind upon a Wife. As for the Buſineſs of the Child, let me alone with that. Go on with the Wedding as you've begun, Heavens proſper it I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Very well!— Now ye may go in, and wait there till I come, and get ready what's wanting.

sp.speaker: Simo
sp.p:
alone. The fellow wasn't very urgent upon me to believe his Stories; and may be all he ſaid wasn't true neither. Be it ſo or no, I care not a Straw: the main thing I ſtand upon is my Son's promiſe.— Well I'll go ſee for my Neighbour Chremes, and beg his Daughter; then if I get
her, I'll have a Wedding to day in ſpite of their • eeths. I don't queſtion my Son's promiſe at all. If he draws back, I can fairly force him to't now—
Here comes the Man in as good time as a body cou'd wiſh.— A good day to ye Neighbour Chremes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O Sir, you're the Man I look'd for.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And I you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You're well met Sir,— there are thoſe who told me they heard from your own Mouth, that this day your Son and my Daughter were to be married. Now I'm come to ſee whether you of they are well in their Wits.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Have a little patience, and you ll hear my Deſires, and an Anſwer to your Queſtion too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well Neighbour, let's hear't then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I beg of ye for Heaven's ſake, by our Friendſhip begun with our Childhood and increas'd with our Years: By your dear Daughter, and my only Son, (whoſe welfare depends wholly upon you) to aſſiſt me in this weighty point? and let the Match ſtill go on, as we formerly deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Pray, Sir, no ſuch Entreaties: As tho I cou'dn't grant it without all this begging. D'ye think I'm not the ſame man as when I made the firſt offer? If the Match be for both their goods, let 'em be ſent for out of hand. But if more harm than good be like to come on't, I'd ha' ye conſi
• er Matters impartially, as tho ſhe were your Daughter, and Pamphilus my Son.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Tis upon ſuch Conditions that I deſire it, and preſs it ſo forward. Nor ſhou'd I ha been ſo urgent, hadn't the Matter requir'd it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As how I beſeech ye?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O Sir, my Son and his Miſtreſs are fallen out.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Meer Tales!

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Believe me Neighbour 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes Faith juſt as I tell ye, Love's a meer Caterwawl, where ſcratc Sing begets kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Say ye ſo Sir, pray then let's prevent th • worſt now we ve fair opportunity, whilſt the edge of his Appetite is taken off by Affronts and I •• uſage. Let's give him a Wife before theſe whe ••
ling Queans by their Tricks and falſe Tears ſoften his Love-ſick Mind to pity. I hope, Sir, wh •• he's once reclaim'd by the pleaſant Converſation of a vertuous Wife, he'll eaſily wind himſelf out of theſe Miſchiefs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You're of this Opinion, but I am not; they'll ne're endure to be together, and I ſhall be as uneaſie under it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But how can you know't, till you've experienc'd it?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis ill buying Experience at the Expence of my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why when the worſt is come to the worſt, if ſuch a thing ſhou'd happen (which Heavens forbid) they can but part. But ſhou'd he once take up and mend, conſider how many Advantages will happen. Firſt I ſhall have my Son well ſettled, you an honeſt Son-in-Law, and your Daughter a good Husband.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's all this ado for? If you're fully perſwaded that all will prove for the beſt, God forbid I ſhou'd be your hinderance in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I have always had a high eſteem for ye.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How come ye to know that your Son and his Miſtreſs are fallen out?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Why Sir, Davus, a Privy-Councellor of
theirs told me ſo, and withal urg'd me to ſtrike up the Match with all ſpeed. And d'ye think he wou'd ha' don't, hadn't he known my Son was willing too.— Now I think on't, you ſhall hear't from his own Mouth.— to Servants within So ho! within there, bid Davus come hither.—
But ſee here he comes himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: to Sim. I was juſt coming to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, whats the Matter?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why don't ye ſend for the Bride, Sir; it grows late. Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: to Chremes. Look ye there now, d'ye hear him?— to Davus Well, Davus, Servants are ſlippery, and I had a fancy once that you were as likely to ſerve your Maſter a ſlippery trick as another body; eſpecially in the Caſe of my Son's Amours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Lord Sir! I do ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I was once of that Opinion, and for fear of the worſt kept ſomething to my ſelf which now • ll diſcover to ye.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And what may that be I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, for I cou'd now find in my heart to truſt thee

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I hope you're ſatisfied in my Fidelity at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: In ſhort, there was nothing of Marriage i' th' Caſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: How, Sir, no Marriage?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas but a Contrivance to feel your Pulſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Will ye tell me ſo?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Even juſt ſo Davus.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why look ye Sir, I could never comprehend this. Bleſs me! there's a damned reach in't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But hear me on now.— No ſooner had I ſent you in, whom ſhou'd I meet but my Neighbour here in the very nick?—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: • S death is't come to this then? Softly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: — I up and told him, What you told me.—

sp.speaker: Dav
sp.p: ſoftly. Confuſion! What's this I hear?

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: — I begged his Daughter, and with much ado prevail'd—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Undone, undone! Softly.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: partly hearing. How? What ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I ſaid 'twas excellently well done.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: As for Mr. Chremes he's ready.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well I'll juſt ſtep home, and put all things in order then I'll come back, and tell ye more o • my mind. Exit Chremes. Davus looks ſimply upon Simo.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Now prithee Davus, ſeeing this is a Ma • ch wholly of thy making.—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: 'Twas wholly of my making with a Pox to't. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: — I d ha' ye take my Son in hand and help to reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I'll do my beſt. Coldly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That's eaſily done now he's upo' th' peeviſh pin.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Well Sir ſet your Heart at reſt

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Do't then, but where's he now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ten to one he's at home.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well I'll ſtep in, and tell him juſt what I told you. Exit Simo.

sp.speaker: Davus
sp.p:
alone. So! I ſhall be hang'd— I ve no more to do, but ſtrait to Priſon goes poor Davus with a vengeance,— there's no crying Peccavi i'th' the Caſe. I've turn'd all Topſey-turvey, impos'd upon the old Man, noos'd his Son into. Matrimony; and brought a Buſineſs about, that
the one never dream'd of, and the other was afraid of— This 'tis to be ſuper-ſubtle! Had I ſat ſtill, and not been tampering, all had been well enough.
But look now, as the Devil wou'd ha't, yonder he comes.— I'm damn'd already.— What wou'd I give for a convenient Precipice to daſh my Brains out. He ſneaks aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to himſelf. Where's the Villain that has undone me?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Heavens! what will become of me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam
sp.p: to himſelf. I muſt confeſs I'm well enough ſerv'd, like a ſenſeleſs ſhort-ſighted Fop as I was what venture my Life and Soul to the Secrecy of a prating Fool? I ſhall pay dear for being a Blockhead; but as I live that Dog ſhan't carry it •• f ſo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If I ſea pe hanging this bout, I'll be ſworn the Gallows will never have me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to himſelf. What excuſe ſhall I pretend to • y Father? Shall I break off, when but juſt now I engag'd my ſelf to marry.— With what Face ſhall I dare to offer it?— I'm at a wretched Nonplus—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: liſtning. And ſo am I in good Faith, tho my wits are on the Tenterhooks; yet I muſt pretend I've that in my Head will fetch him off again, tho 'twere only to put off this plaguy Buſineſs a little longer. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: ſeeing Davus. Hah! Are ye there?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: 'Sdeath he ſees me. Softly hanging his Head.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Pray come hither good Mr. Rogue! what Excuſe now?— Don't ye ſee, you Raſcal, what • miſerable Condition your damn'd Contrivances have brought me in to? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But I'll ſoon bring ye off again.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You bring me off again?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yes Sir, without doubt.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: VVithout doubt as ye did before. Scornfully.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I hope Sir a little better too.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: How can I credit ſuch a Villain? Can you ſet a Matter entirely loſt and deſperate to rights again?— Very fine! what a rare fellow have I rely'd upon? who this day amidſt a calm has rais'd a Storm, and forc'd an odious Match upon me in ſpite of my Teeth?— Didn't I tell you how 'twould be, you Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: You did ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: VVhat d'ye deſerve for your Pains?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: A Halter I muſt confeſs.— But pray, Sir, reprieve me, till I've recover'd my Senſes a little I'll ſoon ſee what's to be done i' th' Caſe.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'm ſorry I han't time to give you your, due. I have ſcarce enough to look to my ſelf much leſs to puniſh you. Exeunt Amio.

div.trailer: The end of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.p:
DId ever any body believe, or but-read of people ſo horribly baſe, as to take pleaſure in the Miſeries of others, and out of them Ruines to make their own Fortunes?— Ah i • this true or no? Yes, yes! 'tis true with a vengeance. There are a brutal ſort of Men that ma'te ſome ſcruple of a down-right Refuſal; but when the time of performance comes; they pluck the Mas • aſide with trembling hands, forc'd to diſcover what they are, and give a flat Denial; then being paſt all ſhame they cry, Pray who are you Sir •
What are you to me Sir? Shall I reſign my Miſtreſs to you Sir? Oh Sir, I'd ha' ye know, Charity always begins at home. If ye charge them with breach of Honour, they re, not aſham'd: they can bluſh when there's no reaſon for't; but when there is, they ſhake hands with their Modeſty.— what Meaſures ſhall I take?— Shall I go to him and reaſon the Caſe with him for this Affront?— I'll give him ill Language enough.— Hold Sir (may ſome ſay) you'll be ne're the better for't— Oh much; I ſhall certainly plague him to ſome purpoſe, and ſo eaſe my Mind a little that way.
div.stage: He goes towards Simo's Door, where he's met by Pamphilus and Davus.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ah dear Sir, I ve moſt inconſiderately ruin'd you and my ſelf too, except Heaven help us.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How! Inconſiderately d'ye call it? then ye • rn't to ſeek for an excuſe. You're a fine Man o' your word indeed. Scornfully.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: How ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: D'ye think to catch me a ſecond time with your Flams?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: What d'ye mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I no ſooner told ye of my Paſſion for Madam Philumena, but you were ſtrangely ſmitten with her.— What a wretch was I to judge of another's Generoſity by my own?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You re ſtill under a miſtake, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Were not your Joys compleat enough before without bubbling me the poor Cully, and • rilling me on with phantaſtick Hopes.— But there! take her for me. Very angrily,

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I take her?— Ah Sir, you can't concieve what troubles I lye under; and to what a miſerable paſs this Raſcal of mine has brought me by his damn'd Projects.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Where's the wonder, ſince he took you for his Pattern.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'm ſure ye wou'dn't talk at this rate if ye knew either me, or my Circumſtanccs.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Jeeringly. Yes, yes: I know very well-ſome words have paſs'd between your Father and you; and that's the reaſon he's ſo very angry with ye: yet he cou'dn't force ye to marry to day.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Nay Sir, to let ye ſee how little ye know my troubles, there was no Wedding to be to day, nor any thing of a Wife deſign'd for me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I know 'twas a voluntary Compulſion.—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But hold Sir, ye don't know the Buſineſs yet.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Yes ſo much on't, that you're juſt upon having her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why d'ye rack me thus? Do but hear.— He never gave over tampering with me to tell my Father I'd marry her: Nay, he lay preſſing and begging o'me, till in plain dealing I cou'd hold out no longer.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What He d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why Davus, that He.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Who Davus?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: 'Tis Davus all over.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Indeed I can't tell, unleſs the angry Gods to puniſh me, made me give ear to that Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: to Dav. Is this true Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ay too true.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What ſay ye Villain? Hah!— The Gallows reward ye for't.— Now anſwer me; if all the Devils in Hell were muſter'd together to force a Match upon him, cou'd they've given fitter advice than this?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I confeſs Sir, I have been a little out-witted, but yet I don't deſpair.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Very likely. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: The laſt Nail wou'dn't go, but we'll drive one that ſhall; unleſs you fancy a bad Beginning always makes a bad Ending.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to Dav. Right Boy; I know if you'll but ſet your wits to work, you'll bring me two Weddings out of one. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Sir, I'm bound, as your Servant, to trudge for ye Night and Day, with might and main, even to venture my Neck, as long as I can do you any good. For what happens croſs you ought to pardon. Tho'my Meaſures were broke, yet I did my beſt; if you can find how to do't better, I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: With all my heart.— But firſt put me in the Condition you found me.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'll do't Sir.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But out of hand then.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Hold 'S't!— Glycerie's Door opens there.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: What's that to the purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: There muſt I make my Plot.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: What's your Plot to ſeek? Hah!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: But now I'dad I've hit on't.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: to Glycerie within. Well! this ſame Pumphilus of yours, I ll go hunt him up, and bring him along with me, if he be above ground— But my dea • don't you lie fretting your ſelf in the mean time? She comes from the door.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Oh Myſis!

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: What's the matter?— turning about Oh Mr. Pamphilus you're well met.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: I am to charm you from my Miſtreſs, that if you have any Love for her, you'd come to her preſently; ſhe ſays ſhe longs ſtrangely to ſee ye.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
Alas, unhappy Man!— My miſfortunes come one upo'th neck of another— to Davus
Muſt we two now be plagu'd upon your account? I am ſent for only becauſe ſhe heard of the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: pointing to Davus. Hadn't this Gentleman been tampering, how well and quiet might all ha' been?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Very well! He's not mad enough himſelf, but you muſt make him worſe. Aſide to Charine.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: to Pamphilus. And truly, Sir, that's it which makes my poor Miſtreſs take on ſo.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Myſis! I ſwear to thee by all that's Sacred, I'll never leave this Creature tho' I ſhou'd loſe all the Friends I have in the whole world for't. This is ſhe I wiſhed for; and my wiſhes are granted; our Humours are well enough ſuited. He that offers to divide us I'll ha' nothing to do with him, Death, and nothing but Death ſhall do't.—

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: I'm revived again.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: The Oracle never ſpake a truer thing.— If the breaking off this Match cou'd be done by any body but me, I ſhou'd be glad on't, but if that can't be, I'll e'en make a bold puſh on't, and own the thing.— What think ye of me? To Charine.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Juſt as deep i'th' Dirt, as I i'th Mire.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: My Brains are at work.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: to Davus. Thou'rt a bold Britain.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to Dav. I know what you'd be at Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Depend on me, I'll do your Buſineſs to your hand. Pam. It muſt be preſently then.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I ha't in my Head, Sir, I ha't.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What's that I prethee?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Your Pardon Sir, I'm working for my Maſter, not for you; therefore don't miſtake me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Well, I'm ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Well, what will ye do now?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p:
Come, come, I want time for my Buſineſs, and muſtn't ſpend it in prating; to deal
plainly with ye, you do but hinder me, and I had rather ha' your Room than your Company.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Well I'll to my Miſtreſs. Exit Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: ſtaring on Charine. Well, what's your Buſineſs here? which way are you ſantring?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Shall I tell ye the very truth?—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: interrupting him. Yes, yes, why not?— we ſhall have a Speech on't.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Prethee what ſhall poor I do?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Very pleaſant I' faith! Arn't ye content that I've put off the wedding, and repriev'd ye for one ſhort day?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But yet Davus—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: interrupting. What but yet?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That I may but marry her.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: A pleaſant Freak!

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Order the Matter ſo that you may come to my Houſe there if poſſible. Pointing to his Houſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What ſhou'd I come for I've no Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: But if ſomething ſhou'd happen—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: interrupting. Well, well, I'll come.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: If there be any occaſion, I ſhall be at home.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Myſis, I muſt go out a little, do but you ſtay till I come back. Myſ. What for?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: For a certain Reaſon that I know.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Prethee be quick then.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'll be here in a trice.

sp.speaker: Myſis
sp.p: alone. Is there nothing in this world that a Man can call his own?— Bleſſed Heaven? I took this Mr. Pamphilus to be the very Heart and Soul of my Miſtreſs, a Friend, a Lover, and in effect a Husband, and all in one, and ready to ſerve her upon all occaſions: And yet after all, what Miſeries do's this unfortunate Woman endure for his ſake? And how much greater is her preſent Trouble, than all her former Satisfaction.
sp.stage: Enter Davus with Glycerie's Child in his Arms.
sp.p: O here comes Davus again.— Prethee good Boy what have we here?— diſcovering the Child Where d'ye carry that Child?—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now Myſis for one caſt of thy Skill and Cunning at a Pinch.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: What Plot's next Davus?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here, take the Child quickly, and lay it at our Door.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Prethee what on the cold Ground?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Can't ye take ſome of thoſe Herbs there, and lay under it?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Well and why can't ye do't your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why if my Maſter put me to ſwear whether I laid it there or no, I may do't with a ſafe Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: I underſtand ye. But pray how came this ſudden qualm upon you?— Give it me then She takes the Child and moves towards Simo's Door.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Prethee go faſter and be back again in a moment, that I may give ye your Leſſon.—
Chremes appears at a great diſtance.
But Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: ſtarting back. What's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Yonder's the Bride's Father; and I muſt e'en go another way to work now.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: I can't imagine what you'd have.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'll make as if I came from that way there o'th' Right-hand.— Be ſure to put in a word or two upon occaſion to make our Stories hang together.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: O'my Conſcience I know your deſigns no more than a Poſt.— If I can do you any Service (which you know better than I) I'll ſtay where I am, without putting any ſtop to your Buſineſs.

p.stage: As Chremes comes towards Myſis, Davus ſneaks to the other ſide

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Every thing's ready now for my Daughter's Wedding, and we've nothing to do more but to invite the Gueſts.— ſeeing the Child at the Door. But what have we here in the Name of Goodneſs?— Goes nearer, and uncovers the Child's Face. A Child upo' my Life.— Hark ye Goſſip! Did you lay this Child here? to Myſis.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: looking fearfully about. Hah! What's become of him?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What are ye Tongue-ty'd?

sp.speaker: Myſ
sp.p: Alas! he's not to be ſeen.— O dear heart, the Fellow has left me and is vaniſh'd.
Davus appears ſeemingly out of Breath, pretending he ſees not Chremes, and bawls as loud as he can.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Bleſs me! what a Buſtle's yonder i'th' Market!— There's a ſquabble indeed— then Corn is confoundedly dear.— Troth I ha' nothing elſe to ſay.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: to Davus. Prithee what muſt I be left alone for thus?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: looking upon the Child. Heyday! what Farce is here?— turning to Myſis Oh ho! whence came this Bantling? Pray who brought it hither? He winks on her.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: not underſtanding. What's the Fellow a Fool to ask me ſuch a Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who ſhou'd I ask? there's no body elſe here to ask?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I wonder whence it ſhould come? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Come will ye give me an Anſwer or no?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: ſoftly to her To the Right-hand a little.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: The Man is mop'd, wan't it your ſelf?—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: ſoftly. If ye offer to ſpeak one word from the Point, at your Peril be it. Holding up his Finger.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Dye threaten me?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: aloud. Whence came this Child?— ſoftly ſpeak out VVench.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: From our Houſe.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: aloud. Ha, ha, ha,— 'tis no wonder if a Strumpet be ſo impudent.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'm miſtaken if this ben't the Andrian's Maid.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Can ye find no body elſe to make ſport with?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I came in the very critical Minute.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You'd beſt make haſte, and be packing with the Child from the Door.— As ſhe is about it, he ſpeaks ſoftly. But ſtay tho; ſee that ye don't budge from this place.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Shame take ye for me, ye do ſo fright me.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: aloud. Is't you I ſpeak to or no?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: VVhy what wou'd the man have?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Have with a Pox? Come tell me whoſe Child you've laid there, once for all, tell me.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: You don't know I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: A fig for what I know; do you tell me what I ask.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: 'Tis yours among ye!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: aloud. Which of ours? All of us didn't get it.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: VVhy 'tis Mr Pamphilus's.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Zookers! what my Maſter Pamphilus's.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Very fine! why isn't it?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I was always i'th' right to be againſt this Match.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: very loud. This is a Roguery deſerves the Laſh.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: VVhy d'ye bawl ſo?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: VVhy didn't I ſee this very Child brought to your Houſe laſt Night?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Oh thou brazen Face!

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'm ſure I ſaw Gammer Cauthara as big as ſhe could tumble with ſomething ſhe carried.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Well 'twas a Bleſſing, that many creditable women were at my Miſtreſs's Labour.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I'm ſure ſhe did not know her Man for whom ſhe deſigned this Trick. I warrant, ſaid they, when Chremes ſees the Child, he'll not part with his Daughter. But i'faith he'll do't the ſooner for that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'faith but he won't tho. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Now therefore in plain Engliſh, if ye don't take away the Baſtard, I'll kick it into the middle of the Street, and take ye and ſet your A— in the Kennel.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: You're either drunk or mad ſure.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: How one piece of Roguery brings out another: Now they begin to buz it about, that this Glycerie is a Citizen of Athens,—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: — So that the Law will make him marry her in ſpight of his teeth.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Under favour, ſweet Sir, Is ſhe not a Citizen?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I had like to have fool'd fair, why I had almoſt noos'd my ſelf. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Whoſe Tongue's that? turning about to Chremes O Sir, you're come in the luckieſt time that can be.— Pray Sir hear me.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I've heard all. Dav. How all?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why all from the beginning.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: You've heard it then?— Fine Rogueries on foot! Now ſhou'dn't this ſame Jade be Carted?— to Myſis Don't think that poor Davus is the Man you play upon. Here's the Gentleman himſelf. pointing to Chremes.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Ah dear! Indeed Sir, an't pleaſe your Worſhip, I han't ſpoke one word of a Lye.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I know the whole Buſineſs.— But is my Neighbour Simo within?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I think ſo Sir. Exit Chremes.
Davus goes to play with Myſis.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Hands off Varlet! If I don't do your Errand to my Miſtreſs, ne're truſt me.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Oh thou ſilly Soul thou dosn't know how the Caſe ſtands.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: How ſhou'd I?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Why this is the Bride's Father, and without all this, he cou'dn't ha' known what we'd have him.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Cou'dn't ye give me an Item before?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Pſhaw! as if there were no difference between what Nature do's briskly on a ſudden, and what's done by dull direction.

p.stage: Enter at a diſtance Crito in a Country habit.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: to himſelf. Why I was told that our Chryſis lived ſomewhere down this Lane. And ſhe found there was more to be got by Jaderyin the Town than Honeſty in the Country. But now as ſhe's dead I'm Heir at Law to her Goods. Where ſhall I ask about her?— O there are Folks.— go's up to them. By your leave I pray.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Goodnow, who's that? Isn't it old Crito, Mrs. Chryſis's Kinſman?— The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: O Myſis! I'm glad to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: And I you, good Crito.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And is it ſo with poor Chryſis, Hah?—

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Yes indeed; ſhe has left us to our ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Crit.
sp.p: Pray how do you do?— How go's the World? Pretty hoddy, Hah?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: What we?— They that can't do as they wou'd, muſt e'en do as they may, as the ſaying is.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: How do's young Glycerie? Has ſhe found her Relations here?

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Ah, wou'd ſhe had.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: What not yet?— Then I've brought my Hogs to a fair Market. 'Sbud if I had known ſo much before-hand, the De'el a foot wou'd I ha' ſtirr'd out o' my Houſe. For ſhe paſs'd with every body for Chryſis's Siſter, and ſhe's now in poſſeſſion of what ſhe had. Now for me, that know no body, to hamper my ſelf in Law-ſuits, there are Examples enough in the world to keep me from burning my fingers. And, now I think on't, ſhe may get ſome ſpruce Gallant to ſtand by her, for ſhe was in the Teens, let me tell ye, when ſhe went from us, the people will cry out, This is a beggarly Raſcal, that ſets up only a forg'd Title. And then a body wou'd make ſome Conſcience too of turning the poor Girl a begging.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: Go thy ways honeſt Crito in troth; thou'rt the ſame Crito ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Come bring me to her however; ſince I'm come ſo far, I'll ſee the poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Myſ.
sp.p: With all my heart.
sp.stage: Exit Crito and Myſis with the Child.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: looking carefully about. I'll follow 'em, but wou'dn't for the world that the old Man ſhou'd ſee me this bout. Exit after them

div.trailer: End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
entring. COme Mr. Simo, you've had proof enough in all Conſcience of my Friendſhip to ye; and I've run riſque enough for you: Therefore pray let us have no more of theſe
Importunities. I ha' comply'd with ye now ſo long, that I was within a very little of undoing my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay Sir, I muſt more and more intreat you and adjure ye, that you'd make good all your Promiſes with your Effects.

sp.speaker: Chr,
sp.p: But pray ſee Sir, how unreaſonable your Paſſion makes ye? For as long as you can obtain your own Ends, you don't regard common Civility, nor well conſider what you'd have your ſelf. If ye did, I'm ſure you wou'dn't deſire to ſerve me after this rate.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: After what rate pray?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah Sir, d'ye ask that Queſtion? You've put me upon marrying my Daughter to a wild Spark o'th' Town, that's pre-ingag'd and a Marriagehater, to have 'em always wrangling, and forc'd to part in a fortnight's time; thus my Daughter's to be mortify'd; and your Son t have the Benefit of it. I promis'd ye and began to perform with ye, whilſt the matter wou'd bear it; and ſince 'twill bear no longer, ye muſt ha' Patience. His Miſtreſs they ſay is a free Citizen, and there's a Child got between 'em; therefore pray don't give us any further diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: For Goodneſs ſake, Sir, don't trouble your Head with ſuch idle Stories. I tell ye 'tis their chief Intereſt to make him as bad they can; this is all a Trick from one end to the other to break off the Match; now do but take away the Cauſe of this, and the Effect ceaſes of it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You're out indeed Sir; for I juſt now ſaw her Maid and Davus quarrelling about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I know the trick.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay they were in earneſt, for they little thought of my ſeeing 'em

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
That I believe too, for I had an Item of this Stratagem from Davus; and I thought t'have
given ye a hint on't, but ſomething put it out of my Head.

p.stage: Enter Davus juſt appearing at Glycerie's Door.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: to them within.— 'Tis my Royal will and pleaſure, that no Grief come within theſe walls to day.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Look ye, yonder's your Man Davus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Whence comes the Rogue? In a fret.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: to them within. Let her rely upon my Worſhip and this honeſt Stranger.—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: liſtning. What's there now a brewing. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: coming from the Door. Well, for the Man, the nick of Time, and the Encounter take 'em all together, never was any thing ſo pat to our purpoſe. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: partly overhearing. Ah damn'd Rogue! Who do's he commend ſo? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: to himſelf. Now Devil do thy worſt; we are as ſafe as a Thief in a Mill.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why don't I ſpeak to him? Aſide

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: perceiving Simo. 'S death here's my Maſter, what had I beſt do? Softly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: to Dav. Oh how is't with your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: O my good Maſters! Simo and Chremes both. Why all things are ready within. Very briskly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You've taken a world of pains I don t doubt. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Now, Sir, ſend for the Bride as ſoon as ye pleaſe. Leeringly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Very well!— there's nothing but that wanting.— But good Sir, let me ask ye one Queſtion.— What buſineſs had you at that Houſe Sirrah? pointing to Glycerie's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who I, Sir? Sim. Ay you Sir.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Meaning me Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes, you Sir, if ye muſt be told ſo often.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why Sir, 'twasn't three minutes ſince I went in—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sirrah, do I ask ye how long ſince? Angrily

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: — With my Maſter Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: haſtily. And is he there then?— O my Torture!— Ye Hang-dog, didn't ye tell me they were broken all to pieces?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So they are Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What ſhou'd he do there then? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What d'ye think Sir?— Only t'other bruſh of quarrelling. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ah Mr Chremes, there's more i'th' Wind; I'll tell ye perhaps one of the fouleſt Stories you ever met withal.— pointing to Glycerie's Houſe Here's a certain old Man juſt come to Town, whence the Lord knows, a ſhrewd wary Fellow, I'll warrant him; if ye did but ſee him you'd ſay he's no ordinary Perſonage; for he looks as grave as an Alderman, and talks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What News from him pray? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Nay, none to ſpeak of— Only I remember he was a ſaying—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well but what was he a ſaying?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: — That he certainly knows Glycerie to be a Citizen of Athens.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Soho! Dromo! Dromo! In a fury.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What a Devil's to do now? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sim Dromo
sp.p: I ſay! Louder.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: But hear me, Sir,— In a fright.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Dog! Speak but another word— Why Dromo, Dromo! Louder yet.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
upon his knees. I beſeech ye Sir, hear me
Enter Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: to Simo. Your pleaſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Take this Raſcal in, and truſs him up imimediately. In a fury.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Who d'ye mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Davus here.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Why good Sir, why?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis my pleaſure— to Dromo take him away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Why what have I done Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Away with him. to Dromo.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: If you catch me in a Lye, cut my Throat.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: ſtopping his Ears. I'll not hear a word— I'll put your Rogueſhip out of Homour.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Notwithſtanding it be true.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Notwithſtanding— do you to Dromo take him and fetter him. And d'ye hear, let him be tyed Neck and Heels like a Beaſt as he is— Away.— Exit Dromo leading in Davus.
As I'm a living Soul, Sirrah, I'll make ye to know this day what 'tis for a Servant to put tricks upon his Maſter, and for a Son to make ſport with his Father. Walking about in a great Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake Sir moderate your Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ah Sir, when it comes to the Duty of a Son, that's a tender point: Don't ye pity me?— that I ſhou'd take ſo much pains for ſuch an ungracious wretch?— Weeps looking towards Glycerie's Houſe. Soho! Pamphilus!— out of your fulſom Neſt.— Ha ye no Grace left?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: VVho calls there?— ſeeing Simo Oh 'tis my Father. I'm Planet ſtruck.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: VVhat ſay'ſt thou, the moſt ungracious— Very angrily.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O fie Sir, leave this ill Language, and argue the caſe calmly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: As tho' the worſt Language wasn't good enough for him.— to Pamphilus and do you ſay now that Glycerie is a Citizen?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo reported, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Reported, Jackanapes?— O prodigious Impudence! was ever ſuch an unthinking Coxcomb? Do's he repent of any thing he has done? Nay has he Grace ſo much as to bluſh at it?— Is he ſo little Maſter of himſelf as to ſet his Heart upon ſuch an infamous woman without regard either to the Cuſtoms or Laws of his Country, or to the will and Pleaſure of his Father?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Oh me! Sighing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O Pamphilus, are ye at laſt convinced?— then, then indeed you ſhou'd ha' thought o'this, when firſt ye took your ſwing in all that's baſe, then you ſhou'd ha' cry'd, Oh me!— walks about in a rage But what do I mean? Why ſhou'd I plague and torment my ſelf? Or why cark my ſelf in my old Age for a mad hot headed Fool? Shall he play the Puppy and muſt I ſuffer for't?— E'n let him have her, make his beſt of her, and Kennel together.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Dear Father!— In a ſoft Tone.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: interrupting. Why dear Father? As tho' you ſtood in need of ſuch a Father.— You've got your Houſe, your Wife and Children, and the dear Father ne're the wiſer; you've brought your Cheat to prove her a Citizen.— You've got the day much good may't do ye.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Pray hear me one word Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What can you ſay for your ſelf? Turning away.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Good Sir, give him the hearing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I hear him? What ſhould I hear him for Mr. Chremes?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But you may let him ſpeak tho.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Let him ſpeak then, who hinders him?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
in a ſoft tone. Sir, I confeſs I loved, and if to love be Sin, I confeſs that too.— But now dear Sir I'm at your diſpoſal, and ſubmit to whatſoever
you ſhall think fit or command. Wou'd ye ha' me marry one woman, and part with another: I muſt bear either, as well as I can. Only thus much let me beg of ye, that you wou'dn t believe that I ſuborn'd this old Man: Let me but clear my ſelf of that and bring him face to face.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Bring him?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Pray Sir let me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but reaſon, pray let him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Sir, I beſeech ye don t deny me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well: let it be ſo then.—
You ſee Sir, I'm content with any thing as long as I ben't groſly impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: A ſmall Puniſhment ſerves for a great Fault, between Father and Son.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: entring.— Well without any more words now; for three Reaſons are as good as three thouſand. I ll do't either for your own ſake, or for Truth's ſake, or for poor Glycerie's ſake, that I've a great kindneſs for.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is that old Crito of Andro?— the very ſame.— Troth Crito I'm glad to ſee thee. What wind blew thee to Athens?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: A chance one.— Is this Mr. Simo?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: D'ye ask for me?— Hark ye Friend,
Ha' you the face to ſay, that Glycerie is a Citizen of Athens?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: And ha' ye the Face to deny it? Pertly.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You've your Leſſon without Book I perceive.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Why that pray? Surliiy.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Wou'd ye know?— Don't ye deſerve to l e laid by the Heels for this? Are you come here to trapan and inveigle raw young Gentlemen?
And to feed their Fancies with fine Flams, and ga • Promiſes?—

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: interrupting What's the man mad? Surlily.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Then you make Matches between the • and their Whores together. Crito ſtares and wo •
ders at the • .

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Alas! how do I tremble for fear the o'd man ſhoudn't ſtand his ground. Aſi •• .

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Simo. If ye knew this man as well as • , you'd be of another mind. Why he's as honeſt • man as e're broke Bread.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The Devil's Broker! He honeſt?— to come juſt i'th nick on the VVedding da • , to ſet up for an Evidence, and was never here before in his whole Life? well muſt his teſtimony carry't?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: If I wern't afraid of my Father, I ve that at my Tongue's end would help him out at a d ••• lift. Aſide,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A Knight o'th' poſt!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: What does be call me? Walks about in a h • ſſ.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis his way, you'd better let him alone.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Let him look to't. If he pretends to talk what e're he has a mind to, I'll make him hear ſomething that he has no mind to. to Simo. Piſh! Do I hinder or care a Fart for your VVeddings? what can't ye bear your Misfortunes like a man?— whether I ſpoke true or falſe you ll know immediately.— turning to Chremes. Once upon a time d'ye ſee, there was a certain Athenian Merchant caſt away at Andro, and that little Girl with him; this man, being in want, had the hap to apply himſelf to Chryſiss Father.—

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: interrupting. Now he begins a fine Tale.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray let him go on.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: VVhy does he put me out? Angrily.

sp.speaker: C • r.
sp.p: On with your Story.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p:
Well! Now this ſame Cryſis's Father, (D •• e
mind?) was my Kinſman. And there did I hear the Man himſelf ſay, that he was a Merchant of Athens; in ſhort, there he dy'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: His Name?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: His Name?— Let me ſee, Oh his Name was Phania.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I'm in a cold ſweat. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p:
Why truly Sir, I think they call him Phania. However, this I'm ſure of, he ſaid he was a
• amnuſian;—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: — And a world of people in Andro heard as much as I.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: aſide. Wou'd it were no worſe than I w • ſh for.— But prithee Crito tell me. What ſaid he about this Girl? Did he ſay ſhe was his own?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Whoſe then pray?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: His Brother's I think.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O' my Soul ſhe's mine then.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: What d'ye ſay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How's this? what ſay ye? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Courage Pamphilus, Courage! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What make ye believe it ſo readily?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why this Phania was my Brother.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I know't: I was well acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'th' time o th' late VVars he fled for't, and •• llow'd me into Aſia, but was afraid to leave my •• ughter behind him. Now Sir, this is the firſt •• ws I ve heard of him ever ſince.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Methinks I'm in another world. My M • nd's diſtracted twixt Fear and Hope, Joy and • onder at ſuch a ſudden B • eſſing. Aſide.

sp.speaker: •• m.
sp.p: I m glad upon ſeveral accounts ſh's found 〈◊〉 your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But hark ye Crito there's one ſcruple yet that makes me uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Wou'd you and your Scruples were hang'd together. This is hunting for a Knot in a Bulr ••• .

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: What's that Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: The Name won't do.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: Truly ſhe had another Name when ſhe was a little one.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Prithee what is't? Don't ye remember?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: I'm hammering at it. He ſtudies upo • .

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: aſide. Shall I ſuffer his ſhallow Brain 〈◊〉 ſtop the Current of my Joys, when I can cure 〈◊〉 with a word ſpeaking? No I ll not ſuffer't D'ye hear Mr. Chremes! Paſſibula is the Name you want.

sp.speaker: Cri. Chr.
sp.p: Ay, that's it, that's it. The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I had it from her own Mouth a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Truly this is good News for all on's, and I hope you think ſo too. to Chremes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As I hope to be ſav'd 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to Simo. And what's to be done next Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why now we are all friends again.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: The beſt of Fathers!— I ſuppoſe Me Chremes will allow us to be in ſtatu quo.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And all the Reaſon i'th' world, unleſs your Father's againſt all.

sp.speaker: Pam. Sim.
sp.p: I'm ſure he's not. I agree to't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Mr Pamphilus, you ſhall have two thouſand Pounds with her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfy'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well I'll to my poor Girl in an inſtant— Come, Crito, go you along with me, for I make a doubt whether ſhe knows me or no.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And hadn't ye better ſend for her now?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I think 'twere better, and that ſhall be Davis's buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But that can't be.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Becauſe he's a little engag'd

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: As how Sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why he's bound Neck and Heels.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ah Sir, 'twasn't well done.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'm ſure I order'd it to be well done.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let him be undone then.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, let it be ſo then.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But immediately Sir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I'll in and about it.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: A bleſſed and happy days work! Ex. Simo.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: to himſelf. Well I'll go to ſee how ſquares go with Mr. Pamphilus.— Oh yonder he is. Obſerves him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Some may be apt to think my Heart is far From what my Lips do utter, but ev'n Now, Now 'tis I'm Conſcious what I ſay's moſt true. That Gods themſelves wou'd not immortal be, Were not their Joys like them immortal too.— And now methinks I'm all encircled round With Heavenly Bliſs, if no Left handed God Come in between and daſh my ſweets with ſowre. Oh for a Friend to whom I might relate This bleſſed Change to make't the more compleat.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: What's the meaning of theſe Reptures?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Oh yonder's Davus, the Man o'th' whole Earth I cou'd have wiſh'd for; for I'm ſure there is not a Soul can more heartily reliſh my Enjoyments.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: to himſelf. Where ſhou'd a man light of this ſame Pamphilus now?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Oh Davus!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: not ſeeing him. Who art thou for a man?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: 'Tis I old Rock!

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: turning about. What you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ay ye don't know what good Fortune I ve met withal.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No Faith! But I know to my ſorrow what Fortune I've met withal. Shrugging his ſhoulders.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ay Boy that I know too.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Juſt as the world goes. Bad News always flys faſter than good.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: My deareſt has found out her Parents.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Before George 'tis brave. Merrily.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: liſtning. Bleſs me! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: And her Father is one of our great Cronies.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Who's that pray?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: No leſs than Mr Chremes.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Spoken like a Cherubim!

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I've now nothing to do but to marry her, and—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: The Man dreams of what he has a mind to waking. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Then for the Child Davus—

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No more of him. I'll warrant ye he'll come to be a Hero at laſt.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: going to them. I'm a made Man, if all this be true,— I'll e'n ſpeak with 'em. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Who goes there?— O dear Charine, you're come i' th' luckieſt time that could be.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I m very well, pleaſed—

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: How! Ha' ye heard the News then?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Every Syllable.— VVell I hope won't forget your old Friend on your VVedding day. Mr. Chremes is now your own, if you'll but ſay the word, I'm ſure he'll do't.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
I ll warrant ye, not forget ye.— 'T wou'd
be too long to wait Mr. Chremes's coming, let's ev'n go to my Miſtreſs where we ſhall be ſure to find him.— But do you Davus go home, and ſend Company to remove her to our's.— What makes ye ſtand like a Poſt?— why don't ye move?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I'm going Sir.—
Gallants, You muſt not expect their return, for the Match and every thing elſe will be made up within Doors.— One Clap, good Gentlemen.

div.trailer: The End of the Fair Andrian.

div.p: The Eunuch. A COMEDY, Acted at the Feaſt of Cybele, WHEN L. Poſtumius Albinius and L. Cornelius Merula were Curule Edil's, By the Company of L. Ambivius Turpio, and L. Attilius of Preneſte.
Flaccus made free by Claudius, Compos'd the Muſick, which was perform'd on two Right-handed FLUTES.
It was taken from the GREEK of Menander;
Acted twice under the Conſulſhip of M. Valerius, and C. Fannius.
A. U. C. 593. before Chriſt 156.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Laches, Father to Phedrie, and Cherea.
Phedrie, His Eldeſt Son, a Gentleman of a ſoft and eaſie Temper, fondly in Love with Thats, whom he keeps.
Cherea, His younger Brother, a hot, wild, amorous Youth, wantonly in Love with Pamphila.
Antipho, A young Gent. Cherea's Companion and Confident.
Chremes, A young Country Squire, ſomewhat blunt in Speech and Behaviour, and unacquainted with the Tricks of the Town.

Thraſo. A Proud, Self-conceited, Pedantick, Bragging, Hectoring, Clowniſh Officer; A Pretender to Thais, and one that believes himſelf a great Wit, and a Man of Courage, when at the ſame time he's both Coward and Coxcomb.

Gnatho, The Paraſite, a hanger on of the Captains; a crafty, ſlie, inſinuating wheadling, buffooning Fellow, always extolling the Captain's Wit and Valour, and by an ingenious equivocating ſort of Flattery, abuſing the Captain to the very Face.
Parmeno, Servant to Phedrie, and his Counſellor, a bold, cunning, intriguing Fellow, and a down-right Woman-hater.
••• us, The Eunuch.
• anga, Servant to Thraſo.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Thais, A Noble Courteſan, kept by Phedrie, a good natur'd Creature, of a flattering, inſinuating, winning diſpoſition.
Pythia, Her Maid very buſie and faithful, a mortal Enemy to Parmeno.
Doria, Another Servant to Thais.
Sophrona, A Nurſe.

list.head: MUTES.
list.item: Simalio, Dorax, Syriſcus, Servants to the Captain.

div.p: Scene, ATHENS,
The Time Six or Seven Hours.

div.head: The EUNUCH.
ACT I.
div.opener:
SCENE, The Street before Simo •
s Door. TIME, The Forenoon.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: entring. WHAT's to be done now? Shan't I go to her?— What not now, when ſhe ſends for me ſo kindly?— Or ſhall I reſolve never to put up the Affronts of a Jilting Miſtreſs?— She ſhut me out; now ſhe invites me in— Go with a Pox?— No that I won't, tho ſhe'd beg it on her Knees.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, if you cou'd hold out at this rate, 'twou'd be the beſt and braveſt thing you ever did: but if ye begin upo'th • Huff, and your Heart not ſerve ye to go through with it; if you faint i'th' Enterprize, and go before you're ſent for, or ſo much as reconcil'd, and ſneakingly tell her, You're ſo entirely devoted to her, as not to live an hour without her, your buſineſs is done to all Intents and Purpoſes. She'll ride you to death when ſhe has you at mercy.— Wherefore I'd ha' you be twice advis'd
before it be too late. For alas Sir, what will reaſon or moderation ſignifie in a Caſe that will bear neither: For Love you know is ſtrangely whimſical, containing Affronts, Jealouſies, Jars, Parlies, Wars, then Peace again. Now for you to ask Advice to love by, is all one as if you ask advice to run mad by.— As for your preſent Reſolutions while your Blood is up, What go to her? When a Rival's preferr • d? My ſelf refus'd? Even Entrance deny'd me? Ne're perſwade me to • t; I'll die firſt. I'll make her know I'm none of her Cully. Why • n good faith Sir, one pitiful hypocritical Drop of a Tear, which this Creature can hardly for her Soul ſqueeze out of her Eyes with all her ſcrubbing, will confound all this bluſter, bring you to your whining Peccavi, and make you ſubmit to • er Ladyſhips's mercy.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p:
Oh horrid ſhame!— Now I ſee ſhe's a • urſed Jilt, and I • a miſerable Fool; I'm ſick on't, • et I die with Love; then I periſh with my Know
•• dge and Senſes about me, both living and look
• ng on. And I know not what to do.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What ſhou'd you do Sir, but free your •• lf from her as cheap as you can? If you can't •• aw the Stake fairly, make the beſt of a bad •• me, and never ſtand vexing your ſelf for the •• tter.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: D'ye think that's the beſt way?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay Sir, if you know the beſt way.— Add no more Troubles to thoſe that Love has • rought on • ye; but bear what's already befaln •• like a Man.—
Oh yonder comes the Cater-pillar that ſpoils all our • aiveſt, and leaves us to ſtarve. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thais
sp.p:
to her ſelf. Unhappy woman! I am very much afraid that Phedrie ſhould take it worſe, or
otherwiſe than I intended, that I did not let him in yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ah Parmeno! I'm all over in a cold ſweat at the very ſight of her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Brisk up Sir! To her I ſay, ſhe carries Fire enough to warm ye with a vengeance

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: over-hearing. How now Phedrie! What are you here? And waiting at the Door too? why didn't ye come in without any more ado?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: The De • el a word's here of ſhutting the Door upon us. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What Speechleſs my Dear?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well askt Madam! for theſe Doors were always wide open to me, and I the higheſt in your Ladyſhip's Favours. Scornfully.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Let theſe things paſs my Dear. Clapping him on the Cheek with her Fan.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: angrily. How! Paſs!— more mildly. Ah Thais, Thais, wou'd that you and I did but love equally, and went an even pace: that what you've done might trouble you as much as me: or that I might concern my ſelf as little at it, as you do.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: interrupting. Prithee don't fret thy ſelf my pretty Phedrie, for by this light twasn't becauſe I lov'd or car'd for any body more than thy dear ſelf, but as the caſe ſtood • twas a thing not to be avoided.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Likely enough: that's uſual.— She poor Soul ſhut him out of doors out of ſtark Love and Kindneſs. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: to Par. Say ye ſo Parmeno?— Well, well, go on:— to Phe. but prithee my Dear, hear but why I ſent for ye.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: We'll hear ye for once.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Firſt let me know, whether this Man here can keep Counſel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Meaning me Madam?— The rareſt Fellow
i th' world at it; but we muſt enter into Articles about keeping your Secrets; if the Story be true, I am as mute as a Fiſh; but if it be a falſity, a Foppery, or a Flam, 'twill out in an inſtant, I'm full of holes, and run like a Seive. Therefore pray Madam, not a word of a Lye as you hope for Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: My Mother was born at Samo, but liv'd at Rhodes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Mum, mum for that.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: There it was that a certain Merchant preſented her with a fine young Girl Kidnapp'd from Attica.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Was ſhe a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſo: We cou'dn't tell for a certain. She told us her Parents Names; as for her Country, and other Tokens ſhe forgot, nor cou'd it be otherwiſe expected becauſe of her Age. The Merchant added withal, that he underſtood by the Pyrates (of whom he bought her) that ſhe was ſtoln from Sunio hard by Athens— No ſooner did my Mother take charge on her, but ſhe gave her the beſt Education ſhe cou'd, and bred her up like her own Child: So that we were generally taken for Siſters. In company with that Stranger (the only perſon I was then engag'd withal) did I come hither, who left me all I have at preſent.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: interrupting. A couple of Rappers.— Guſh.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Becauſe forſooth one Diſh to be ſure wou'd never ſatisfie you, neither was he your ſole Benefactor; for this Gentleman's Pocket has ſmoaked to ſome Tune for moſt of your Bravery.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p:
Be it ſo: But can't you let me go on with my Stor?— to Phe. whilſt things ſtood thus: the Captain, who began to take ſome liking to me marched into Caria, mean time I got acquainted
with thee my dear Rogue. And thou knoweſt how dearly I have lov'd thee e're ſince, even to the truſting thee with the greateſt of my Secrets.—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Parmeno will let go again.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You may ſwear it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: For Loves ſake, dear Hearts! hear me out— Not long after my Mother died at Rhodes; now my Uncle, you muſt know, was a little given to the World, and perceiving the Girl was very likely, and had a good hand at the Lute, hoped to make Money of her, and forthwith expoſed her to Sale, and made his Markets on her. As good Luck wou'd have it, my Friend the Captain being there, buys her for a Preſent for me, being perfectly ignorant of this whole Affair. He's juſt come to Town, and perceiving what's between you and I, he invents many Excuſes and Flams to put off his parting with her as long as he can: But ſays, cou'd he but perſwade himſelf I lov'd him better than you, and were he not miſerably afraid that when I once got her I ſhou'd turn him off, he'd part with her preſently. This he's ſtill afraid of, but as far as I can perceive he has a hankering after her himſelf.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: And is it got no farther than hankering?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: No, for I ve made ſtrict enquiry— Now my dear Phedrie, I've a thouſand Reaſons why I'd wheadle him out of her. Firſt, becauſe ſhe goes for my Siſter; and then to reſtore her to her Friends; for I'm a loneſome Woman here, no body with me, neither Friend nor Kinſman; therefore I hope by this good Office to make my ſelf Friends; therefore if you love me help me out in the Management of this buſineſs: Let this Swaggerer be Maſter of Miſ-rule for two or three days— What no Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p:
Thou baſeſt of thy Sex!— What ſhall
I anſwer thee, who dealeſt ſo ungratefully by me? Walks about in a Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O rare Maſter o' mine! Gramercy ſay I: He's touch'd now— E'dad thou'rt a Man every Inch of thee.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: As if I didn't know what you wou'd be at.— in another tone mocking her A young Girl was Kidnapp'd hence,— my Mother bred her up like her own,— ſhe went for my Siſter— Id fain wheadle him out of her— and reſtore her to her Friends— All this ſtuff is to ſhift me off, and to take in your Captain forſooth; But why I pray? Only becauſe he's more in your Ladyſhip's Favour than I am? and you're plaguily afraid this Girl will put your Noſe out of joynt, and take your Iuſty Stallion from you.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Who I afraid on't?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ay you: Why ſhou'd you be ſo concerned elſe? Is he the only Perſon that has made you Preſents? Did ye ever find me cloſe fiſted? T'other day you asked for a Black, didn't I go Poſt haſte and get you one? And then you'd have your Eunuch forſooth, purely, becauſe your Ladies of Quality have 'em, this I got too: I'm ſure yeſterday I paid down o'th' nail no leſs than fifty Guineas for 'em both. Tho I'm ſlighted by ye, yet you ſee I didn't forget ye; and my Good nature's finely rewarded.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: How's this my Phedrie! No, tho' I ſhou'd be very glad to have this Girl, and I believe I might this way as eaſily as may be; yet rather than diſoblige thee, I ll do what thou wou'd'ſt have me Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Oh that that word came from your Heart now rather than diſoblige thee. Cou'd I but believe that was ſpoken ſincerely, I cou'd then bear any thing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He ſtaggers: one damned wheadle has don't in a trice.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Ah dear! Don't I then ſpeak from my Heart? When did I ever deny you a Requeſt, tho 'twere made but in a jeſt? And yet I can't for my Soul obtain the Favour of your abſence but for two days.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ay if it were but two days— But what if that two ſhou'd prove twenty?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, It ſhall be no more than two or—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: interrupting. Or what? No more on't.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: It ſhall be no longer indeed. Let me prevail with thee for once.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well for once you ſhall have your Mind.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Now I love thee moſt wonderfully, thou haſt ſo obliged me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well I ll into the Country, and there pine away for theſe two days.— That's my Reſolution ſince my cruel Dear muſt have her Humour.— But Parmeno, do you take care to deliver the Eunuch, and Black in my abſence.

sp.speaker: Parm.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: God b'uy my deareſt Thais, for two long days.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: God b'uy to thee my ſweet Creature. Ha' you any other Commands?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What can I deſire further; but that tho the Captain has your Company, yet your Heart may be at another place: Let me both night and day be the Entertainment of your Love, your Wiſhes, your Dreams, your Expectations, your Thoughts, your Hopes, your Pleaſure, your All. In fine, let your Heart be as much mine, as mine is yours

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Dear Heart! I'm afraid Predrie believes not one word of what I have ſaid, but takes me for one of your Jilting Creatures of the Town. But I that know my own Heart beſt, am ſure, I've devis'd no Flams; nor is there any Soul I love ſo fondly and tenderly as this Gentleman. And whatſoever I have done i'th' caſe was purely for the ſake of the poor Girl, whoſe Brother, a perſon of ſome Repute, I hope I've in a manner found out. To day he appointed to give me a viſit, I ll ſtep in and wait his coming.

div.trailer: End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: DO as I order'd ye, Let the Preſents be carry'd.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: So they ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: But with care then.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: It ſhall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: But with ſpeed too. Par. It ſhall ſo.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Have I •• 'd ye enough on't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: All! Thats a Queſtion indeed?
As tho' 'twas ſo hard a piece of buſineſs.— For my part Sir, I wiſh with all my Soul that you were as ſure of winning a Thouſand pounds as ye are of loſing theſe Preſents.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Prithee don't trouble your Head about thoſe things, for if I loſe them I loſe my ſelf too, which is far the greater loſs.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: It ſhan't trouble me, but I ll do your Buſineſs effectually.— Have you any further Commands for me?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Be ſure you ſet off the Preſents with all the Commendations you can; and give my Rival all the Interruption imaginable.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pſhaw! I'd ha' done that without your bidding.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well I ll into the Country; and there tarry.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I fancy ſo.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: returning. But hark ye Parmens.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's your pleaſure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Doſt really think I can have ſo much power o're my ſelf as to hold out my whoſe time?

sp.speaker: Par.
