sp.p: Who you Sir? No Faith: For either you'll come back again preſently, or elſe your want of ſleep will ſend ye hither at Midnight with a Whynot?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'll tire my ſelf as much as I can, that I may ſleep whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Twon't do Sir, tire your ſelf as much as ye pleaſe, you'll be ne're the nearer

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: All this ſignifies nothing Parmeno.— I muſt break the neck of this eſt • minate Humour; I indulge my ſelf too much; in ſhort, d'ye think I can't live without her three whole days if occaſion ſerve?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How Sir! What three live long days? For ſhame Sir! Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Nay I'm ſully reſolved upon't however.

sp.speaker: Parmeno
sp.p: alone. Heavens! What a plaguy thing's this! that Love ſhould alter men ſo ſtrangely, as you can't know 'em for the ſame? There was never a Gentleman in Town had a better Head-piece a graver Carriage, and leſs given to the Fleſh than this maſter of mine.—
sp.stage: Enter Gnatho leading Pamphila, attended by her Waiting Maid at a diſtance from Parmeno.
sp.p: But who comes yonder i'th' Name of Goodneſs? Ha, ha, 'tis that wheadling Raſcal Gnatho, a hanger on o' th' Captains. He has got the young Gentlewoman by the Fiſt, as a Preſent to his Lady.— Bleſs me what a ſmug-faced little Rogue it is. No wonder if I make but a ſcurvy Figure to day with my old rotten Eunuch.— Why this Creature cuts out Thais her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Gnatho,
sp.p:
to himſelf. Bleſs me! to ſee the difference between one man and another, betwixt a Fool and a Philoſopher! The thing I ſay it for is this: As I was coming along to day I ſtumbled upon one of my own Rank and Quality; an honeſt Fellow I ll warrant him, who had made a ſhift to guzzel away an Eſtate as I had done before him. I ſeeing ſuch a rough, naſty, meager Fellow, rigg'd out with Rags and Rheumatiſms. Whats the meaning of this fine Dreſs? quoth I, Alas! (ſaid he) I had an Eſtate once, but play'd the Fool and coudnt keep it, and you ſee what Im brought to: All my Friends and Acquaintance fly me as they wou'd the Plague— Here I began to look down upon him with ſcorn: Why you whorſon Blockhead, ſaid I, is it come to that then, that you hadnt left your ſelf an Aftergame? Have ye loſt your Brains and your Money together? Why do but look on me, who was once in the ſame Caſe with your ſelf? How freſh and ſparkiſh, how Genteel I go, and how ſtrong and luſty I am? I have the Indies at Command, tho Lands I have none; and tho I have ſcarce a Groat in the world, yet I want for nothing. In another Tone But (ſays he) Im of ſuch an unluckly Conſtitution that neither buffooning nor beating will agree with me. How's that, ſaid I, d'ye think that's the way? No you're plaguily wide o' th' Mark. In the days of Yore
this might have done well enough: but we are now in another Method, and perhaps I was the Inventer of it too— There's a ſort of people in the World who • et up for Wits of the firſt Rate, and yet have no more Brains than Maggots: Now theſe are the Men for my turn: but then I am not their Merry-Andrew to make them ſport, but very readily make ſport at them, tho at the ſame time I praiſe their parts to the Skies. If they ſay any thing, I cry it up too. If they unſay it, I commend 'em for that too: What they deny, I deny: What they affirm, I affirm: In fine, Ive brought my ſelf to be juſt of their Mind in every thing: and by this means, I get many a ſweet Bit, and a ſweet Penny.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A very pretty Fellow upo' my word! Give him a Fool and he'll make him a Mad-man. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Whilſt this Chat laſted we got to the Market-place, where I was joyfully met by a Troop of Confectioners, Fiſhmongers, Butchers, Cooks, Paſtrymen, Fiſhermen, and Poulterers; all of my old Cronies whom I had been a good Cuſtomer to before, and ſince I had ſpent my Eſtate, and am ſo ſtill: They Complimented me with Hat in Hand, invited me to Supper, and were very glad to ſee my Worſhip: when my poor hunger-ſtarvd Comrade ſaw I was ſo highly in their Books, and live ſo bravely at eaſe, he begg'd o' me for Heaven's ſake to teach him a little of my Art. I bid him follow me, and be my Pupil; and as the Sects of Philoſophers borrowed their Names from their Maſters, ſo all that have learn'd the Art of Wheadling ſhould from me be calld Gnathonicks.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To ſee the virtue now of living at eaſe, and being fed at another Man's Table Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
But hold Im plaguy backward in handing this preſent to Mrs. Thais, and to invite her to the Treat— advances towards the Door and ſees Parmeno yonder's Parmeno our Rival's Servant all
i'th' dumps before the door: Our Buſineſs goes ſwimmingly on; theſe Sparks will have but a cold Suit on't— I'm reſciv'd to have a little ſport with this poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I warrant they think this Gift will make the Lady theirs for ever. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
My nown dear Friend! Gnath •
's thy very humble Servant. Well what are ye upon now?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Upon my Legs. Surlily.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I I ſee that.— But don't ye ſee ſomething here that offends your Eye-ſight. pointing to Pam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Yes you. Surlily.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: That I believe too.— But is there nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why what ſhould there be?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Becauſe, my Friend, you ſeem to be a little out of Humour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Nay I wou'dn't have ye do ſo.— But what think ye of this Preſent? Hah!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why ſhe's tolerable.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I've gall'd him I ſee. Softly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: over-hearing. How plaguily he's miſtaken now? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Won't Madam Thais be mightily taken with this Preſent think ye?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As much as to ſay our Noſe is out of joint: But hark • e Friend, every Dog has his day; there is a time for all things.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Now, Parmeno will I give thee a Holy-day for this half Year; and ſave thee the trouble of trotting up and down, and ſitting up till four or five in the morning. Don't I do ye a prodigious piece of Service? Par Who me? Ay a damnable one.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Thus I always oblige Friends.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You do well.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: But perhaps I detain ye Sir; your buſineſs poſſibly calls ye elſewhere?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No I'm at my Journey's end.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Pray Sir, do me the favour then to introduce me to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Very good! This preſent will be your Paſport now.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Will ye be pleas'd to have any one ſent out to ye? Exit Gnatho, Pamphilia, and Waiting Maid

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: alone. Let but two days be over, and I'll take care that you may knock till your Heart akes without admittance, tho' now you are ſo happy as to have the Doors flye open at a touch of your little Finger.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: What here ſtill my nown Friend? D'ye keep guard here that not an Embaſſy by a Civil Meſſenger can paſs privately between the Captain and the Lady? Exit Gnatho.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: alone. Very wittily ſpoken! Theſe wonderful fine things muſt needs pleaſe the Captain? ſeeing Cherea. But hold, I ſee my Maſter's younger Son making this way.— I wonder what makes him from his poſt at Pireo, when he's upon Duty there.— There's ſomewhat more than ordinary in the wind;— And he's in great haſte too— I can't gueſs what makes him throw his Eyes about thus.
sp.stage: Enter Cherea at a diſtance from Parmeno, out of Breath, and looking about him.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'm undone! The pretty Creature's loſt— And ſo am I— who have unluckily miſt on her. Where ſhall I look for her? where ſhall I trace her? whom ſhall I ask for her? what blind Alley ſhall I range in?— I'm in a ſtrange Quandary.— I've this comfort left, that ſhe can't be long incognito where'ere ſhe be.— The moſt charming Look! From this Moment, I've done with the whole Sex be • ides. Your Every-day Laſ • es and Faces will ne're down again.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Heyday! Here's another in the whining and languiſhing Vein, or I'm beſide the Cuſhion— The old Gentleman their Father's finely bleſt? If this Spark once begins the Sport, he'll be ſo mad upon't, that Mr. Phedrie will be a Child to him.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Wou'd the De'el had this old Mumſimus for ſtopping my Journey: And me too for ſtaying, when I ſhould have taken no notice of him.— Ho! here's Parmeno! Well met old Friend.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why ſo concern'd, and yet ſo Gay? And whether a going?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Who I? Troth I can't tell whence I came, nor where I'm going, I've loſt my Senſes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How ſo I beſeech ye?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I'm in Love man.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Heyday.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Now old Boy, ſhew what a Man your are: thou knoweſt how often thou haſt promiſed me: Maſter Cherea, do but find out one you ve a mind to, and I'll ſhew what a Talent I have at Intriguing: You remember twas when I uſe to get you many a good bit out of my Fathers Pantry, and no body e're the wiſer, ye Rogue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pſhaw no more of that.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Why, Faith • twas e'en ſo: Therefore prithee now be as good as thy word, at leaſt if you think it worth beating your Brains about.— This pretty Creature isn't at all like our Town Ladies, whoſe Mothers ſaddle their backs, and ſtrait-lace their Waſts to make em well ſhap • d. If any chance to grow a little plumper than the reſt, they preſently cry, She's an Hoſteſs; and then her Allowance muſt be ſhortned, and tho ſhe be nat •• aly fat and luſty, yet by her dieting ſhe's made as ſlender as a B •• omſtick: By this means one Woodcock or another is caught in their Springe.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And how's yours I beſeech ye?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Such a Beauty, the World never ſaw.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Hey-day!

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Her Complexion true and natural; Her Body ſound and ſtrong, and as plump as a Partridge.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How old think ye? Che. About Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: In the very prime I faith.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Now, do you but help me to this ſweet Creature, either by force, fraud, or wheadle, I don't care which way, ſo I do but enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But what is this ſweet Creature?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Faith I know not.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Whence came ſhe?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Where does ſhe live?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Nor that neither.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Where did you ſee her •

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: In the Street here.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How came you to loſe her?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: That's it I was curſing at, when I met you Nor do I think there's that Man living, whoſe good Fortune had left him thus in the lurch. What a Misfortune was here!— I'm a very Wretch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's done to ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: De • s ask? Don't ye know old Archidemides, my Father's Kinſman and Companion?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: This Fellow met me full butt, as I was hot upo' th' Scent after this pretty Creature.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Faith 'twas a little unſeaſonable.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Rather deviliſh unfortunare: for lighte • Matters may be call'd unſeaſonable For I can ſafel • ſwear, I hadn't ſeen him this half Year till now, when I neither deſir'd nor wanted his Company. V • asn't this a damn'd Accident? Hah! what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As you ſay, Sir, 'twas a damn'd Accident.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: He comes hobbling after me as far as he could ſee me, with his Chin and his Knees together; his Joynts ſhaking in his Hide; hanging his Jib like an old Horſe, and groaning like a rotten Sheep; He bawls out, Soho, Cherea, Soho! 'tis you I wou'd ſpeak with.— With that I made a halt. De'e know, ſays he, what's my Buſineſs with ye? No, pray tell me Sir. Oh, ſaid he, my Cauſe comes on to morrow. And what then, ſaid I? Why be ſure (quoth he) to tell your Father, that he muſt not fail to be at th'Court. I think he was a whole hour by the Clock in telling this. I ask'd him if he had any further Buſineſs, he ſaid None at all. Away march I: And looking for this young Creature, I found ſhe had taken down this Street.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: My Life on't, if this ben't the ſame that was preſented to Thais. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: As ſoon as I was got hither ſhe was vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Had ſhe any Attendance with her?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Yes a Man and a Waiting-maid.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Aſide. The very ſame i'faith.— Set your Heart at reſt, Sir, your buſineſs is done.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Sure thy Wits are a Wool-gathering.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No, I know what I ſay.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Why, can'ſt tell who ſhe is?— Prithee • ell me.— Did ye ſee her? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I did ſee her, I know her too, (more than that) I can tell where ſhe's gone too.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Ah dear Rogue! Doſt know her indeed?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And can • ſt tell where ſhe's gone too?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
She was brought hither as as a Preſent to
•• a • s.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Is any Man living able to be at the Charge •• ſuch a Preſent?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Yes, Captain Thraſo, your Brother's Ri
••• .

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: For ought I ſee my Brother will be put to his laſt Trumps then.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay Faith! ſo you'd ſwear indeed, if you knew what a precious Preſent he has provided to match this withal.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What's that prithee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: An Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What that Tool of a Man that he bought yeſterday? That haggiſh Fellow?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That's he Sir.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Certainly he and his preſent will be kick'd to the Devil.— But I ne're knew before that this Thais was our Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why ſhe's lately removd hither.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Unlucky Whelp that I am! That I ſhou'd ne're ſee her.— But prithee tell me is ſhe ſuch a Beauty as they talk of? Par. Every Jot.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: But ſhort of our's my Life on't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Quite another thing.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Prithee honeſt Boy, do but thy beſt to bring us both together.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You ſhall have my good will in't. I'll do what I can to help ye: What wou'd he have more;

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Whither away now?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why home to hand the Preſents hither according to your Brothers Orders.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Oh the Luck of this ſame roguy Eunuch, to go into this Houſe upon ſuch an Errand!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: De • e ask that? Why he'll always be bleſt with the ſight of his beautiful Companion; they li talk together, live together, and now and then perhaps lie together.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What wou'd you ſay now, if you were that bleſſed Creature?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Which way? Speak dear Rogue. Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Suppoſe you take his Cloaths,—

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: His Cloaths? And how then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And be carry'd thither inſtead of him,—

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: On, on Boy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And give out that you are he.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I ſmall your deſign.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And there you may enjoy all thoſe rare Bleſſings you fancied but juſt now for another. You may eat and drink with her, ſit by her, touch, •• y with her, and— lye by her. For not a Creat • re in that Houſe can tell what you are, or whence you came. And beſides, your Age and thoſe Smooth chops of yours will make you paſs •• r a Compleat Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
Spoken like an Angel! and advis'd like an Oracle!—
• hugs Parmeno, and is carrying him off.] Come away Boy, let's in and about it, equip me to •• ghts now, immediately away with m • , and bring me to her as faſt as you can for your Life.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: ſtruggling. Hold Sir!— what d'ye mean? I did but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw! That's Nonſence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'm ruin • d! How like a Fool have I done! where d'ye thruſt me Sir?— Faith you had almoſt • uſht me on my Noſe— 'Tis you I ſpeak to Sir. Pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: But I ſay let's go.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Are ye reſolv'd upon't then?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Abſolutely.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Have a ca • e you don't make more haſte 〈◊〉 good ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: No, no, let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A • but my Bones will ſmart for't. Oh! 〈◊〉 horrible Villany!

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
A Villany d'ye call it for a Man to go into a •• dy-Houſe; and a pay a Company of ſilts in their • n Coyn? why if they make a Trade to abuſe,
torment and trepan innocent young Men, is it not Juſtice and Equity to plague and chouſe them again?— Shan't I rather play Tricks with them, than with my Father? This I ſhou'd be blam'd f • r; as for t'other, 'twould be ſaid, I ſerv'd them in their own kind.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How's this! Well! if ye be fully bent 〈◊〉 on't, e'en take your own courſe; but then 〈◊〉 lay the blame at m • door afterwards.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I won't then.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And is it your will to have it ſo?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Tis my will to have it ſo, and it muſt 〈◊〉 ſo, and it ſhall be ſo; and what I have ſaid I w •• ſtand by.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Nay then follow me.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Venus and Cupid favour the Deſign.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: WELL, but was ſhe ſo very thankf • l then?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: O yes Sir, moſt hugely.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And glad at Heart ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: O yes, but not ſo much for the Gift as the Giver: and for that let me tell ye ſhe's plaguil • . proud on't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'm come to watch a fair Opportunity to bring my Preſents in too.— But hold! Here's Captain Bellſwagger. Retires to one ſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p:
Really I have the luck on't; every
thing that I do is moſt wonderfully taking.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I have obſerv'd as much.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: The King of Perſia, whenever I did him a kindneſs, was always very ſenſible of it: He wasn't ſo to every body.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: A ſmart Tongue ſo well hung as yours, makes all that Glory his own, which others ſo long have toil'd for.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Right Boy!

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: The King has you in his Eye then?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Right again.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: And loves to have you there.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No doubt on't.— Nay more he truſted his whole Army to my Conduct, and follows my Advice in every thing.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Prodigious!

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Then if he chanc'd to be weary of Comp • ny or Buſineſs, and had a Mind to take a little eaſe— as the— you know what I mean.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, As tho' when he had a mind to clear his Stomach, as a body may ſo ſay, of all Concerns,—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Right, then would he take me to him Hand to Firſt.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Ay marry Sir! this is a King indeed.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Oh! He's a man of a Thouſand.—

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Yes, one of a million— if he chuſe you for his Companion. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: All the Officers envy'd me, and grumbl'd at me behind my back: I didn't value it a Straw; they envy'd me damnably. But above all, one who had the Charge of the Indian Elephants. This Fellow being more troubleſome than the reſt, Prithee Strato, ſaid I, why ſo plaguy Big? Is it becauſe you are Lord o're a parcel of Beaſts?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Neatly ſaid, i'faith, and ſhrewdly.— Bleſs me! You overthrew Man and Beaſt— What ſaid he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Nay I don't know how he ſhould.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bleſs me! This Captain's the blindeſt Coxcomb, and the other the vileſt Raſcal I ever ſaw. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What think ye Gnatho? Did I ever tell ye how ſharp I was upon the young Rhodian Spark at a Feaſt?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Never, Sir, let's hear it, I pray,— He has told it me a thouſand times. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: This Rhodian Spark I told ye of, was with me at a Feaſt, where by chance I had a ſmall Girl; this Strippling began to be ſweet upon her, an • waggiſh upon me too. How now you impudent Saucebox, (ſaid I) you're Man's meat your ſelf, and yet have a mind to a Tit-bit.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What's the matter? Hah!

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Very fine, ſharp and delicate; that could not be mended.— But pray, Sir, was this a • l your own? I took it for an old one.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why did you ever hear't before?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, very often: And it takes extreamly.—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I'll affure you, 'twas all my own.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I am ſorry you were ſo ſharp upon the fooliſh young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ah the De'el take thee for a Raſcal. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what did he ſay then?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: He was quite daſh'd out of Countenance; And the whole Company was ready to die with Laughing. After that every body was plaguy wary of meddling with me.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: And well they might.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: — But hark ye, Gnatho, had I beſt clear my ſelf to Thais from the jealouſie ſhe has of my being in love with Pamphila.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Let that be the leaſt of your Thoughts; but rather give her more cauſe to be jealous.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: That's a Queſtion: Don't ye apprehend me Sir? Should ſhe but ſpeak a word of Phedrie, or offer to commend him on purpoſe to plague you.—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: That.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Your only way to prevent that, is, whenever ſhe names Phedrie, be ſure you hit her in the Teeth with Pamphila; if ſhe cries, let's have Phedrie to be merry with us, do you anſwer, And Pamphila to give us a Song: If ſhe praiſe his ſhape, extol her Face: And be ſure give her a Rowland for her Oliver, and that wil vex her to the Heart—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Ay, if ſhe loved me, this might do, Gnatho.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: As long as ſhe deſires and loves your Preſents, you may lay your Life ſhe loves you. So 〈◊〉 you may venture to teaze her; ſhe'll always 〈◊〉 leſt any angry word ſhould turn the 〈◊〉 of your Bounty another way.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Thou ſay'ſt right.— Why I never ſo much as dream'd of this before.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: A good Jeſt i'faith: Sure you didn't give your Mind to't; for had you ſet your Wits about it, your Contrivance wou'd ha' been worth fifty of mine
sp.stage: To them enter Thais attended by Pythia.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I fancy'd I heard the Captain's Tongue juſt now.— Oh, here he as— My dear Heroe, welcom. Hugs him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Oh, my ſweet Thais, my dear Honey, how, is't.— Don't ye love me now, for giving you this pretty Wench?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Admirable i'faith! how nobly he opens the Campagne. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I'm eternally obliged to you for't.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Let's in to Supper I ſay: why this dallying?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Here's another too! Faith one wou'd ſwear he is the Captain's Baſtard, they're ſo like one • nother. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Gnatho. As ſoon as you will, for I am ready.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: advancing nigher. I'll to her, and make as tho I juſt came from home.— Are you going a broad Madam. Aſide to Thais

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: to him. Oh Parmeno, troth you are co •• very lucky, I was juſt a going out.

sp.speaker: • ar.
sp.p: Whither Madam?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why don't ye ſee this Gentleman here. Aſide to him

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I do ſee him, with a pox, to my ſorrow.— When you pleaſe Madam, my Maſter's Preſents a •• at your Service. Aloud

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What do we • ſtay for? why don't we ••• on?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: to Thraſo. May it pleaſe your Honour, by your leave; firſt let me make my Preſents as I was ordered, and go and have a little harmleſs Chat with the Lady.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Special Preſents! I'll warrant ye not to •• nam'd the ſame day with mine. Jeerin • .

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: The Trial's all— Goes towards Lach Houſe So-ho! within there! ſend out the pe • ſon, I ordered— Enter the Blackamoor. Here advan ••• forward— Here's a Laſs come from as far as Preſter John's Country.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I can have as good for Seven or Eight Guineas.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Ay and a better too.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: to them within You, Sir, Doras where are ye? ſtand forth Boy.— Here's your Eunuch for ye then— ſee what a pert look he has got, and • aſt in the prime of his Age. Enter Cherea dreſſed up like the Eunu • h.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: As I hope to be ſaved a very tight Fellow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What ſay ye now Mr. Gnatho: D'ye ſpy any Faults here?— And you noble Captain?— what never a word?— That's Commendation enough of all Conſcience.— Try him in the Schools, Field, Muſick, or where you will, you ll find he has had the Education of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: For a need that Eunuch wou'd down well enough, tho a man was ſober. Aſide to Gnatho.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And yet Madam, the Gentleman that made theſe Preſents, dosn't deſire to be your only Favorite, nor that all others ſhould be thruſt out of doors for his ſake: He dosn't tell your Romantick Stories of his Fights and Duels, nor yet boaſt of his Wounds and Scars; neither does he ſtand in your Light, as a certain perſon that ſhall be nameleſs. But when it ſhall be no trouble to you Madam, when you pleaſe, and your Ladyſhip is at leiſure,he thinks it favour enough to be then admitted.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Tis Evident this Fellow has got ſome poor Grubſtrect Merchant for his Maſter.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Faith like enough; for he wou'dn't keep this Fellow ſo long, had he a Shilling in his Pocket to hire him a better.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Peace Dog.— Thou art not worthy to • e kick'd— If you can ſtoop to flatter him, pointing to the Captain thus, you'd be content to do the moſt ſordid thing in the world for a livelihood.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Shall we ſtay to hear this Fellow prate?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I'll only juſt ſtep in with theſe, and order my Maids what to do; and I'll be back again in an inſtant. Exeunt Thais, Che. and the Black.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I ll go before— B • t do you ſtay and wait upon my Miſtreſs. to Gnatho.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Fie! 'tis beneath a General to Squire his own Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Parmeno. Why ſhould I ſpend my Breath upon thee?— Like Maſter like Man.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What d'ye laugh at? Somewhat ſurlily.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
Why what you juſt now ſaid: Beſides you put me in mind of the Rhodian Spark, and I cou'dn't forbear— but here's Madam Tha ••
again.
Re-enter Thais, Pythia and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Run home and ſee that all the Rooms • o ready.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: I'm gone Sir. Exit Gnatho.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: to Pythia. Be ſure Pythia take care to do what I bid ye— if Mr. Chremes ſhou'd chance to come to day, deſire him to ſtay a little; if he's in haſte, beg him to come another time; if he can't do that, ſend him over to the Captains to me.

sp.speaker: Pyt.
sp.p: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Hold— I had ſomething elſe to ſay.— Let me ſee,— O I remember't— Be ſure you make much of the young Gentlewoman. Do you keep home. Exit Pythia

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Now let's march.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Do you follow me. to the Attendants. As they go off one way, enter Chremes alone another way.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
In troth the more I think and chew upon this buſineſs, the more I'm afraid that this Thais ſhould play me ſome plaguy Dog-trick or other; I find my ſelf damnably wheadl d by her. When ſhe firſt ſent for me,any man might have wondered what buſineſs I had there; Faith I cou'dn't tell my ſelf: but when I came, ſhe immediately caſts about for Fetches and Excuſes to make me
tarry. I have, (ſays ſhe) juſt now been at my Devotion, therefore more fit to diſcourſe of grave and ſerious Matters. At that my Heart miſgave me plaguily. She drew a Chair and ſat down by me, and fawning upon me, ſhe began to pump for diſcourſe. When ſhe had nothing elſe to ſay, ſhe'd fall a asking me, How long my Father and Mother had been dead? I told her, a pretty while ſince: Then, whether I had not a Seat at Sunio, and how far it ſtood off the Sea. Pox! I believe ſhe liked the Situation her ſelf, and had a mind to gull me out on't. And laſtly, If I hadn't loſt a young Siſter thence? and who was with her then? What ſhe had about her whenloſt? Whether 'twas poſſible for one to know her again? And ſuch like Stuff. I can't imagine why the De'el ſhe ask'd all theſe Queſtions; without ſhe deſigns to put her ſelf upon me inſtead of this loſt Siſter; as it is the • mpudence of theſe Jades. However if ſhe is alive, 〈◊〉 is juſt Sixteen and no more: but this ſame Thais is ſomewhat older than my ſelf— She has ſent again to beg of me very earueſtly to come.— • ow let her tell her buſineſs plainl, or trouble me o more. I ll be hangd if ſhe catch me here a third • ime. So ho! within there! ſoho! knocks at the Door.

sp.speaker: P • th.
sp.p: within Who is there?

sp.speaker: C • r.
sp.p: Tis I, my Names Chreme •
〈…〉 prett • little Squire is it you?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
So— I ſaid as much, this wheadling bode •
〈◊〉 good Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pyt.
sp.p: M Lady humbly deſires you to come again to morr •• .

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'm to go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: For love's ſake Sir, do.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I tell you plainly I can't.

sp.speaker: Pyt.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, ſtay but a little till my Lady comes bac • .

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Faith I don't intend it.

sp.speaker: Pyt.
sp.p: Why not, dear Mr Chremcs. Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pox take ye for a diſſembling Baggage.

sp.speaker: P • th.
sp.p: Well if you be reſolved, I beſeech ye Sir, to give your ſelf the trouble of ſtepping over to her where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I dont care if I do that.

sp.speaker: P • th.
sp.p:
to them within. Doria! Enter Doria. Go quickly and ſhew this Gentleman over to the Captain's. Exeunt ſeverally.
Enter Antipho alone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yeſterday a Knot of good Fellows of us were got together at Pireo, where we clubb d to have a Feaſt to d • y. We choſe Cherea for our Steward. The Forfeits were all laid down, and time and place agreed upon. The time's paſt, and at the place they know nothing on't; our Gentleman Steward has given us the •• ip, and Faith I can't tell what to ſay, or think o' th' Buſineſs.— The reſt of the Company have employed me to hunt about for him; I think I d as good call in at his Father's— diſcovering Cherea. But who is yonder a coming out of Thais's Houſe? is it he, or is it not he?— As I live 'tis he— He day! what a Toy of a man have we got here?— What means thi • diſguiſe?— what unaccountable freak is this? I am puzzled, and cant imagin for my Heart what's the matter? whatſoever it be I will know before I ſtir a foot. Retires a little on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
to himſelf ſoftly. But is no body here now? Not a Mortal.— Does no body dog me?— Not ſo much as my Shadow.— Shall I now give vent to my ſwelling Joys?— Oh Heavens! what wou'd I give for ſome good Body to cut my Throat immediately, that in the height of this Joy I may end my Life without the leaſt daſh of misfortune.— But
is there never a curious inquiſitive Fellow following me cloſe upon the Heel, to deafen and murder me with Queſtion upon Queſtion at every turn? As, Why ſo tranſported? Why ſo wonderful merry? Whither away ſo faſt? Whence came ye? Where got ye this Garb? What Frolick's this? Are ye in your Wits? or are ye ſtark mad?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: advancing nigher. Faith, I'll e'en up to him, and do him that favour my ſelf.— Cherea, what is't you chuckle at ſo? what means this fool's Coat? why ſo merry about the Mouth? Hey brave! what d'ye mean? D'ye pretend to be in your wits? what d'ye ſtare for?— Here they ſtare upon one another what never a word?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Huzzah! This is a day of Jubilee! well met old Soul! Gad take me, there's not a Man alive I'd have wiſh'd for ſo ſoon as thy dear ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee tell me this mighty buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And prithee dear Rogue prepare thy ſelf to receive it then.— I ſuppoſe you know my Brother's Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, you mean Thais I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: The very ſame

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I thought I knew her.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: This day a pretty young Female was preſented to her. But why ſhould I ſtand prating, and commending her charming Face to thee my Friend, when thou knoweſt ſo well what a Critick I am in Beauties?— In ſhort ſhe fired my Blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
Ay Boy, had you but ſeen her, I'm ſure you'd ſay ſhe was the Miracle of her Sex. But to leave impertinencies, I was preſently in up to the Ears; And as good luck would have it, we had an Eunuch at home, which my Brother bought
for his Miſtreſs, but wasn't yet delivered to her. Our Man Parmeno gave me an Item of a Deſign, which I immediately put in Execution.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And what was that?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Be patient and you'll hear't the ſooner. It was to change Cloaths with the Eunuch, and for me to be preſented inſtead of him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What for the Eunuch?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Ev'n ſo old Boy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee what advantage could you propoſe to your ſelf by that?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: That's worth the asking indeed, why to ſee her, diſcourſe with her, and be alone with the pretty Creature I loved (ye Rogue.) And d'ye make nothing of this now?— In ſhort preſented I was to Thais, who as ſoon as ſhe received me, very joyfully brought me home; and committed the Beautiful Creature to my charge.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To whoſe Charge? to thine?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Yes, to mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Marry, ſhe was in ſafe Hands!

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: She ordered that not a Man ſhould com • nigh her but my ſelf, and charg'd me not to ſtir a ſtep from her; and that She and I ſhould be alone together in the Parlour. I look'd as if Butter would not melt in my Mouth, and cry'd, Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Lord help thee.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
She told me ſhe was going out to Supper; And with that drew all her Train after her, except a few raw new comers to attend the fair Stranger. Thoſe prepared a Bath for my Angel: I urg'd 'em to haſten't as much as they cou'd. Whilſt they were about it, this ſweet Creature was ſitting in a Withdrawing Room, caſting her Eyes upon a fair Piece, which was the picture of Jupiter, who (as the ſtory goes) came down into Danae's Lap
in a Shower of Gold. I made bold to dart a Look that way too, and finding how like the Intrigue was to mine, I cou'dn't but be • ten times the more tickled at the Conceit on't. That a very God ſhould transform himſelf into a Mortal, and privately ſteal through the Tyles of another Man's Houſe, and ſo drop like a Shower into his Miſtreſſes Arms. But what God, thought I, was this? Why no leſs a God than the Thunderer himſelf, who ſhakes the Battlements of Heaven. And ſhould Fleſh and Blood refuſe to follow his Example? I'll do't, and with all my Soul too. While theſe thoughts were working in my Head, they call'd her away to the Bath, ſhe goes, ſhe waſhes, ſhe comes back: And then they put her to Bed, I ſtood waiting for the word of Command. At laſt comes one to me, Prithee do you Dorus take this Fan, and cool the young Gentlewoman thus, the time we are Bathing. When we have done, you may bath if you've a mind to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'd a given the whole almoſt t'have ſeen that impudent Face of thine at that time; how you carried your ſelf; and how like a great Booby you managed the Fan.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: The words were ſcarce out of her Mouth, but the • all ruſh'd out of the Room to the Bath, and ſet up a Gaggle, as Servants do when their Maſter's Back's turn'd. Mean time my dear Lady falls into a ſweet ſleep; with that I cunningly caſts a Sheep's E • e askiew through the Fan, ſhewing him how he look'd and took a ſidelong Glance round the Room to ſee that the Coaſt was clear.— I finding all right, made faſt the Door.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What then brave Boy?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: How? what then? Simpleton!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A Simpleton indeed!

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
Should I have neglected ſuch a ſhort,
wiſhed for, and unexpected Opportunity, when it dropt into my very Mouth. I muſt ha' been a very Eunuch indeed then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith Boy, thou'rt in the right.— But in the mean time what's become of our Treat?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Tis juſt ready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Troth, thou 'rt a brave Fellow. But where is't? At your Houſe.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: No; at old Harry Platters.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's plaguy way off.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: We muſt go the faſter then, that's all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But won't you change your Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: How can I? Pox on't! I'm quite baniſh'd home, for fear my Brother ſhould ſee me, and what's worſe, leſt my old Father ſhould become out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why then e'en let's go to our Houſe; that's the nigheſt place I can think of, to ſhift your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: That's right; let's away then and lay our Heads together, how my Dear may be for ever mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A Match then.

div.trailer: The end of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Doria
sp.stage: alone, with a Casket under her Arm.
sp.p:
AS I'm a living Soul, as much as I can gather from the Captain's humour, I'm terribly af • aid this Swaggerer ſhould make ſome diſturbance to day, and fall foul upon my Lad • . For as ſoon as young Chremes, the Gentlewoman's Brother came thither, ſhe askt leave of the Captain to have him admitted. He began to huff and be angry, but yet durſt not deny her. Beſides, my Lady
urg'd him to deſire the Gentleman to ſit down and welcom, becauſe ſhe'd have him ſtay there, for this wasn't a proper time to tell him all ſhe had a mind to about his Siſter. At laſt with a dogged Look, he coldly bids him welcom. The Gentleman ſtaid, and my Lady began to diſcourſe. This Captain Huff-cap imagining he had been a Rival brought under his Noſe to affront him, thought he would do ſomething that ſhould plague her too. Hark ye, ſays he, go for Pamphila, to give us a Song. By no means in the World, crys my Lady; What ſhould ſuch a Wench do at a Feaſt? The Captain being ſet upon't fell to wrangling. Mean time the cunning Creature whips her Gold and Jewels into this Casket, and ſlipt it into my Hand to carry off; which is a certain ſign ſhe won't be long behind, as ſoon as ſhe can get away.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: As I was walking to our Country Houſe upon the Road, (as 'tis uſual with people when they are uneaſie) a thouſand thoughts came running into my Head one after another, which I took all in the worſt Senſe: To be ſhort, whilſt I was muſing upon theſe things, I paſs'd by my Houſe unawares, and had got half a Mile before I perceiv'd it; upon that I turn'd back with a Heart as heavy as Lead.— When I was juſt got by the way to the Houſe, I ſtood ſtill, and began to think thus with my ſelf: What? muſt I be forc'd to ſtay here eight and forty long hours without her?— What of all that?— A meer trifle!— How a trifle?— What if I can't kiſs her Hand, yet 'tis very hard if I can't have one look at her? If I can't have the one, ſure I may have the other: Tis better to be almoſt diſtanc'd, than to be quite thrown out of the Race. With that I went by on purpoſe.— But hold, what makes Pythia run out of Doors in ſuch a fright?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. Where's this curſed, wicked Creature— Wretch that I am! where ſhall I find him? Or where ſhall I look for him?— That ever any man ſhould have the impudence to offer at ſuch a Villany!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Alas! my Heart miſgives me ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. Nay more than that; after the Villain had abus'd the Girl, he tears her Cloaths, and drags her up and down by the Hair o'th Head.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: How's this? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. O that I had but the Rogue in my Clutches now!— How I would claw the Eyes of the Whores-bird!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I can't imagin what great diſorder here has been in my abſence— I'll e'en ſtep to her Aſide.
To Pyth. What's the matter? whither in ſuch haſte? whom d'ye look for, Pythia?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Hah, Mr Phedrie! Whom look for ſay ye? a Curſe upon you and your precious Preſents both together.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Prithee tell me what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: The Matter, quoth I?— Your Eunuch that you gave us, what wicked Work has he made here? He has gone and raviſh'd the young Gentlewoman the Captain gave my Lady.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: in a maze. What ſay'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I'm quite undone.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ay and drunk too, I think.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Would the worſt of mine Enemies were as drunk as I am.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Law, Pythia, wasn't it a very prodigious thing, ha!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Thou'rt certainly mad.— How is it poſſible for an Eunuch to do this?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I can't tell what he was; but what he has done, 'tis plain. The poor young Creature is all in Tears, neither can ye get one Word from her. This precious Rogue hides his Head now. I'm wofully afraid he has finger'd ſomewhat out o'th' Houſe too, when he ran away.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: 'Tis a wonder to me ſuch a Limber-hamm'd Dog ſhou'd get out of ſight ſo ſoon, unleſs he has ho • s'd himſelf at my Father's.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Dear Sir, ſtep in and ſee.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You ſhall know that preſently.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O Gemini! Prithee my Dear, did you ever hear of ſuch a horrid Prank before? I never did.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Truly I have heard ſay, theſe Eunuchs are great Admirers of fine Women, but can do nothing but ſlabber them over. But I, like a ſilly Jade as I was, never thought of this: If I had, I ſhould have lockt up my Gentleman, and have kept the Girl far enough from his reach.
sp.stage: Re-enter Phedrie dragging in Dorus by the Ears.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Come out ye infamous Dog!— What d'ye hang an Arſe ye Runagate Scoundrel!— Thou damnable Bargain out of your Kennel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Do but ſee what a damn'd Friday-face the J • il-bird makes? How came you hither again?— Why this change of Habit I pray?— What anſwer Dog?— Had I ſtaid but a minute longer, Pythia, I had miſs doth Rogue, you ſee hes juſt equipt for the March.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: O dear Sir, have ye met with the Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Met with him? Ay.

sp.speaker: Pyth
sp.p: That's good Luck indeed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay ſpecial good Luck upo' my word:

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What ha ye done with him?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Done with him? Can't ye ſee before ye?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Whom ſhou'd I ſee?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: This Fellow here. Pointing to Dorus.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What of this Fellow here?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: The ſame that was ſent to your Houſe to day.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I dare ſwear Sir, none of our Houſe e're ſet eye upon him.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sure they were blind then.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray Sir, can ye believe this to be the Man that was brought to our • ouſe?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Believe't? The De'el 〈◊〉 elſe had I to ſend.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Fie!— there's no Compariſon to be made between this and that; for that other had a fine Air, and look'd like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ay, ſo you thought, becauſe he had got his gay Cloaths on: now he has alter'd his Habit, you take him for an ugly Creature.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray Sir, don't perſwade me to't, as if there were no more difference than that comes to. Why he that we had to day was ſuch a fine young Fellow, 'twould ha' done your Heart good to have ſeen him. This is a dry, decrepit, drowzy-headed Fumbler, and looks like a Weezle.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What ſtuff's this?— You've brought me to that paſs, that for my part I know not what I've done my ſelf.— Come hither Sirrah, to Dorus Didn't I buy ye, and pay for ye?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Now pray Sir, let me have one pull at him.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Do ſo.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Were you at our Houſe to day? He nods L • ok ye, he denies it,— He that Parmen) brought was but ſixteen.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well I'll at him once again my ſelf. Firſt, tell me how you came by theſe Cloaths? What ha' you loſt you Tongue?— Ye ugly Dog, why don't ye anſwer me? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: One Mr Cherea came.—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Not my Brother I hope?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes Sir?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: To day.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: How long ago?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But a little while.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Who did he come with?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Parmeno, an't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Did you know him before?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No Sir, nor ever heard of his name.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: How came ye then to know 'twas my Brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Parmeno told me ſo.— And 'twas Cherea gave me theſe Cloaths—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: — And put on mine, and away they went together.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to Phedrie. So Sir, Who's drunk now? 'Twas I fill'd your Head with Stories, wasn't it? Now 'tis as clear as the Sun, that the poor Gentlewoman's raviſh'd. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Away ye Beaſt,— D'ye believe one word this Fellow prates?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: A Fig for believing! The thing's plain enough of it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: ſoftly to Dorus. Come a little this way, Dye mind me Sirrah?— Nigher yet.— That's well.— Let me hear this Buſineſs once again, Did Cherea take your Cloaths from ye?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: He did Sir,

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And put 'em on himſelf?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And was ſent hither in your ſtead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, that he was.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! This is the moſt wicked impudent Dog living. Aloud in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Alas Sir! Are ye not convinc'd that we have been moſt baſely abuſed?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p:
No wonder if a crack'd Chamber-maid believes this Scoundrel: Angrily to Pyth.— But the truth on't is, I am ſomewhat gravell'd my ſelf ſoftly— Hark ye Sirrah, deny all, or I'll cut your Throat aſide to Dorus— Can't I rack the Truth out of ye to day? Did ye ſee my Brother Cherea?
Aloud to Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir. Fearfully.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I ſee there's nothing to be done without blows.— This way ye Dog— He hunts Counter.— Down o' your Knees, and ask me pardon.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: kneeling. Good Sir, I beſeech ye, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Into your Kennel then. Beats him.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hey, hey. Runs out howling.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Faith I cou'dn't tell how to make a fair come off without this Stratagem. If ſo, the thing's paſt cure. Aſide.— D'ye think ye Raſcal to make a May-game of me. Aloud to Dorus.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: My Life on't, this damn'd plot is of Parmeno's contriving.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You may ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I'faith I'll pay him in his own Coyn before I ſleep.— But prithee Doria, what wou'dſt adviſe me i'th Caſe?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You mean in the young Gentlewoman's Buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Yes, whether we had beſt keep it to our ſelves, or tell on't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
In tr • th, if you're wiſe, take no notice of the Eunuch, or the Girl either: for by that means
you'll keep out of harms way, and oblige our Lady beſides. You need only ſay the Eunuch has given us the ſlip:

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I'll follow your Counſel.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But yonder comes Mr. Chremes;— My Lady isn't far behind then

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: What makes ye think ſo?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Becauſe the Captain and ſhe were almoſt at Daggers drawing when I left em.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Then away with the Casket quick:— I'll learn of this Gentleman what's to do.
sp.stage: To her, enter Chremes half drunk.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Hey-dazy!— I ha' been finely bubbled I'faith.— This Wine has been too hard for me.— The time I was toping,— I thought my ſelf as ſober as a Judge,— But when I came to try my Legs,— S bud my Feet nor my head knew which was to go uppermoſt.—

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Chremes!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Who's that?— Oh, the pretty, pretty, Phythie! Why thou art worth forty of the Phythies I ſaw laſt.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: And upo' my Word you're forty times more pleaſant than you were before.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: The old Saying's very true, If twasn't for Meat and good Drink the Women might gnaw the Sheets.— But your Miſtreſs has been come home a long time I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Why is ſhe come from the Captain's then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Oh a damnable while— They were quarrelling like Dog and Cat.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Didn't ſhe deſire ye to follow her?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No, ſhe only tipp'd a Wink at me as ſhe went away.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: And wasn't that Item enough?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
No Faith: I cou'dn't tell what her winking
and twinking meant till the Captain very civilly gave me to underſtand it by thruſting me Head and Shoulders after her.— But ſee ſhe's upo' th' Back on's already.— I wonder what Devil brought me hither before her. Enter Thais.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: to herſelf. I believe this hectoring Bully will be upon my Back preſently to take away the Girl by force: Ay let him come: if he offers to touch her but with one finger I'll pluck his Eyes out;— I can away with his Impertinencies and big Words, as long as they are but Words; but i'faith if he comes to touch our • opyhold once, I'll make him ſmart for't. Angrity.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah Madam, I've been here a long while.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: My dear Chremes! 'twas you I wanted; Arn't you ſenſible this Quarrel was upo' your account? And the whole buſineſs a concern of yours?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Of mine? Pray how ſo? As if I had been—

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Whilſt I'm taking pains to help you to your Siſter, and reſtore her to ye, I'm forc'd to ſit down with theſe and a thouſand ſuch like Affronts.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray Madam, where is ſhe now?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: At home at my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Hah! Concern'dly.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What's the Matter? you needn't fear; for her education hasn't been beneath her ſelf, or you either.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Nothing but the truth. I freely give her to ye, and ſhant expect a Farthing for my pains,

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I thank ye Madam, and ſhall endeavour to make ye amends when time ſerves.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: But have a care Sir, you don't loſe her before you have her, for tis ſhe the Captain is coming to plunder us of by force of Arms.— D'ye hear, Pythia, run n and fetch the Casket and To • ens quick.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: diſcovering Thraſo and his party. D'ye ſee 'em Madam?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Where is't ſet, Madam?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: In the Cheſt of Drawers.— D'ye move no faſter ye Baggage? Exit Pythia.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What an Army has this Fellow muſter'd up againſt ye?— Lamentable!

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What Cow-hearted my Dear?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pſhaw, I Cow-hearted? I'm as bold as a Lion. Struts.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Ay, and ſo you had need.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah Madam, I doubt ye take me for • a— ſtrange Fellow.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: However take this for your comfort, this Fellow you're to deal with is a perfect Stranger, has leſs Intereſt, leſs Acquaintance, and fewer Freinds to back him than you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That I know too: But 'tisn't for a wiſe Man to ſtand behind an Aſs when he kicks. I'd rather prevent a Quarrel before hand, than revenge it afterward.— Do you run in and Barricade the Door, whilſt I run to the Piazza, and fetch the Conſtable to keep the Peace. Going off.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: catching him by the Cloak. Hold Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I had better go.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Stand your ground pray. ſtill holding him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray let me go, I'll be back again in an inſtant.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Sir, you need not call any help— do but tell him ſhe is your Siſter, and that you loſt her when ſhe was young, and are now come to the knowledge of her, then ſhew him the Tokens.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Here they are Madam.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Do you take 'em Sir.— Chr. takes the Casket. If he offers the leaſt violence you may have him before his Betters:— You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes very well

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p:
Be ſure you ſpeak this with a good Cou
• age.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Edad, and ſo I will. ſtruts and puts his Arms a Kimbow.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Up with your Cloak Man— Dear Heart I've pitch'd upon a Champion that wants one himſelf. Aſide Exeunt on one ſide.

p.stage: Enter on the other ſide Thraſo, Gnatho, Sanga, Servants with Link-boys, Fire-forks, Shovels, Diſhclouts, &c.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Prethee Gnatho; Is't for a Man of Honour to put up ſuch a notorious Affront as this? I'll dye upo' th' ſpot firſt.— Simalio, Donax, Syriſcus, follow your Leader.— Firſt I'll ſtorm their Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Then I'll carry off the Damſel triumphantly.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Better and better.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And laſtly, I'll put the Jilt under ſevere Contributions.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Advance Donax with your Truncheon, and Command the main Body.— Simalio Command you the Left Wing, and you Syriſcus the Right.— Where are the reſt? Where's Captain Sanga with his Ragged Regiment?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Sanga. Ye lazy Son of a Whore! D'ye think to engage the Enemy with a Diſh-clout, what did you bring that for?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Who I, Sir? Why I knew the Proweſs of my General, and the Carriage of his Souldiers ſo well, that they could never part without Blood and Wounds, ſo I brought this to wipe 'em withal.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Where's all the reſt of 'em?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: The reſt, with a vengeance? There's only Sannio left to keep the Houſe from running away.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Gnatho do you ſet 'em all in Rank and File.— I'll bring up the Rear, and there give the Signal for the Onſet.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
This 'tis to be Wiſe: When he has drawn
• p his Men in Battalia, he'll make ſure of one • Poſt for his own retreat. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: This was always the F— K— 's way.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: D'ye obſerve, Madam, what this Cutthroat's about? I ſee my Counſel wasn't amiſs when I advis'd ye to Barricade the Door.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Pſhaw! This Fellow that you take for a Hector, is as Faint-hearted as a Town Bully.— Bear up Man.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Gnatho. What had we beſt do?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Had we but a Mortar now to play upon 'em under the Covert way; one Bomb wou'd make 'em ſcamper.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: diſcovering Thais. But hold, yonder's the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Shall we give the Aſſault, noble General?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Hold I ſay.— Wiſe Commanders uſually ſend a Summons before they Storm: Perhaps ſhe'll ſurrender upon Diſcretion before we make the Aſſault.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Oh wonderful! What plaguy things theſe Politicks are? I never am in your company, but I go away the wiſer for't.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Thais. Thais anſwer me the firſt Article, when I gave ye Pamphila, didn't ye promiſe me ſo many days to my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What of all that?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: That's a pretty Queſtion!— Didn't ye bring one of your Gallants under my Noſe? What buſineſs had ye together? Why did you ſlink away with him from my Houſe?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Cauſe 'twas my Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why then deliver up Pamphila, unleſs you'd have her carried off by force.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Deliver her to thee? Touch her if you • a • e: Thou worſt of— Angrily.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Chremes. Hah! Sir have a care, not a word more.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Do you prate, Buffoon.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Shan't I touch what's my own?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Thine, Villain?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Chremes I ſay once again, have a care Friend; I ſee you don't know who you ſpeak to?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
to Gnatho. Won't ye be gone, ye Raſcal 〈◊〉
to Thraſo And you, Captain Swaſh, d'ye know what to truſt to? If ye give us the leaſt diſturbance here, I'll make ye remember the Place, the Dav, and Perſon you affront too, as long as you breathe.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Chremes. Poor Wretch! I pity ye, that ye ſhou'd provoke ſo great a Man to be your Enemy.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll crack your Fools Pate for ye, if ye ben't gone preſently.

sp.speaker: G • na.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Mr. Snarle? Are your Hands ſo heavy?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p:
to Chremes. Pray who are you for a Man? What wou'd you have? And what have yo •
• o do with the Girl?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That ye ſhall know preſently: Firſt, I ſay ſ • e's Free-born.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: So!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And a Citizen of Athens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And my Siſter too.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Oh Impudence.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Therefore Captain, Jeeringly. I tell ye once for all, lay hands on her if you dare.— to Thais Now, Madam, I'll ſtep and fetch Sopl • ona, the Nurſe, and ſhew her the Tokens.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why will you, Sir, hinder me from meddling with what's my own?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, that I will. Withdraws.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Thraſo. Bear witneſs, this Chremes own 〈◊〉 himſelf a Thief, he has done his own buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to. Thais Do you ſay the ſame too?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Go look. Withdraws.
sp.stage: Here Thraſo and Gnatho ſtare at one another.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What ſhall we do next?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: E'n let's march home again— By and by ſhe'll come fawning like a Spaniel to beg your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Think ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Nothing more certain, I know the humour of theſe women well enough; when you will, they won't, and when you won't, they will.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Thou haſt hit it.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Shall I diſmiſs the Army?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: When you will.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Sanga. Well Captain, you and yours are diſcharg'd, now like a noble General take your Army into Quarters of Refreſhment i'th' Kitchin.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Troth my belly chym'd Cupboard above half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Well ſaid Tom Prog.—

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Follow your Leader. Exeunt ſhouting

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: entring. D'Ye ſpeak in Riddles ſtill ye dirty Quean? In another Tone mocking her. I do know, I don't know, he's fled, I heard on't, but was not there. Huſſy, can't ye tell me in plain terms whatever the Matter is. The poor Girl's Gown's rent, ſhe's all in Tears, and won't ſpeak. The Eunuch's fled too; But why?— What's done?— What no anſwer?—

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, What wou'd ye ha' me ſay? when they all affirm 'twasn't a Eunuch that was here.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Who was't then •

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: One Mr. Cherea.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What Mr. Cherea?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: The young Gentleman, Phedrie's Brother.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: VVhat's that ye ſay ye VVitch?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Nothing but what is certainly true.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Pray what ſhould he do here? Upon what account came he hither, pray?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I can't gueſs, unleſs he was in Love with Pamphila.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: 'S death, I'm undone then, all my Meaſures are broken if this be true. Is • t for this the poor Creature bemoans her ſelf ſo?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: So I believe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: How's this ye Baggage? Didn't I give you a particular Charge about her, when I went away.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: VVhat could I do i'th' Caſe? You order'd that ſhe ſhould be wholly committed to his care?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Oh you Jade, you ſet the VVolf to • eep the Sheep: I'm aſham'd to the Soul to be ſo curſedly fool • d.— Seeing Cherea afar off. But what fellow • s that?
sp.stage: Enter Cherea at a diſtance ſtill in the Eunuch's Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: • S't, Madam! Patience I beſeech ye: All's well, we have got our Spark in Lob's pound.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: 'S't! on the Left-hand; Don't you ſee him?— look there then.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I ſee him.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Seize him immediately.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What can we do to him, Fool!

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Do to him, ſay ye?— See, I beſeech you, what a curſed impudent Look he has got,—

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I ſee no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: And with what Confidence he comes to us.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: to himſelf. Antipho's Father and Mother were both at home, as if they'd ſtaid there on purpoſe, that I cou'dn't poſſibly g • t in without being diſcover'd. The time I was i • th' Porch, an Acquaintance o'mine came that way. Upon this, I takes me to my heels as faſt as I cou'd, runs into a blind Alley, then to another, and ſo to a third. Thus did I dance up and down in a Peck of Troubles to prevent a diſcovery.— But hold, is that Thais? The very ſame.— I'm at a plaguy ſtand what to do.— Pſhaw, what care I? She can neither hang, draw, nor quarter.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Let's up to him.— O good Sir Dorus, you're welcome home.— Pray tell me, Did you run away from us?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: True as you ſay, Madam. Looks ſimply.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: And are extreamly pleaſed with this vagary I warrant?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Not ſo extreamly neither Madam.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: D'ye think you ſhall come off ſo?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Well Madam, pardon me this one Fault, if you catch me in another hang me up.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Were you afraid that I ſhou'd prove a harſh Miſtreſs, that you ran for't?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: No indeed Madam.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Of what then?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Why I was only afraid this woman ſhou'd ha told Tales of me. Pointing to Pythia.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why what have you done then?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: A ſmall matter.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Impudence! A ſmall matter d'ye call it?— Is raviſhing a Virgin and a Citizen ſo ſmall a Matter in your account? In a Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I took her for one of my fellow Servants.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Thy fellow Servant? I can ſcarce keep my Nails out o'th' Eyes of him.— Thou Devil incarnate! Are you come to laugh at us too? In a great Fury.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: to Pythia. Keep off you Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Why Madam? As if there could ha' been any thing done to me, if I had pull'd his Locks for him, ſince he owns himſelf your Servant?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Triffling aſide,— Indeed, Mr. Cherea, you ve done a very unworthy thing, and which did not become ye, for tho I had deſerv'd this Affront never ſo much, yet 'twas diſhonourable for you to do't. As I live, I know not what courſe to take about the poor Girl. You've ſo broken all my Meaſures, that I can't poſſibly return her to her Friends, neither as I ought to do, nor as I intended: that I might ingratiate my ſelf among 'em by ſo compleat an Obligation.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Now, Madam, I hope to ſee a laſting kindneſs betwixt us both. For from ſuch bad Beginnings as this oft the greateſt Friendſhips riſe. And who knows but ſome lucky Star has order'd this?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why truly I interpret it thus, and wiſh it from my Soul.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And I beg it might be ſo. Believe this one thing, 'twasn't to affront you, but pure love caus'd all this.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p:
I do believe it, and therefore rather pa •
don it: For I'm not of that Nature, Mr. Cherea, nor yet ſo inſenſible my ſelf as not to know ſome what of the Power of Love.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: As I hope for Happineſs, Madam, I'm extreamly taken with you.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, look to your ſelf then.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I wou'dn't hurt her if I might.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I'll truſt ye no farther than I can ſee ye.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Leave prating, Fool.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
Now, Madam, I muſt crave your Aſſiſtance in this great Deſign. I truſt and commit my ſelf wholly to your diſpoſal, and beg your Protection.
Let me die, if I don't marry her.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: But what if your Father?—

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: What he?— I'm ſure of his Conſent, could ſhe be prov'd to be a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to ſtay a little her Brother will be here ſtrait: He's but ſtept for the Nurſe that brought her up. And ſo Sir you may be by at the Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Then I'll ſtay.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: I think we'd better go in i'th' mean time than ſtay at the Door.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: D'ye know Madam whatyou're going to do?

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why that Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Why? Sure you don't intend to take this Blade into your Houſe again.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Truſt me for once Madam, he'll make ſome new Diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Prithee leave your tattling.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: It ſeems you han't made ſufficient tryal of him then.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I'll do no harm good Mrs Pythia.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I'll not truſt ye an Ace good Mr. Cherea.— • anleſs your Head were off.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: But Mrs. Pythia thou ſhalt be my Keeper.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: No Faith, who will truſt their ſelves with you, either to keep or be kept by ye? Away with ye.—

p.stage: Enter at a diſtance Chremes and Sophrona.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: What luck's here, here's the Brother juſt upon us.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Alas-a-day! I beſeech ye Madam, let's in. I wou'dn't for the world be ſeen i'th' Street in this Dreſs.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Why ſo? 'Cauſe you're aſham'd on't?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Yes indeed am I.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Yes indeed am I, ſay ye? For the young Woman Cherea! clapping her Hands at him.

sp.speaker: Tha.
sp.p: Do you go in, Sir, I'll follow ye.—

Exit Cherea But do you ſtay here Pythia to bring in Mr. Chremes.
Exit. Thais.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. What Trick now? what miſchief can I think of?— How ſhall I contrive to make this Rogue Parmeno pay Sawce for this damnable Cheat, he has put upon us?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Come, beſtir your ſelf Nurſe a little faſter.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: So I do you ſee.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, but you don't advance.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to Chremes. Have you ſhown Nurſe the Tokens?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes all of 'em.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what ſays ſhe? Does ſhe know 'em again?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, and remember 'em very well.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: That's good News introth, I wiſh the poor Gentlewoman well with all my Heart.— Be pleas'd to walk in, my Lady has look'd for ye ſome time.— Exeunt Chremes and Sophrona.

Yonder comes that precious Rogue Parmeno,— In the Name of Heaven, how unconcern'dly the Fellow ſtalks it?— But I believe I have found out a way to revenge my ſelf on him as I wou'd wiſh.— I'll go in and ſee the Truth of this Diſcovery, then I'll come again and fright the Raſcal to ſome Tune. Exit Pythia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
alone. I'm come to ſee how Cherea carries on his Intrigue; which if it be manag'd cunningly, goodly, goodly! what Monuments of Praiſe are due to my Worſhip? For to ſay nothing of procuring him the Perſon he loves without Trouble, Fees, or Charges, when the Amour might have proved very difficult and coſtly from a covetous Bawd: I've done that which I think I deſerve a Statue for; Having ſhown this Spark a way to know all the tricks and cuſtoms of theſe
common Jilts, and by timely notice to abhor 'em for ever after. When they're abroad forſooth, none ſo cleanly, none ſo modiſh and genteel, none ſo delicately neat as they: when their Ladyſhips feaſt with their Gallants, they feed as nicely as poſſible: But to ſee the inſatiable Gluttony, the vile Naſtineſs, the griping Penury of theſe filthy Jades at home, how greedy of a Cruſt, how eagerly they ſlabber and ſoſs up Brown-George out of ſtinking Pottage; to know all this before hand may be the ſaving of a young man.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: at the Door over-hearing him. Faith I'll be even with you for your Rogueries you've ſaid or done; you ſhall have ſmall Joy Sirrah, in making Sport with us.

p.stage: Enter Pythia, taking no notice of Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: entring. Bleſs me! what a baſe unworthy Action's this: An unfortunate young Gentleman! And Parmeno, an ungracious Wretch to betray him hither!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's in the wind now? Aſide:

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf It grieves me to the Soul Dear Heart, I left the Houſe in haſte to get out of the ſight on't— VVhat a dreadful Example do they ſay they'll make on him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Heavens! what new miſchief's this? Is my Plot come to this then?— I'll e'en ſpeak to her. Aſide.— VVhat's the matter M • s. Pythia? what's that you talk'd of? who's that will be made an Example?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: D'ye ask that, ye deſperate Fool? why you've quite ruin'd the young Gentleman you had brought for the Eunuch, when you thought, I warrant, you had put a trick upon us.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How ſo?— what has happen'd?— Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p:
I will ſo.— You don't know then that
the Girl that was preſented to my Lady to day, is a Gentlewoman o • this Town, and her Brother a Perſon of Quality?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I know nothing on't.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: But ſo it prov • d.— And 'twas ſhe that your poor wretch raviſh'd. VVhen her Brother knew of it, a moſt bloody-minded Fellow,—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: VVhat did he do? Fearfully.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: — Firſt bound him Hand and Foot, 'twou'd grieve your heart to ſee it.—

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Bound him? Damnation!

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: — Tho my Lady begg'd all ſhe cou'd for him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What ſay ye? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Now he threatens to ſerve him like a common Horner, a thing I ne're ſaw, nor wou'dn't for the world.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: With what Face can he anſwer ſo great a Villany? Pyth. Why ſo great, I beſeech you?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why isn't it the greateſt of all Villanies?— Pray, who e're heard of one apprehended for a Fornicator in a common Bawdy-houſe?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I can't tell that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That you mayn't ſay you don't know on't, this I declare, and forewarn you, that 'tis no leſs than Mr. Phedrie's Brother,—

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: How? Prithee, 'tisn't he? Is't?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: — Therefore your Lady had beſt take care he comes to no harm— But why don't I break into the Houſe my ſelf? Offers to go.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Have a care what you do Parmeno, you'll do him no good, and ruine your ſelf into the Bargain; for every body believes 'tis all your contrivance.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
coming back. What courſe ſhall I ſet upon? Seeing Laches at a diſtance Oh, yonder comes my old Maſter from his Country-houſe— Shall I tell him on't or no?— Studies.— Introth I
will, tho I certainly know I ſhall make a Rod ſo my own Breech. Neceſſity has no Law, he muſt reſcue his poor Son.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: You do well.— I'll go in.— Be ſure you tell him the whole Story from the beginning to the end.

sp.speaker: Laches
sp.p: to himſelf. I always find this advantage from the nearneſs o' my Country-houſe, that I'm never much tired with the Town or Country: When I begin to be ſick of the one, I ſhift Lodgings to the other.— But isn't that our Man Parmeno?— 'Tis he, as I hope to live.— Parmeno! Who is't you wait for at this Houſe?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: turning ſhort. Who's that there?— Ah, Sir, you're welcome to Town.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Who d'ye wait for? Hah!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'm Thunder-ſtruck, I can't wag my Tongue for fear. Aſide,

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Ha! What's the matter? Why d'ye ſhake ſo? Is all well at home? Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Firſt I'd have you be fully ſatisfied of this one thing, Sir, that whate're has happen'd, I'm as innocent as a new-born Babe.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That's well askt, for I ſhou'd ha' • told you that before.— Mr. Phedrie bought an Eunuch, which he preſented to this woman.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: To what woman?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Thais.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: He buy Eunuchs?— S'bud, I'm undone then.— what did he coſt?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: I muſt run my Country then.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Then his Brother Cherea fell in Love with a Muſick-Wench.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: How! what? Is he in Love too? Do's he know what belongs to that Sport already? Is he come from his Poſt to the City?— One Plague upon another! Angrily, looking on Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Pray Sir, don't you direct your Diſcourſe to me, I wasn't his Counſellor.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Speak another word about your ſelf, you Hangman? and as I live.— But tell me the whole buſineſs quickly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Mr. Cherea was ſent there inſtead of the Eunuch, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Inſtead of the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Very true Sir, and now they've appehended him for a Rape, and have bound him Hand and Foot.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Hell and Furies!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But mark the Impudence of theſe Jades.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Is there any Roguery you han't told me on yet?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You've heard all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lac.
sp.p: Why don't I break in upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Parmeno
sp.p: alone. I don't queſtion but I've brought an old Houſe upon my Head by this day's work; and yet I cou'dn't poſſibly avoid it.— Howe're I'm pleas'd that theſe Strumpets ſhall feel ſome of the ſmart by my Means. The old Gentleman has ſought an occaſion this half Year, to make notorious Examples of ſome of 'em, and now I think he has found one.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. I'faith this was the pleaſanteſt Scene I e're ſaw in my Life, to ſee the old Gentleman come blundering upon us in ſuch a miſtake. I had all the Sport to my ſelf, becauſe I knew his Ailment.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: over-hearing. VVhat a Plague's here? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. I'm now come to ſee for the Fool Parmeno.— But where in the name of goodneſs ſhall I find him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: O'my Soul ſhe looks for me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: to her ſelf. O! I ſee him, I'll be with him preſently.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's the matter Mrs. Impertinence? What wo • 'd you be at? what are you ſo tickl'd at?— what ne're a done?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Oh my Sides!— I've almoſt burſt my Sides with Laughing at thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Your Reaſon, pray?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: A pretty Qneſtion!— Faith, thou'rt the arranteſt Aſs I e're did, or ſhall ſet my Eyes on? 'Tis utterly paſt my skill to tell thee what excellent Sport thou haſt made within.— I took thee for a cunning ingenious Fellow.—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Had ye no more wit than to believe preſently what I ſaid? were you not aſham'd of the Villany you put the poor Gentleman upon, but you muſt tell Tales of him to his Father? How ſimply did he look, think ye, when his Father ſurpriz'd him in that diſguiſe? What? Don't you ſee what a fine paſs you have bronght your ſelf to?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ha! How's this you filthy Carrion? Did ye tell me a Lye, and then laugh at the Wit on't? D'ye think it ſuch fine Sport to abuſe us ye Jade.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Oh the fineſt ſport i'th' World.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: D'ye think you ſhan't pay dearly for this?

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay, Faith ſhall ye.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: I fancy as much. Theſe Threats may come to Morrow, but you'll be hang'd to day for entring a young Gentleman a Debauchee, and then diſcovering it, they'll both have a pull at your Coat for this.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'm a Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Pyth.
sp.p: You ſee the Reward of your Roguery; and ſo Good b'ye to ye. Exit Pythia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: alone. Like a ſenſeleſs Fool! I've betray'd my ſelf like Rats with their own Squeaking.
sp.stage: Enter Thraſo and Gnatho at another part of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Thraſo. What's in hand now, Sir? Upon what Aſſurance or Deſign came we hither? what Enterprize next, Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Who I? I'll e'en ſurrender my ſelf to her upon diſcretion, and e'en do as ſhe'd have me.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: How, Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd I be leſs ſubmiſſive to this Lady than Hercules was to Omphala?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: A pat Example,— wou'd I cou'd ſee the Slipper flung at your ſoft Head too. Aſide.— But what makes her Door open? Diſcovering Cherea. What miſchief's a foot now?— I think I never ſaw that Face before.— What makes him cut Capers thus as he comes out?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: to himſelf. Come my dear Country-men, was ever any Man born under a happier Planet than my ſelf? Not a Man upon my word. For 'tis plain the Powers above to ſhew in me how great their Soveraignty is have ſingled me out, on whom they have ſhowr'd down ſo many Bleſſings all at once.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why's he ſo merry trow?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: My dear Parmeno! 'Tis to thee I'm indebted for the Riſe, the Advancement, and the Perfection of my Comforts.— Doſt know my dear ſweet Creature's prov'd a Gentlewoman?—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I heard it by the bye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: — And that ſhe's to be my Bride?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As I hope to be Knighted that's Admirable.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Sir, what he ſays? Aſide to Thraſo.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p:
Then I am heartily glad my Brother's Amours are in ſuch a happy Condition. The Families
are both united now; Thais has put her ſelf wholly under my Father's Care and Protection, and is wholly ours.

sp.speaker: Par.
