sp.p: Then, Mr Phedrie is like to have her for good and all.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: This too is worth a laughing at, for the mighty Captain's routed.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Do you take care that my Brother may know of this as ſoon as ye can, whereſoe're he be.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'll ſee for him at home. Exit Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: So Gnatho, Doſt not think I'm gone to all Intents and Purpoſes?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: There's no thinking otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Cherea
sp.p: to himſelf. Where ſhall I begin firſt?

Or whom commend moſt? Him that advis'd me to do't, or my ſelf that had the Heart to venture upon't, or the good Fortune that directed us both, and that brought ſo many Circumſtances of ſo great moment, and ſo luckily too into the Compaſs of one Day.—
Or ſhall I praiſe the Indulgence of my Father?
Great Jove! that doſt poor Mortals Fate ſecure,ſecure,
Grant that our Joys may with our Lives endure.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to himſelf. Bleſs me! Parmeno tells me Wonders. But where's my Brother?

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: Here at your Service.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'm extreamly glad for your good Fortune, Brother.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I believe ſo, and truly Brother, there's ne're a Miſtriſs more worthy to be belov'd then your's, ſhe has ſo vaſtly oblig'd our Family.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Hey-day! Do you commend her before my Face.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Gnatho. I'm quite undone! The leſs I Hope the more I Love? Good Gnatho, I rely wholly upon thee

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: What wou'd you ha' me do Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Bring it about either for Love or Money. that I may continue a little in Madam Thais Favour.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: That will be hard.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You can do't I know, if you give your Mind to't: If ye perform it, Command what Gift or Reward you pleaſe, 'tis your own?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Shall it ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It ſhall indeed.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Why then Sir, if I do't, I deſire to have free Egreſs and Regreſs into your Houſe, whether you be at home or abroad, and a Place at your Table, whether invited or no.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: It ſhall be ſo upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Well, I'll make an Effort.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Whoſe Tongue's that?— O Captain is't you?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Perhaps you know not what has happen'd at this Houſe.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What makes ye ſcouting in theſe Quarters then?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Under your Protection, Gentlemen.—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: D'ye know the Protection you're to expect? Take this from me Good-man Captain, if I find you ſauntering here again in the Street, you muſtn't think to ſham me off with; I was looking for a Friend, and my Buſineſs lay this way, for you're like to have no Quarter.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Soft Sir, that's not like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'll be no worſe than my word.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I didn't think you'd been ſo huffy.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You'll find it juſt ſo.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
Pray be pleaſed, Gentlemen, to hear your
Servant Gnatho, a word or two, and then do what you pleaſe in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Lets hear't then.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Do you Captain move a little a Thraſo ſtands off. one ſide: In the firſt place, let me beſeech ye both to be perſwaded, that whate're I do i'th' caſe is purely for my own ſake, but if your Intereſt ſhou'd jump with mine, you 're unwiſe if you don't follow my Councel. •

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Out with't then.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: What if you took the Captain in amongſt ye too? Fawningly.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: How amongſt us?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p:
Conſider a little better Sir.— Why faith you and your Miſtreſs live very high, for you're uſed to an eaſie ſplendid Life, you've but a ſmall Allowance your ſelf; and this Thais will be requiring more: Now that you may ſupply her, and ſave your own Pocket, there's not a fitter or more convenient Ur • nſil than this Blunderbuſs i'th • whole World. F ••
〈◊〉 , he has Money enough at Command, and •• e more prodigal on't than he. Then he's a Soft-headed Fool, and a Half-witted Coxcomb, and a ſumbling Fellow that ſnores Night and Day. Ye • needn't fear the Gentlewoman's falling in Love with him; then you may kick him out of Doors when you pleaſe.—

sp.speaker: Phe
sp.p: to C • erea. What had we beſt do?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Then, Sir, what's beſt of all, he treats as high and nobly as a Lord.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Ten to one but we may have occaſion for this fool ſometime or other.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: I'm of that Mind too.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I'm oblig'd to you.— One Favour more let me beg of you, to admit me alſo into your retinue.— I've been cleaving of that Block long enough already.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: We grant it.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: And with all our Hearts.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Then in requital Gentlemen, here's to the fleecing and jeering the Cully to death.

sp.speaker: Che.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: He deſerves it.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: to Thraſo. Now noble Captain you may make your Approaches.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: And prithee how do Matters ſtand?

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: How? the Gentlemen didn't know your worth: when I had inform'd 'em of your good Qualities, and given 'em a Character of ye as your noble Actions and Vertues deſerve, your Suit was granted. Aſide to him.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: to Gnatho. Well haſt thou done.— To Phe. and Che. Gentlemen, great thanks do I return ye. I never was any where, but that all kind of People lov'd me moſt dearly.

sp.speaker: Gna.
sp.p: Didn't I tell ye how choice he was of his Expreſſions; polite upo' my word.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Now there's nothing wanting; You may retire.
Gentlemen adieu, one kind Applauſe.

div.trailer: The end of the Eunuch.

div.p: THE Self-Tormenter. A COMEDY, Acted at the Feaſt of Cybele, WHEN L. Valerius Flaccus, and L. Cornelius-Lentulus were Curule Edil's, By the Company of Ambivius Turpio.
It was taken from the GREEK of Menander;
Flaccus made free by Claudius, Compos'd the Muſick, which was perform▪d the firſt time of Acting on unequal FLUTES; The ſecond time on two Right-handed FLUTES.
This PLAY was Acted a Third time,
Under the Conſulſhip of Titus Sempronius, and M. Juventius.
A. U. C. 591. Ante Chriſt 159.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Chremes, An old Gentleman hard by Athens, of a Nature ſomewhat ſtrict and ſevere; very buſie, and a great Meddler.
Menedeme, A Gentleman, Chremes's Neighbour; The Self-Tormenter; of a Melancholy, yet of a ſofter and milder Diſpoſition than the former.
Clitipho, Chremes's Son, a hot, wild Spark; a looſe Lover, and ſomewhat ſtubborn to his Parents.
Clinie, His Friend, Menedeme's Son; of a civil, courteous, pliant Temper, paſſionately in Love with Antiphila.
Syrus, Servant to Clitipho, and his Inſtructor; a very ſlye, ſubtle, active, intriguing Fellow: always plotting againſt Chremes, and tricking him of Money.
Dromo, Servant to Clinie.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Soſtrata, Chremes's Wife, of a ſoft, eaſie and indulgent Nature, very ſubmiſſive to her Husband.
Antiphila, A young Gentlewoman; Clinie's Miſtreſs, very innocent, modeſt, loving, and faithful.
Bacchis, A noted Courteſan, kept by Clitipho, a haughty, proud, impudent, drinking, chargeable Miſs.
Phrygia, Her waiting Maid.
Antiphila's Nurſe.

div.p: SCENE, The Fields near ATHENS.
The TIME about Ten or Eleven Hours.

div.head: THE Self-Tormenter.
ACT I.
div.opener: SCENE, The Country before Chremes's Door. TIME, The Shut of the Evening.
div.stage: Enter Chremes, and Menedeme, with a Rake, &c upon his Shoulders, returning from the Field.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
THo our Acquaintance is but very ſhort, for it began, ye know, upon your buying this Farm here next mine; that and little elſe being the occaſion of it, yet, either your own worth or your Neighbourhood, which I eſteem next door to Friendſhip, makes me take the boldneſs with all freedom to tell ye, that you do not ſeem to live as becomes either your Age, or your Condition. For in the Name of Heaven and Wonder! what do ye do with your ſelf? what wou'd ye be at? If a body may Judge by your Face, you write Threeſcore at leaſt. I
don't know any that is better ſeated; has a prettier Eſtate; or is better ſerv'd than you: and yet you manage all the Buſineſs your ſelf, as if you hadn't a Soul i'th' World to help ye. Let me go out ne're ſo early in the Morning, or come home never ſo late at Night, there you're at it, Digging, Plowing, or Lugging ſomething or other; in a perpetual hurry, without any regard to your Quality or Perſon, I'm very certain you don't do this for your diverſion.— Perhaps you'll ſay, I hate to ſee my Work go on ſo ſlowly: Let me tell ye, Neighbour, if you'd beſtow but half the Pains upon your Servants, that you do upon your Ground, your Buſineſs wou'd go on ten times faſter.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Chremes, ha' you ſo much leiſure from your own Buſineſs, as to mind another Man's that dosn't concern ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Common Humanity, Sir, obliges me to be ſo concern'd, as I'm a Man: And therefore you may take what I ſay either by way of advice, or by way of enquiry: that if what you do be well, I may do ſo too; if ill, I may divert you from it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have Reaſon for what I do: you may do as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Can any Man ha' Reaſon to torment himſelf?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: If there were any juſt occaſion for this toyling and moyling of yours, I ſhou'dn't be againſt it. But then I wou'd gladly know what it is: and what ye ha done to deſerve ſo ill of your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Hey ho! Weeps.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Never cry for the Matter: but whate're 'tis let me know't: Out with it: Fear nothing, but •• pend upon me. I'll either condole with ye, or • viſe ye, or aſſiſt ye in what elſe I can.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Wou'd ye needs know • t then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: For the very Reaſon I juſt told ye of.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'le tell ye then.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But pray Sir, down with your Tools the mean time, and don't tire your ſelf ſo.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray what's your deſign in't?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ah! Let me alone, that I mayn't indulge my ſelf one minute.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, but I won't. He forces the Rake, &c. from him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ah! that's not fair.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What a weight's here?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I deſerve it all.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come, come; out with't now.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have an only Son, a Youth.— What did I ſay I have? Ah Chremes! I had one indeed; but whether I have now or no, I know not.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why de'e ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
I II tell ye, Sir.— Hard by dwells a poor old Woman of Cornith, whoſe Daughter my Son began to be ſo fond of, that it had like to have been a Match; and all this without my knowledge; When once I found out the Intrigue, I began to take him to task roundly; and not with the tenderneſs that is due to the Weakneſſes of Youth: But extreamly ſharp I was, after the common ranting way of Fathers. I was every day taunting at him: How now, ſaid I, De'e think to go on after this vile rate? And keep a Miſtreſs ſo openly, whilſt I am living? No Clinie, you're mightily miſtaken, and don't know me, if you think ſo; I ſhall look upon ye as mine, as long as ye do what ye ought to do; but if otherwiſe, I know what I ought to do, and you ſhall find it. I know this is only the effects of too much Idleneſs; when I was at your Years I didn't give my Mind to Women; but was forced to go a Souldier into Aſia to get a Livelihood; where by the War I got
me both Riches and Honour too. At laſt, Matters came to that paſs, that the poor Boy hearing the ſame thing preſs'd upon him ſo often, and ſo gravely, was brought over. And thinking my Age and Prudence better Guides than his own, he ſhipp'd off for Aſia, and went Reformade under the King of Perſia there, Mr. Chremes.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How's that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He ſtole away without my knowledge, and has been gone a whole quarter of a year Weeps

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You're both to blame. Yet what he has done ſhew'd both an ingenuous Temper, and a brave Spirit.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
When I heard of this Journey from ſome of his Intimado's, I went home with a Heart full of Sorrow, my Mind half diſtracted, not knowing where to turn my Head for Grief. I ſat me down, my Servants all attend my beck, ſome help To undreſs me, others run to lay the Cloth, and get my Supper ready? And all moſt diligent to aſſwage my Grief? At ſight of this, I thus began to muſe: Alas! Muſt ſo many ſweat and toil for me alone? So many ſtrive to humour me? So many Women ſpend their time to adorn my Houſe and me? Shall all theſe vaſt expences be for me alone? For me, whoſe Cruelty has driven hence my Son? My only Son, who ought t'have an equal ſhare with me or more, ſince Youth can better relliſh theſe Enjoyments. If I ſtill keep this courſe of Life, no plague too great can •• ght upon my Head. Whilſt he thus lives in penury a
•• cad, baniſhed from home by my my ſeverily, Ill e'en revenge his wrong upon my ſelf: I'll labour, ſpare, 〈◊〉 , and ſcrape up all for him. With that I put my reſolution in practice; for I've turn'd all things 〈◊〉 o' doors left neither Diſh, nor Bed for uſe, 〈◊〉 pulld down all. I turnd off all my Maids 〈◊〉 Men too, except a few to till my Land, which
were no charge to me. I expos'd all to Sale, and put Houſe to be Sold over the Door. I raiſed the Sum of two or three thouſand Pounds, and bought this Farm, where I toil and moil every day: I'm fully perſwaded Neighbour, I do leſs injury to my poor Child whilſt I'm in Miſery, as well as he: nor ought I to take any manner of Pleaſure till he return ſafe to be ſharer with me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I believe you are an indulgent Father, and he as dutiful a Son, if mamged to the beſt advantage: But indeed you didn't know his Temper, nor he well yours: And when things are ſo, theres no living. You never told him how much you valu'd him, nor had he that confidence in you which he might have preſum'd upon. If this had been, things had never came to this.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Very true, Sir, I confeſs; but I'm moſt in fault.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, I hope the beſt yet, and do verily believe you'll ſee him ſafe at home ere long

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ah! Heavens grant I may.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll warrant ve, Sir.— This is Bacchus's Day; and I ſhou'd be gald of your company ac Supper to night, if you cou'd conveniently.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I muſt beg your pardon for that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why ſo?— Pray Sir give your ſelf ſome little Refreſhment. Im ſure your abſent Son wou'd gladl • have it ſo

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: There is no Reaſon I that forc'd him to hardſhip, ſhoud ſhift it off my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is that your reſolution?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Good night t'ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And to you too.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p:
Menedeme with his Rake upon his Shoulder. Chremes alone. I profeſs he has forced Tears
from me, and I can't but pity the poor Gentleman.— But as the day goes tis time for me to invite my Neighbour Phania to Supper.— Ill call in and ſee if he's at home.—
sp.stage: Steps to Phania's Door and returns.
sp.p: Oh, I ſee he need not be reminded, for they tell me he's at our Houſe already.— I make my Gueſts ſtay for me now: Ill in to 'em.— But what makes the Door go?— who's that comes out of my Houſe.— I'll ſtep a little a one ſide.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Clinie within at Chremes's Houſe. As yet you needn't fear Clinie: they han't been ſuch a while away; I'm confident ſhe'll be here, and the M • ſſenger too in a ſhort time. Therefore ſ • ake off theſe cauſeleſs Fears that ſo torment ye.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Who's that my Son talks to? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Oh! Here's my Father; juſt as I was wiſhing for him, Ill up to him.— Sir, Im glad 〈◊〉 met with ye

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Wh • what's the Matter?

〈◊〉 Sir, dye know our Neighbour Mr. Mene
〈…〉 ?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: And that he has a Son too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, I heard he's in Aſia.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: No, Sir, but he's now at our houſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I happen'd on him juſt at his Landing, and brought him hither to Supper, for we've been very intimate form our very childhood.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Your News pleaſes me ſtrangely.— What would I give now that Mr. Menedeme had come when I invited him, that I might have been the firſt to have ſurpriz'd him with theſe joyful tydings. I believe 'tisn't too late yet.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: O Sir, have a care what you do, twon't be proper.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Becauſe he's in a great Quandary what to do with himſelf. He's but juſt come aſhore, and is diſmally afraid, both of his Father's diſpleaſure, and his Miſtreſs's Inconſtancy; whom he love; moſt entirely. 'Twas upon her account that all this ſtir, and his parting from his Father was occaſioned.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I knowt.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: He has juſt now ſent his Foot-boy into the City to her, and I made our Syrus go along with him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What ſays the young Man to the world?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What, Sir? why that he's the greate • Wretch in it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He the greateſt? No man leſs. Does he want for any thing that the World calls good? his Father's well, his Country happy, he has ſt • re of Friends, Relations of good Quality, and 〈◊〉 plentiful Eſtate. And theſe always prove good 〈◊〉 had according as the Man is; they are bleſſings 〈◊〉 thoſe that know how to uſe 'em, but plagues 〈◊〉 them that do not.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: But, Sir, his Father was always a cro's old Gentleman. And I'm afraid of nothing 〈◊〉 much, as that his Paſſion ſhould make him 〈◊〉 his Son worſe than he deſerv • s.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What he croſs?— I'll ſay no more, though, 'tis convenient he ſhould ſtand in ſome awe of his Father. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What's that you ſay to your ſelf, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
I ſay, that however the Caſe ſtood, he ought to have ſtaid at home. If his Father was a little more harſh than agreed with his debauchd Inclinations, he ſhould have taken it patiently; for whom ſhould he bear withal, if
he can't with his Father? Which is moſt proper, think ye, the Father to live after the Son's humour, or the Son according to his Father's: As for the young Man's pretending he's hardly dealt by, 'tis no ſuch matter. For the Severities of Parents, (I mean ſuch as are not exceſſively ſevere) are very much the ſame; namely, they won't ſuffer their Sons to be always at the Bawdyhouſe, nor always at the Tavern; and will allow 'em but a little ſpending Money; and yet all this is for their Childrens good. For when ones Mind is quite drencht in Debaucheries, all that he does will have a notable Smack on't. And Son take this for a Rule, Never to buy Wit, when you can have it at another Man's coſt.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I fancy ſo.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll go in, and ſee how Supper goes forward You know how late it is, therefore don't be ou • of the way. Exit Chremes.

sp.speaker: Clitipho
sp.p:
alone. What unconſcionable Creatures theſe ſame Fathers are! to expect their Children ſhould turn Philoſophers in their hanging Sleeves, without ſo much as touching upo' the Levities of youth. They meaſure us by their own depraved Appetities as they are at preſent, and not as they were formerl • .— Well! If ever Heaven ſend me a Son o' my own, he ſhall have an extream loving Father o • me: For he ſhan't be afraid to make me his very Confeſſor, and I'll be ſ • re to give him Abſolution: I'll not do as mine, who ſlyly inſinuates his Morals by a ſide Wind. It vexes me,— when he begins to be Mellow, he'll then tell me of all his old Pranks! but now he reads me a Lect re, about Buying of Wit at other Mens coſts. A crafty Gentleman i'faith! Little does he think that he has preach'd to the wind. My Miſtreſs's Words ſtick more in my
Stomach by half than all his Preachments: Give me this fine thing, and buy me that: And i'faith I can't anſwer her a word. There's none ſo damnably put to't as I.— Altho' this Mr. Clinie has enough lying upon his own hands, yet his Miſtreſs is well and modeſtly brought up, and unacquainted with the tricks of the Town: but mine's an imperious, craving, ſtately Dame: damnably expenſive, and as proud as the Devil. When ſhe asks me for any thing, I return her a Nod; but to tell her I han't for her, is a Mortal Sin.
I did but lately theſe damn'd Tricks eſpy, Yet all lies huſh'd and kept from Daddy's Eye.

div.trailer: End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Clinie as from Chremes's, and Clitipho behind him at diſtance.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: to himſelf. HAd there been any good News for me about my Miſtreſs, I'm ſure they'd ha' been here before now. But I'm horribly afraid ſome Body has been tampering with her in my abſence. There are a thouſand circumſtances running in my Brain that rack my Mind: Opportunity, Place, Youth, a wicked Mother that governs her, and that would pawn her Soul for Half a piece.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Mr. Clinie.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What a Wretch am I?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p:
Have a care, Sir, that none of your Fathers
Family drop out and ſee you here.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I'll look to that.— But I'm afraid there's ſome miſchief towards, for my mind miſgives me ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: D'ye uſe to judge of things, before ye know what they are.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Why, if there hadn't been ſome unlukineſs i' th' wind, we ſhould have ſeen 'em before this time.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: They'll be here in a minute, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: But when will that Minute come?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: You don't conſider that 'tis a great way off.' And when Women, ye know, fall once to Powd'ring and Combing, they are an Age a rigging out.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, Clitipho, I'm very uneaſie.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Bear up man,— yonder comes Dromo and Syrus both together.
sp.stage: Enter Syrus and Dromo at another part of the Stage talking together.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Dromo.— Say • ſt thou ſo my Lad? Ha • !

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Juſt as I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But hold,— Looking about him. Whilſt we go twattling on, we've loſt the women.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: D'ye hear that Clinie? Your Miſtreſs will be here preſently.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Yes, I do hear at laſt; and now am come to ſome Life and Senſe again, Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: to Syrus Faith I don't wonder they lag behind; having drawn ſo great a train at their Heels.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: over-hearing Dromo. Confuſion! How came ſhe by ſuch a Train?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: D'ye ask me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Dromo. Troth we did not do well to leave 'em ſo, for they've things of conſiderable value about 'em,—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: All's paſt recovery.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: — As Jewels and fine Cloaths.— Beſides 'tis ſomewhat duskiſh, and they know not a ſtep o' th' way.— In ſober ſadneſs we've done like a couple of Fools.— Prithee D • omo, do you go back, and meet them.— Make haſte: what d'ye ſtay for?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh curſed misfortune, how baſely have my hopes deceiv'd me!

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What's the matter? what makes ye ſo concern'd now?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So concern'd ſay ye?— Don't ye hear what a train of Servants, what Jewels and fine Cloaths ſhe brings with her? when I left her but with one Girl to wait upon her: where ſhould ſhe have all this, think ye?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Po! Now I know his Diſtemper.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Bleſs me! What a damnable crew is coming?— I'm ſure our Houſe will ſcarce hold 'em all— What a plaguy deal will they eat and drink, and how woefully our old Maſter will be put to't!— But hold here are the Sparks I wanted.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! What's become of true Faith? Whilſt for your ſake, Antiphila, I fled my Native Country like a rambling Madman; you have feathered your Neſt finely at home, and left me in the midſt of all my troubles. You, I ſay, that are the cauſe of my fouleſt diſgrace, and of my being ſo regardleſs of my Father. Now I'm aſham'd and troubl'd to the Soul, that he who read me ſo many good Lectures upon the Tric •• of thoſe Creatures, loſt all his Advice; and was not able to make me leave her. But now it muſt be done: When it might have been much to my advantage, then I wou'dn't,— Not a Creature more miſerable than me.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: aſide. Faith Mr. Clinie has miſunderſtood every Syllable we were talking of.— To Clinie. Hark ye, Sir; you think worſe of your Miſtreſs than ſhe deſerves: for as far as we can gather from circumſtances, ſhe's ſtill the ſame Woman; and her Heart as true to you as ever.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: How's that? prithee tell me. For I'd d • ſi • e nothing i'th' world ſooner than to find my jealouſies falſly grounded.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: In the firſt place, that y • o may be ſure to know all: the old Woman that went for your Miſtreſs's Mother was nothing related to her; and ſhe's gone to her long home. This by chance I heard Antiphila tell the other, as I was coming along.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Prithee what other was that? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Good Sir, have patience, and let me finiſh my firſt Story, and then I'll come to yours.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Diſpatch it quickly then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
To begin; when we were got to the Houſe, Dromo knocks at the Door; out comes an old Woman: as ſoon as ſhe had open'd it, Dromo whips in, and I after him; the old Woman claps to the Door, and falls hard to work again. And now was the time or never, Sir, to learn how your Miſtr • ſs had ſpent her time in your abſence; ſince we dropp'd upon her unawares, and this gave us an opportunity of making a Gueſs at their common Practices; which give the beſt Light into Peoples Humours. We found her hard at it, making of Tapeſtry, meanly dreſs'd in a Sute of Morning, for the old woman that's dead, I ſuppoſe. She had no rich or gawdy Attire on, but dreſs'd like thoſe homely Dames that have no Gallants to ſee: Nor yet dawb'd over with naſty paint: But her Hair looſly • hevelled, and careleſsly thrown about her
Shoulders. Forbear! Clinie going to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Prithee honeſt boy, don't feed me like a Fool.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Well Sir, the old woman ſhe ſpun: beſides her there was a Girl weaving too with patch't Cloaths, ill dreſs'd and very naſty.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: If this be true, Mr. Clinie, as I fancy 'tis, thou'rt the happieſt Man alive. Didn't you mind how ſluttiſh and naſty he ſaid the Maid was? That's a certain ſign Man, the Miſtreſs is honeſt' when the Confident goes in Rags: for 'tis always the way to Fee the Chamber-maid firſt, before they make court to the Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Prithee, dear Rogue, on with your Story, but have a care of currying Favour by your Flams. What ſaid ſhe, when you firſt mentioned me?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: When I told her you were landed; and deſir'd her company forth with, ſhe immediately threw aſide her Work, and cou'dn't ſpeak for crying; which, you may be ſure, was all for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: As I hope for Mercy, I'm ſo tranſported, I ſcarce know where I am, I was in ſuch a fright but juſt now.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I knew, Sir, there was nothing amiſs.— Now 'tis my turn, Syrus: Let's know who that other was.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: We've brought Madam Bacchis your Miſtreſs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: How?— Bacchis d'ye ſay? Why ye curſed Dog whither d'ye bring her. In a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Whether d'ye bring her? Why to our houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What to my Father's Sirrah? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, to your Father's.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: To ſee the Impudence of this Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Heark ye, Sir, Eaint Heart never won fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Look to't Sirrah, ſhall you pretend to advance your own Reputation upo' my coſt: If you ſtep but the leaſt awry, I'm gone to all intents and purpoſes— And what will ye do then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But Sir—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: But, What?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, if you'll give me leave.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Prithee give him leave.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Well then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The caſe is thus,— as if—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Pox he's going to tell a Story nine hours long.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I think ſo too.— Therefore, Syrus, leave fooling, and come to the point.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: In troth Sir, I can hold no longer, you're grown ſo troubleſome, that there's no dealing with you.— To Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: to Clitipho. Faith you ſhould give him the hearing tho, therefore pray be ſilent a little.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You'd have a Miſtreſs, Sir; you'd enjoy her, and be able to preſent her too, but you wou'dn't run any hazard for her. Really you are wonderous wiſe: If it be wiſdom to aim at that which can never be. You muſt either take the Hazard with the Prize, or loſe the Prize and run no Hazard. Now, Sir, take which ſide you love beſt: Tho I'm very certain the Plot I've laid is both well contrived and ſafe: Firſt, you'll have the liberty of your Miſtreſſes Company under your Father's Noſe, without the leaſt danger; and then by the ſelf-ſame means I ſhall find a Trick to nib the old Man o'th' Money you promis'd her; for which you've ſo often deafen'd my Ears with your Duns. And what a Duce wou'd you have more?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Provided it be as you ſay.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Hang your Provideds, can't you run the hazard on't.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Well, come on then, your Plot, how is't laid?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Your Miſtreſs ſhall go for this Gentleman • s—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Very fine!— But prithee, what ſhall we do with his own then? Shall ſhe be clapt upon his Back too, as tho one wasn't enough to crack his Credit.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: We'll have her to your Mother's.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What to do there?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, 'twill take up nine hours indeed to give ye the Why's and Wherefore • s. 'Tis enough, that I ha' reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Meer ſtuff! I can ſee nothing as yet to remove my ſuſpitions.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Hold Sir.— If you're afraid of this Plot, I've another in my head, which I'm ſure you'll both own to be ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Prithee invent me ſuch a one as that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That I will in an inſtant.— I'll give 'em the meeting, and pray 'em to face about, and march home again.— Scornfully.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Hah! What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'll rid you of your Fears with a vengeance: that you may be ſure to • leep ſound in a whole Skin.— Is going off.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Clinie. What had I beſt do now?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What you Sir? Why e'en make good uſe of—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Hark ye, Syrus, tell me truly what I ſhould do.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Away, away, you'll wiſh ye had, when 'tis too late.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Here's a fair Opportunity offer'd; make good uſe on't while you may; you aren't ſure of having the like again.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Why, Syrus, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Bawl till your Heart ake, I'll on for all that.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Clinie. In good earneſt you're i'th' right on't.— But hark ye, Syrus; Syrus I ſay; foho Syrus.— Aloud.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: No Syrus; I throw my ſelf, my Love, my Reputation too into your Hands. Ill leave all to your determination; but ſee you diſcharge your Truſt well.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That's Counſel worth laughing at i'faith: As tho my Game wasn't at ſtake as well as yours. If an unlucky caſt comes up, and ſpoils all our Deſigns, you'll come off with a Reprimand, or ſo; But poor Pilgarlick muſt meet with a dry beating. Upo' this Score, I muſt mind my Buſineſs very colſely. But you muſt beg this Gentleman to gallant your Miſtreſs the while.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: He may be ſure of my aſſiſtance: And as the caſe ſtands I'm oblig'd to't.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, I'm extreamly engag'd to ye.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: You muſt take care Bacchis ben't out in her part.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe has her Leſſon to a tittle.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: For my part, I wonder how you could wheadle her to come ſo ſoon; for ſhe ſometimes would ſcorn the very beſt of ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
I took her in the very critical minute, which is the moſt nicking Advantage: For who ſhould I find there but a ſneaking Captain paying his Devoirs for one ſingle Night's Lodging; ſhe manag'd this poor Devil tightly with ſuch Artifice, as to inflame his greedy Appetite by keeping him at Bay: and at the ſame time to do a Signal piece of Service to you.— But hark ye Sir, have a care of making any falſe ſtep: You know how plaguy ſhap-ſighted your Father is in theſe
Intrigues. And I can tell, how hard it is for you to keep your ſelf within compaſs. You muſt have a mighty care of all double-meaning expreſſions, of caſting a Sheep's Eye over your left Shoulder; of ſighing, ſpitting, humming and jeering.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Faith I'll act it rarely.—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: See that you do then.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: — You your ſelf ſhall admire me for't

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But ſee how quickly the Ladies come after us?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Where are they? why dye hold me Boy: To Syrus holding him.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You've nothing to do with her now.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Right, not before my Father.— But till then.—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No nor till then neither.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Come let me go.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: ſtill holding him. Not a ſtep, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Prithee, for one minute.

sp.speaker: S • r.
sp.p: That I forbid too.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: A civil Reſpect at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Get ye gone, if you've any Guts in your Brains.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p:
Well I'm going, but what muſt Clini ••
do?

sp.speaker: Syr
sp.p: Stay here

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: He has a fine time ont!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Troop off, I ſay.
sp.stage: Clitipho walks on a little a one ſide.

p.stage: Enter at a diſtance Bacchis, Antiphila, Dromo, Waiting-Maids, &c.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
In troth, dear Philie, I can't but commend ye, and think ye very happy; in being ſo careful as to make your good Behaviour wholly anſwerable to your Beauty. As I'm a Sinner, I
don't admire that all the Sparks of the Town ſhou'd die for ye, ſince your Diſcourſe diſcovers the Sweetneſs of your diſpoſition: For my part, when I come to conſider the Life and Converſation of all ſuch as you, who are n't common to every Coxcomb, I don't wonder to find ye ſo modeſt and vertuous, and our ſelves ſo very little like ye. For you it is the beſt way to be honeſt, but our Gallants won't ſuffer us to be ſo. Our Beauty makes 'em adore us for a while, but when that's decay'd, the Sparks are mad for a new Face: So that if we didn't provide for our ſelves in time, we might een pine away the reſt of our days in a Deſart. For you Madam, that take up with a Perſon, whoſe Age and Nature is correſpondent with your own, he wholly keeps himſelf to you, and by mutual conſent your Loves are made firm; and nothing can ever ſeparate your Hearts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'm little acquainted with others; my ſelf I know well enough, who always take care that my dear Clinie's Happineſs ſhoud be the Foundaof my own.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: overhearing. Ah, my dear Antiphila, 'tis for thy ſake alone that Im come home again; for whilſt I was from thee all the Hardſhips I was put to were nothing to the being deprivd of thy ſweet Company.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Clitipho peeping from his Covert. I believe him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I can ſcarce contain my ſelf old Boy! Is't not a plaguy thing to be debarred of one's Humour? Hah!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Clitipho. As far as I can perceive your Father will make ye ſmart fort, if you bent gon.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What young Gentleman's that which ogles us ſo?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: ſeeing Clinie. Oh,— lend me your hand 〈◊〉 beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: For Heaven ſake, what all ye my Dear?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'm going.— Faints away.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Help.— Alas, poor Soul!— Antiphila
• ecovers a little. How came this Fit upon ye my Philie!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: in a ſoft Tone Do I ſee my Clinie, or do I dream.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: VVho's that you ſee?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: My Life, my Soul; Heavens bleſs thee.— Embracing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And thee alſo my long wiſh'd for dear Clinie.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: How is't my dear?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, ſince I've got you again my Dear.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: embracing. And have I got you again, my Dear, within theſe Arms? You that I have ſo paſſionately long'd for?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Come, come, turn in: The old Man and his Supper ſtays for ye. Exeunt omnes.

div.trailer: End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
div.p:
'TIs juſt break of Day: And why ſhou'dn't I knock at my Neighbour's door now, and give him the firſt news of his Son's Return, tho the young man I fancy will hardly thank me for it? But when I ſee the poor Geneleman take on ſo extremely for his Sons leaving him, how can I
find in my heart to keep from him this unexpected comfort, ſince his Son will be never the worſe for't neither? This muſt not be. For I will aſſiſt the old man to the utmoſt of my power. And as I perceive his Son and mine help one another all they can, and go hand in hand together in all their concerns; ſo it is but reaſonable that we their Fathers ſhould do one another all the good Offices we are able.
div.stage: Enter Menedeme on the other ſide of the Stage with a Rake, &c. upon his Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: to himſelf. Either I'm born under the Fatality of an unlucky Planet, or that old Sayings worth nothing, that Time cures all things. For this abſence of my Son afflicts me every day more and more; and the longer he's away, the more I deſire to ſee him again, and the more I miſs him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Oh, yonder's the Gentleman himſelf coming from home; I'll to him, and diſcourſe.— Morrow to ye Neighbour, I'm come to ye with ſuch News, that I believe you'll be heartily deſirous to know what tis.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why, Sir, have ye heard any thing of my Son then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He's ſafe and ſound. Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Where is he, I beſeech ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: At my Houſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What my Son?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, your Son.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Is he come home then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My Boy Clinie come home?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Even ſo.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let's be going then.— I beſeech ye, Sir, bring me to the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But he wou'dn't for the World have ye know he's come back: He avoids your Preſence upon the account of what he has done; and is now afraid, you ſhould be more ſevere than ever.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And didn't you tell him, how I was quite another man?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why didn't ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Becauſe if he finds you ſo ſoft, and give way ſo eaſily, 'twill be the whoſe for him and you too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It can't be help'd; for I've been too too ſevere a Father already.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, you are always upon the extreams, either too profuſe or too ſparing; you run into the ſame inconveniencies by one as well as the other. Formerly you forc'd your Son out of Doors rather than ſuffer him to keep a Miſtreſs, who then was contented with a little, and would have been glad to have ſnapp'd at any thing: but when ſhe was forc'd, by his leaving her, to grow common, and now can't be kept without a Mine of Money; now you give him his full liberty. For to let you know how ſhe is accoutred for the Ruin of Mankind; ſhe carries at her Heels no leſs than ten or a dozen Waiting-Maids, with a great luggage of Golden Trappings; were a Prince her Gallant, he d be put to t, to maintain her: Don t you think to do't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Is ſhe at your Houſe too?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
She at my Houſe ſay ye?— Yes, to my coſt, I ve made but one Treat for her and her Retinue; and I faith, if I make another, I muſt be forced to run my Country. To omit other Charges, what a curſed deal of Wine has ſhe conſumed me by her taſting and ſipping only: Crying, Good old Father, this ſame Wine is too rough, pray, Sir, let's have ſome that is more ſmooth. I pened every Cask
and Pipe in my Cellar, and all my Servants we: as buſie as ſo many Bees: And this was but one nights work; what will become of you then when they ll prey upon ye every day? As I'm • living Soul, Sir, I heartily pity your condition.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: E • en let him do as he liſts: Let him take it, ſpend it, make Ducks and Drakes of it; I' •• reſolved to bear it, ſo I can but have him at h • m • with me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: If you be ſo much ſet upon't: I believe 'twill be much the better way to conceal your Deſign, what're you allow him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What wou'd ye have me do?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Any thing rather than that you intended • Can't you convey him Money by a ſecond hen • and let your own Servant bubble ye or ſo? And the truth on't is, I have an inkling that that are about ſome ſuch thing already; and that they are contriving how to do t moſt cleverly. My Man Syrus, he whiſpers with yours, and the young Men they lay their Heads together too: And tis better to loſe a Pound this way than a Penny t other. 'Tisn't ſo much the Money, Neighbour, that is to be minded, as the manne • how to give it him with the leaſt danger: For if he once finds which way the Stream runs, and that you had rather part with your Life and Money too, than loſe him: Phy! What a vaſt Gap d • you lay open to his Debaucheries? So that your Life will be a burden to ye; For too much Libe •• corrupts an Angel: Whatſoever Crotchet comes in his Crown, he'll be for't without conſidering whether his Demands be reaſonable or no: You ll never endure to ſee your Eſtate go to wreck, and your Son ſpoiled into the Bargain. If you refuſe him a Farthing; he'll fall to the old Dog-trick, which he finds will work moſt upon ye, and threaten to be gon forſooth.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: All this ſeems true and probable enough.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, I cou'dn't ſleep one wink this Night for racking my Head to reſtore to you your Son.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Your hand Sir.— I hope, Sir, you'll go on as you ve begun.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I m ready to ſerve ye.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: D'ye know what I mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Let's hear't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: That you'd haſten 'em in the Deſign, you perceive they have, of getting the Money from me: For I long to give my Boy what he wants, and as much to have a ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll do my beſt, Sir, I muſt take my Syrus in Hand, and give him his Leſton.— But hold ſome body's coming out of my Houſe.— You had beſt get out o'th way; for fear they perceive we are plotting together. A little buſineſs at preſent calls me hence; for my Neighbour Simus and Crito have ſome difference about ſome Lands, and made me their Referree: I'll go tell 'em they muſt not look for me to day, as I promiſed them: I'll be here again in a minute.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray Sir do. Exit Chremes.

sp.speaker: Menedeme
sp.p: alone. Bleſs me! What an odd compoſition Men are of! that they ſhould ſee further and judge better of other Peoples Affairs than their own? It may be, becauſe in our own concerns we are too much prepoſſeſſed by our Paſſions of Joy or Grief. This ſame Chremes now, how much wiſer he ſeems to be for me, than I am for my ſelf? Going off.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Mededeme as he is going off. I have got clear of them both, that I may ſerve you with more leiſure.
sp.stage: Exit Menedeme with his Rake, &c. upon • h Shoulder is

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Well, Friend Syrus, take this way or that way, Money muſt be had by hook or by crook; and our old Fox muſt be trapped too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: partly hearing. I wan't miſtaken I perceive when I ſaid they were about ſome ſuch deſign. Clinies Man is a poor dull Tool, but mine's a ſharper; he muſt do the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Whoſe Tongue's that?— Zookers all's ſpoiled? Did he hear me trow or no?— Aſide,

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What is it you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's your buſineſs here?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No great matter.— You're a brave Man, Sir, to be ſtirring ſo early this morning, after ſuch a rattle laſt Night.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why there was no hard drinking.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No hard drinking, ſay ye? marry, I think, you re heart of Oak.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: This ſame Wench of Clinie's is a good ſort of a Wench, and pleaſant enough.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, ſo I found.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: And in troth has a very good Face too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: So ſo.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Tho, not comparable to the Women in your days: but really as the World goes now, the Woman is very well: And I don't wonder Clinie is ſo deſperately ſmitten: But he has a Father, a covetuous, miſerable, griping old Hunks, our next Neighbour; Do ye know him Sir?— Becauſe he is afraid he ſhou'd be ſtarved himſelf, he has turned his poor Son out a grazing; D • n • you know what I ſay to be true?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, Why not?— There's a Raſcal deſerves the Strapado.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What Raſcal, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: The dull Rogue Clinie's Man.—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: (Faith Syrus I was plaguily afraid of thy Corps.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: — That ſuffer'd all this.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What cou'd he do?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What cou'd he do? Why he might ha found out ſome device, or invented any ſlight to have help'd the young Gentleman to Money for his Miſtreſs: And ſo ha' ſav'd the ſtingy old Fellow from all this vexation, whether he wou'd or no.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You're pleas'd to rally Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Twas no more than his Duty, Syrus.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, do you approve of thoſe that put tricks upo their own Maſters?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, if there be juſt occaſion for't.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Very well I faith.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Sometimes a little Tricking ſaves a great deal of Trouble: As in this Caſe, twou'd ha' kept his only Son from rambling.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith I can't tell, whether he's in jeſt or in earneſt: However he encourages me to that which I had a plaguy mind to before.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And now, Syrus, why does the Fellow • dle away his time ſo, till his Maſter be forc d to march off a ſecond time, for not being able to defray his Miſtreſs's Charges: Won't he raiſe one battery againſt the old Man's Pocket.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The Fellow's a Fool, God bleſs him

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You ſhou'd give him one Puſh for the young Gentleman's ſake.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Sir, I'd dot with all my Heart, if you'd ſay but the Word; for I'm a compleat Maſter of that Art.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: So much the better.

sp.speaker: Syr,
sp.p: — I don't uſe to fail, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: VVhy do't then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, take care to remember this, if it ſhould chance one day to be your Son's caſe, for you know we are all ſubject to failings.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ihope, I ſhall have no occaſion for that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Troth, ſo do I: nor do I mention this, becauſe I ſuſpect any ſuch thing; but I ſay again, if it ſhould chance to happen ſo, that you mightn't,— You ſee he's but young. And e'dad, Sir, if that time once come, I ſhould manage ye moſt nobly.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: VVell talk of that when that time comes. Do you mind your preſent • ue? Exit Chremes.
Syrus alone. Well, I never heard Maſter talk better than mine upon this occaſion. I cou'd never ha' hop'd to have had ſuch a large Toleration for Roguery.— But who comes out of our Houſe there?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Clitipho entering. What Impudence is this I pray? 's this your Trade Clitipho? Do theſe things become you? Hah!

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What did I do, Sir;

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Didn't I ſee ye juſt now with your hand in the Courteſan's Boſom?

sp.speaker: S • r.
sp.p: liſtning. Alls out, I'm quite broke.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Who I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Theſe very Eyes ſaw it: come don't ſtand in a lye. You deal baſely by the Gentleman that you cou'dn't keep your hands to your ſelf. For 'tis a great Affront to entertain a Friend, and then play an under-hand Game with his Miſtreſs. How ſtrangely uncivil you were laſt night at Supper too?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You re i'th Right on't, Sir. To Chremes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
And how troubleſome too? That, as I'm a living Soul, I was miſerably afraid it ſhould ha
coſt you a Duel. I know the humour of theſe Lovers is to reſent things extreamly, which no body dream of.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: But, Sir, he has a mighty confidence in me, and knows I won't ſerve him an unhandſome Trick.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What then? But you might ha' left 'em together a little while however: Lovers have a thouſand things to ſay and do, which your Preſence is a curb to; I know this by my ſelf: for I have never a Friend i'th' world, Clitipho, that I dare truſt all my private Actions with: I'm afraid of my Superior, and aſham'd of my Equal, leſt the one ſhould take me for a Fool, and the other for a Debauchee.— Suppoſe it to be his Caſe: For 'tis our Duty to know when and where to be complaiſant to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye mind what he ſays?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Ay, to my Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Didn't I tell you of this before? But you've play'd the part of a very ſtaid and reſerv'd Gentleman! Aſide, and jeeringly to Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Prithee hold your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You are i'th' right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ſwear Syrus, I'm aſham'd of him.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: So I believe, Sir: and good reaſon too, for it grieves me alſo very much.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What ne're a done?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I ſpeak as I think.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Chremes. Muſtn t I come nigh 'em then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, in a civil way, but not as you do.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: aſide. Our Plot's juſt ſinking: He'll betray all before we get one Bag of Money.— to Chremes. Pray, Sir, will ye be pleas d to take a Fool's Counſel for once? Chr. What's that?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: To order him to withdraw a little

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Whither, I pray?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
Whither? why whither you pleaſe, make
room for the Lovers, and take a turn the while.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I take a turn? To what place?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Piſh! as if ye wanted a place to walk in: take this way, or that way, or which way you will.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He ſays right, I'll have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Confound ye for a Dog! for ſending me to the De'el's Arſe a peak.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Keep your Hands to your ſelf then another time. Aſide to Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What ſay ye, Sir? What d'ye think will become of this Son of yours, if ye don't, with the utmoſt Authority of a Father, give him due Correction and Inſtruction?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, and now's the time you muſt watch him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ay, ſo you had beſt: for he minds me every day leſs and leſs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But hark ye Syrus, tho'! Ha' ye conſider'd the buſineſs, I told ye of? He' ye found any Plot according to your Mind yet?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You mean about the bubbling of Menedeme.— S't Sir! I've juſt now ſtumbl'd upon one.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Thou'rt a brave Lad: Prithee what is • t?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, Sir: But as one thing brings out another. Chr. What then Boy?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: This ſame Bacchis is a plaguy Jade.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: So I thought.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
aſide. Yes, if you knew all.— Do but obſerve what a Whore's trick ſhe's going to play. Here lives an old Woman of C •
rinth, to whom this Baggage had lent above thir • y • ounds.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: This old Womans dead and gone, and left her young Daughter whom ſhe, keeps in pawn for for the Money.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: So then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Her has this Bacchis brought along with the reſt: and ſhe's now in your Lady's Apartment.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well, and how then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: She baits at Clinie to lay down the Money, and then ſhe'll give him the Girl for an Acquittance. But ſhe demands the full ſumm of Thirty Pounds.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Does ſhe ſo?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Whoo! D'ye queſtion it?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I did— But what d'ye mean to do next?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Who I Sir?— I'll away to Mr. Menedeme's tell him that this Girl was ſpirited away from Caria, that ſhe's one of a rich and noble Family, and he'll get the Lord knows what, if he'll ranſom her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You've miſs'd the Mark.

sp.speaker: C • r.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll anſwer ye for Menedeme: I'll have nothing to do with her: What's your Reply?

sp.speaker: Cyr.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, ſpeak more to our Mind.

sp.speaker: Shr.
sp.p: There's no occaſion for that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No occaſion, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No marry is there.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Why, Sir? I don't take your meaning.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll tell ye preſently.— Stay, ſtay, a little!— What's the meaning of this buſtle at our Door.
sp.stage: Enter at a diflance Soſtrata, with a Ring in her Hand, and the Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: to the Nurſe entring. If I ben't mightily miſtaken, this is the very Ring I ſuſpect my Daughter had about her when expos'd.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What means my Woman by this talk, Syrus?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: How is't Nurſe, is't not the ſame think ye?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I ſaid 'twas the ſame, as ſoon as e're I ſaw't.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: But did ye view it well?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Oh, very well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Do you go in; and bring me word whether ſhe has bathed her ſelf; the mean time I'll wait here for my Husband. Exit Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Chremes. She wants you Sir, you had beſt ſtep and ſee what ſhe'd have. I can't gueſs why ſhe's ſo i'th' dumps: 'Tisn't for nothing I'm ſure— I fear the worſt.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pſhaw! What ſhou'd it be? She's only big with Fool, and wants to be deliver'd.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Hah, my good old Man!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And my good old Woman too.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: I was looking for thee my Bird.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well now, your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Firſt, I'd deſire ye to believe that I wou'd n't do any thing againſt your Commands.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That's very hard to believe, but if you'd ha' me, for once I'll believe't.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: This clearing her ſelf aforehand bodes ſome plaguy Miſchief. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Don't you remember, when I was once big with Child, you ſtrictly charg'd me not to bring it up, if it prov'd a Girl.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ſmell out the buſineſs, you have brought it up then. Isn't it ſo?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: If that be true, 'twill make a damn'd hole in my Maſter's Pocket.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: No ſuch matter: for I gave it to an old Woman of Corinth, a good honeſt Neighbour of ours to expoſe it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Bleſs us! Was there ever ſuch a Simpleton?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Oh me! What hurt have I done?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What hurt quoth a? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Indeed dear Husband! If I have offended 'twas ignorantly.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I know this well enough, tho' you had ne're own'd it, that every thing you ſay or do is ignorantly and fooliſhly. How many Blunders ha' you committed in this one thing! Firſt, had you, regarded my Authority, the Girl ſhou'd ha' been made away withal, and you ſhou'dn't ha' come with an idle flam of her Death, when you did all ye cou'd to ſave her.— But let that paſs, 'twas Fondneſs, and a Mother's Tenderneſs: 〈◊〉 bear with • t. But how rarely you've forecaſted • he Buſineſs! And what were your Intentions? P • ay conſider on't. 'Tis moſt manifeſt you've betray'd your▪ Child to this old Woman, either for a common Proſtitute, or to be expos'd to publick Sale. I fancy you thought any thing wou'd ſerve turn, ſo her Life was ſav'd. But why ſhou'd one trouble his Head with ſuch Fools, who know nothing • f Juſtice, Honeſty or Reaſon: Be it better or worſe, for 'em or againſt 'em, they ſee nothing but what they liſt.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: My dear Chremes! I confeſs I was much to blame, and am convinc • d: And now let me beg of ye, as Nature has made you the Wiſer of the two, ſo be the more generous: And let your Goodneſs protect my Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well I'll forgive ye this Fault: But in ſober Sadneſs, Wife, my good Nature will be the ſpoiling of ye. But now let's hear the occaſion of this Story whate re it be.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: As we Women are always very fooliſh and ſuperſtitious; ſo when I gave the Child to be expos'd, I took a Ring off my Finger, and ſent it with her; that, if ſhe died, ſhe might ha' carried away ſome Token of our Kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
That's well; ſo you ſav'd the Child's Life,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
and had your own Humour into the Bargain too.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: ſhewing a Ring. Look ye, this is the very Ring.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How came ye by • t?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: The young Gentlewoman that Bacchis b • ought with her,—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: How! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What ſays ſhe to't?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: — She gave it me to hold, whilſt ſhe went to the Bath: At firſt I took no notice on't; but when I eyed it more narrowly, I knew it, and came running in all haſte to acquaint you.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And what can ye ſuppoſe or gather from this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: I can't tell without you'll examine her where ſhe had it, if ſhe can inform you about it.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: My Plot's countermin'd: I find there's more i'th Wind than I cou'd wiſh for; ſhe's certainly my Maſter's Daughter, if this be true. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Is the old Woman alive ye deliver'd the Child to?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How did ſhe ſay ſhe had diſpos'd on't?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Juſt as I order'd her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's her Name, that we may hunt her up?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The very ſame, She's as ſurely found, as I'm loſt. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come, Wife, let's retire.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: How things happen beyond my Expectation! I was extreamly afraid you'd prove as ſevere now, as when you gave your firſt Orders.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: A Man can't always do, as he wou'd, if his Eſtate won't afford • t: Now my Circumſtances are ſuch, that I ſhou'd be glad of a Daughter: Formerly 'twas otherwiſe. Exeunt omnes.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Syrus
sp.p: IF I am not very much miſtaken, I'm in a fa •• way to be utterly routed; all my forces are ſo miſerably ſtreightned, that I ſhall never come of • ſafe, unleſs I find out ſome way to keep the old Man from perceiving this to be his Son's Miſtreſs. For to hope for one ſowce of Money, or to think of topping upon the old Fellow will be to no purpoſe. I ſhall come off nobly, and with flying Colours, if I can compound for a Leg or an Arm. It goes to the very heart of me, to have ſuch a delicate bit ſnatcht ſo ſuddenly out of my very Chaps.— What ſhall I go about?— Or what ſhall I invent?— I muſt draw a new Platform.— Hang't, Diligence out does the Devil.— Suppoſe I go this way to work.— Pox, that won't do— Suppoſe that way.— 'T will be all one.— But I believe this will do't.— No,— Yes, beſt of all— I ha't, I ha't: I believe I ſhall once more come to the fingering of that damn'd Run-a-gate Money.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: to himſelf. From this time forward nothing can happen to me that can give me any diſquiet: Such is the Happineſs I'm ſurpriz'd into. I'll ſo wholly give up my ſelf to my Fathers pleaſure now, that I'll be far better than he himſelf can wiſh.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
aſide. I wasn't beſide the mark I ſee: The Gentlewoman is really diſcovered, by what I
hear from the Spark— to Clinie. I'm heartily glad, Sir, things are fallen out ſo favourable to your deſires.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Prithee, honeſt Boy, did you hear on't too?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, for I was by at the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Did ye ever know any one ſo fortunate as I?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Let me die if I'm half ſo glad for my own. ſake as for hers, whom no bleſſing can be too great for.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I believe ſo too. Now Clinie it comes to your turn to do us a ſmall kindneſs: You muſt remember your Friend, that his buſineſs may be ſecur'd too, and his Miſtreſs be ſtill conceal'd from our old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: not minding him. Gods!—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Forbear theſe Raptures.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: — Shall my dear Antiphila be mine then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Won't ye let me ſpeak, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What wouldſt have me do, old Soul? • m ſo tranſported, prithee bear with me.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith ſo I do, but ſore againſt my will.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: ſtill not minding him. We ſhall live as happy as the Gods.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I ſee my Labour's loſt.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Now ſpeak, I'm ready.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But by and by you won't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Yes, but I will.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I tell ye, Sir, there's ſome care to be taken, that your Friend's Buſineſs be ſecur'd. Now if you go away and leave Bacchis at our Houſe, my old Maſter will immediately find her to be his Son's Miſtreſs: But if you take her along with ye, the Intrigue will be as much i • th' dark, as ever 'twas,

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Ah, but Syrus, nothing makes more againſt my wedding than this; for with what Face can I ſpeak on't to my Father? Do you mind what I ſay?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay to him? what excuſe can I pretend?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: VVhat?— I wou'dn't have ye ſay one word of untruth: but e'en plainly tell him the whole buſineſs. Clin. How!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'd have ye tell him your Paſſion for Antiphila, and that you'd needs marry her: but that this Bacchis is Clitipho's Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: You demand of me nothing but what is juſt, reaſonable and eaſie; I ſuppoſe you'd have me beg my Father to keep all from your old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You miſtake me; I'd ha' your Father tell him the whole ſtory directly, from top to bottom

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: How! Are you mad or drunk? Introth you'll plainly ruin him: Prithee-tell me how he can have his Buſineſs ſecur'd, as ye ſay?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh, I reckon this a M • ſter-piece of my Cunning: In this P •• t I triumph in having that mighty knack and ••• ulty at Juggling as to cheat both of them, by telling the truth: So that when your old Gentleman ſhall tell our old Gentleman of his Sons Miſtreſs, he ſhall laugh at it.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: So you •• ce more deſtroy all my hopes of Matrimony: F •• as long as Chremes believes her to be my Miſtre •• ; he'll never venture his Daughter upon me. •• rhaps you don't care whether I ſink or ſwim, ſo you can but ſerve Clitipho's turn.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What • Pox! D'ye think I'd ha' ye act the Cheats for ever? One day ſerves my turn, till I've finger'd the Money, that's all: Not a bit longer do I deſire.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Will one day ſerve? But what if his Father ſhou'd find out all i • th mean time?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Right! And what if the Sky ſhou'd fall!

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I dread what will come on't.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Dread? A Fiddle-ſtick! As if you weren't • ble to ſlip your Neck out o • the Collar, when • ou pleaſe; you may clear all by making a full diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Well come on then, let Bacchis be brought over then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That's very well.— Here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: to Phyrgia entring. I faith this Rogue's impudent Pretences have brought me hither to a fair purpoſe; in hopes of the Thirty Guinea's he promiſed me: And if he fools me now, he ſhall • awn and cringe, till his Heart ake for me, to come hither again, and I'll not do't: Or elſe I'll • ake an Aſſignation. and appoint a time (which he'll be ſure to tell his Maſter of;) and when Ciitipho's Mind is big with expectation, I'll baffle 'em and not come at all; and then Syrus's Back ſhall •• undly ſmart for't.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p:
overhearing. She promiſes very fair, Sy
••• .

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye think ſhe's in jeſt, Sir? She'll as fairly ourform it, if I don't look to my hits.

sp.speaker: Bac
sp.p:
to Phrygia They're in a dead Sleep ſure; 〈◊〉 l • ll rouſe 'em with a vengeance.— Hark ye,
•• rygia, did you take notice of Charine's Houſe which the Man ſhew'd us juſt now?

sp.speaker: Phr.
sp.p: I did Madam.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
'Tis the very next Houſe on the Right
• and. Phr. I remember it.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p:
Hie you thither, full ſpeed: For the Captain is juſt now with Charine at
• acchus's Feaſt.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What a Devil's to do now? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Tell him I'm here ſore againſt my will, and am kept by force: But I'll have a trick to get rid of 'em, and come to him ſtrait. Phrygia going off.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: S death! I'm at my laſt Prayers Aſide. Stay Madam, ſtay, Where are you ſending her, I beſeech ye? Call her back.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: to Phrygia. Get you gone, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The Guineas are juſt ready, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Then I'll ſtay. Phrygia returns.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You ſhall receive em in a minute.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: As you pleaſe for that: D'ye ſee me in ſuch haſte for 'em?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, do you know, what you are to do?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You muſt juſt ſtep over to Menedeme's, and all your Train muſt go too

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Ye impudent Dog, what d'ye mean? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: To coyn Money for your Ladiſhip's uſe?

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: D'ye think me a fit Perſon to play upon thus?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, I'm in earneſt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Have I any buſineſs with you there?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, Madam, but there I'll pay you the Money.

sp.speaker: Bac.
sp.p: Let's be going then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Come this way, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ex.
sp.p: Bacchis led out by Clinie, and Phrygia.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Soho, Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Bring over all Bacchis's Servants to your Houſe quickly.

sp.speaker: D • o.
sp.p: Why ſo tho?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Don't ſtand to ask Queſtions, let em carry all their Baggage with em too: The old Gentleman will think his Charge is leſſen'd as ſoon as his Houſe is clear o • th Lumber: Faith he little thinks he ſhall pay ſawee for't at the long run: And you, Dromo, if you have any Wit, take not the leaſt notice of what you know.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You'll ſay, I'm a perfect Mute.

p.stage: Exit Dromo, and preſently re-enters with Bacchis's Servants, and their Luggage, croſſing the Stage.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to himſelf. As I'm a Sinner, I can't but pity my poor Neighbour's Caſe, to ſee him under ſuch great Misfortunes, as to be forc'd to maintain this Creature, with all her Family at her back. I'm ſatisfied he won't feel much for a Week or ſo, 'cauſe of his longing deſire to ſee his Son. But when he once comes to find ſuch a vaſt Charge to continue daily, and that there will be no end on't, he'll wiſh his Boy at the furtheſt Indies.— Oh, here is Syrus very ſeaſonably.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Why don't I board him? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ha! Sir!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What makes ye ſo merry?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I've wiſh'd for ye this half hour.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I fancy you ve been tampering with the old Gentleman about ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You mean that which we diſcours'd of juſt now— No ſooner ſaid, but done.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: In good earneſt?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, in good earneſt.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Faith I can't forbear ſtroaking thee. Come hither ye little Rogue, I ll remember thee for this: E'dad I will.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, if you knew how prettily it jump'd into my Brain.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pho! D ye pride your ſelf 'cauſe of your good Luck?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Troth, not I: I only ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: L •• hear t then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Clinie has told his Father that Bacchis is your Son's Miſtreſs: and that he brought her thither only to caſt a Miſt before your E • es.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Very well!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pray tell me what ye think on't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Twas admirable, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: aſide. Ay, if you knew all— But mark what Plot's behind.— Then Clinie tells him he has ſeen your Daughter, is much taken with her, and has a Mind to marry her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What ſhe that we ve juſt found to be ours?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.— And he'll deſire his Father to get your conſent.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why ſo, Syrus? I don't underſtand any reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pſhaw! you're ſo dull of Apprehenſion.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: His Father is to give him Money for the Wedding, to— you take me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To buy him a Wedding-ſuit, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Right, right.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But I'll neither give him my Daughter, nor my Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, Sir? Why not?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why not, ſay ye? D'ye think I'll marry her to a—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: As you pleaſe for that; I didn't ſay you ſhou'd let him have her for good and all; but only pretend it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I hate ſuch Pretences.— Plot as you pleaſe, ſo as you don't make me one of the Plot. Shall I promiſe to give my Daughter when I don't intend to do any ſuch thing?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I was in hopes you might.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Not a bit on't.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Introth it might ha' been done cleverly; I had ne're undertook it, hadn't you urg'd me to't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I grant it.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But however, Sir, my Intentions were good.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I d ha' ye by all means do your beſt to cheat Menedeme, but then I d ha' ye go another way to work.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: So I will, Sir, we'll find out one.— But for the Money I told ye your Daughter owes to Bacchis, that muſt be paid down upo' th' Nail. Neither will you (I preſume) ſhift it off by ſaying, What is t to me? Did ſhe lend me the Money? Was't done by my Orders? What had ſhe to do pawn my Daughter, without my conſent? As for that, the old Saying s true, You may have much Law o' your ſide, and but little Equity.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ll ha' none of theſe ſhifts.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Tho' others may do't, yet 'twon't look well in you, for the whole Town counts you a rich Man, and very well to paſs i'th' World.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well then I ll go, and pay the Money my ſelf,

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You d better order your Son to do that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Becauſe he now goes under the Name of her Gallant. Chr. What of all that?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Why if he carry't himſelf, the thing will look as if it had ſomething of truth in't: And by that means I ſhall the more dexterouſly bring about my own deſign too— Oh, yonder's the Man, you'd beſt ſtep in and fetch the Money.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: So I will. Exit Chremes.

p.stage: Enter Clitipho at another part of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p:
to himſelf. There's nothing ſo eaſie, but it becomes hard to an unwilling mind. This very walk I have taken, tho but a little one, yet how faint t has made me. And now, I dread nothing ſo much as to be ſent on another Fool's Errand, and not ſuffer'd to come nigh my dear Bacchis.— to Syrus. Now all the Gods confound thee for a Rogue, and all th • fine Tricks and Inventions!— Thou art always framing ſome damn'd V • llany to plague me 〈◊〉
Angrily.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
Keep • ur Curſes to your ſelf (if you go to that) I'm 〈…〉 Ill-nature had liked to
have brought my Neck to a Halter. Huſſingly.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: O' my Soul, I wiſh it had! I'm ſure 'twas no more than you deſerv'd.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Than I deſerv'd.— How ſo pray? I'm glad I know ſo much of your Mind before ye receiv'd the Money I juſt got ready for ye.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What cou'd I ha' ſaid leſs t'ye? You went and brought my Miſtreſs hither, and then not ſuffer me to come nigh her.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Well, I ha' done, I'm cool again.— But can you gueſs where your Miſtreſs is?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Why at our Houſe?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No but ſhe isn't.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Where then pray?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: At Mr. Clinie • s.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: All's gone.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Courage, Sir: You your ſelf ſhall go to her with the Money promis'd her preſently.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Thou prateſt like a Fool; Where ſhou'd I ha't?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: From your own Daddy.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: You only banter me. Smilingly.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You'll ſoon ſee that.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Nay then I'm made for ever, Syrus!— Dear Rogue, let me buſs thee.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: 'St! there comes your Father.— Have a care you don't play the Fool, and make a wonderment at the Matter; obſerve the Motion; do as you're bid, and ask no Queſtions.

p.stage: Enter Chremes with a bag of Money.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Where's this Clitipho now?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Say, here Sir— Aſide to Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Here he is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Syrus. Ha' you told him the Buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Moſt of it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Clitipho. Here take this Money, and carry it to her.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Zookers: Why d'ye ſtand like a Poſt? Why don't ye take it? [Aſide to Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Giv't me if you pleaſe. Chremes gives him the Money.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Follow me as faſt as you can.— To Clitipho.— But you, Sir, be pleas'd to ſtay here a minute till we come back, for we ve no occaſion to ſtay long there. To Chremes.

sp.speaker: Chremes
sp.p: So my Daughter has got Thirty good Pounds of me already, which account goes for her Board. I ſuppoſe the other Thirty muſt follow for fine Cloaths. After this comes a round Sum for a Portion. Well! This ſame Cuſtom is the Devil. Now muſt I leave all Works to find ſome honeſt Fellow to eaſe me of that Money I've been ſo long ſcraping together.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: to Clinie within. Dear Child, now do I think my ſelf the happieſt Father i'th' World, ſince I find you ſo well reform • d.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: overhearing. How ſweetly he's miſtaken. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Chremes! 'twas you I wanted.— Now, Sir, you may be the making of my Son, my ſelf, and Family; and I beg you'd do't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Good Sir, What wou'd ye ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It ſeems you have found out a Daughter to day.— My Son Clinie deſires your Conſent to marry her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What a ſtrange Man are you?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ha' ye ſo ſoon forgot the Trick we talk'd of juſt now, which was to be play'd to chouſe you of your Money?—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: — Why this is it they're now at work upon.—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What is't you ſay Chremes?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: — I ll warrant ye, this ſame Bacchis at your Houſe is my Son's Miſtreſs too; Is ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: They ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And you believe it?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yes, that I do.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Then they pretend that your Son has a Mind to be married: So that when I've promis'd him my Daughter, you may let him ha' Money to buy Wedding-Cloaths and the like.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: That's the buſineſs then, he wants it for his Miſtreſs. Chr. No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Alas unhapp • Man! My Joys are nipt i'th' bud: And yet I'd rather endure any thing than part with him again.— What anſwer, Sir, ſhall I carry from ye, that he mayn't perceive I've found it out or lay it to Heart?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: To Heart ſay ye?— Pſhaw! Menedeme you cocker him too much by half.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let it be ſo: I'm gone too far to draw back:— I beg, Sir, but the continuance of your Favours.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You may tell him we met and treated of the Match;—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Well, and what more?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: — That I'm ready to do any thing: that I like him for a Son-in-Law: And laſtly, if you pleaſe you may tell him I've given my Conſent.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Oh that's it I'd have.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That he may ask ye for the Money the ſooner, and you the ſooner part with it according to your Wiſh.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: That's what I aim at.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Introth, by what I can ſee, you'll quickly be cloy'd with this Son of yours; but as the Caſe
ſtands, if you've your Wits about ye, you muſt give it him very cautiouſly, and little by little.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: So I will.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You had beſt go in and ſee how much he'd have, I ſhall be at home, if you want me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: 'Tis that I'd have, for whate're I do I ſhall make you acquainted with. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Menedeme
sp.p: FOr my part, I muſt own my ſelf to be ſomewhat ſilly, and ſlow of Apprehenſion: But my Neighbour here, this ſame Aſſiſtant, Counſellor, and ſage Direct •• o mine out-does me a bar and a half.
