All the honourable Titles of a Fool, Blockhead, Clod-pate, Aſs, and Dolt, may well enough be appl'd to me; but they won't come up to him: for his Folly is beyond all Expreſſion.

p.stage: Enter Chremes at another part of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Soſtrata within. P • ithee Wife don't tire out the Gods with being ſo unmannerly overthankful for having found out your Daughter, unleſs you meaſure them by your ſelf, and fancy they can t underſtand a thing without hearing it a hundred times over— to himſelf But i'th' mean time, what a-duce makes Clitipho and Syrus ſtay ſo long at Mendeme • s.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Who are thoſe that ſtay ſo long, Chremes?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Hah; Mr. Menedeme are you got hither again?— Well, Sir, did ye tell your Son what I ſaid?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Every Syllable, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And what ſays he to't?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He was as much tranſported, as if he had a mind to be married.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ha,— ha,— he.—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What d'ye laugh at?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: My Man Syrus's Trick came juſt into my Mind. Men. Indeed?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This cunning Rogue has a knack of ſetting other Peoples Faces as well as his own.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You mean my Son only counterfeits his Joy. Chr. Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This very buſineſs came in my Head too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah he's a pickled Rogue. Laughs.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You'd ſay ſo indeed if you knew all. Jeeringly

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Say ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me the hearing.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But hold.— Firſt, I deſire to know how much you've thrown away upon 'em: For as ſoon as you told your Son I had promis'd him my Daughter, immediately Dromo, I'll warrant ye, clapped in a Word, that the Bride wanted Wedding Cloaths, Jewels, Attendants, and the like, that you might give 'em Money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How! not a word. In a maze.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nor your Son neither.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a tittle, Sir, but was only very urgent to ha the match ſtruck up to day.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You amaze me.— But what did my Man, did he ſay nothing too?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nothing at all.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How ſo, I beſeech ye!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Nay, I can't tell.— But I admire that
you ſhou'd ſee other things ſo well, and not this.— Pſhaw! 'Tis only Syrus has ſet your Son's Face too ſo admirably well, that no Man could ſuſpect in the leaſt this Bacchis to be my Boy's Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How's that!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'll not ſay a word o' their kiſſing and clipping: for I reckon that nothing.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What more cou'd be done to carry on the Counterfeit? Men. Piſh!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What is't, I beſeech ye?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Well, obſerve then.— I've a little withdrawing Room at the back part of my Houſe; where a Bed was brought in and made up.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What followed?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What?— Why thither went Clitipho.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: All alone? Men. Yes alone.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: My Mind miſgives me ſtrangely Aſide.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Immediately after him went Bacchis

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: All alone too. Men. Ay, all alone too

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'm ruined.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: As ſoon as they were in, they made faſt the Door.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How!— Was your Son a Looker on all the while.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why not? He and I ſaw it together.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, Menedeme, ſhe's certainly my Son's Whore then. I am abſolutely undone.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I ha' ſcarce where withal to keep Houſe for ten days.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What! Are ye concerned that he ſhou'd help his Friend a little?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No, but for fear he ſhou'd keephis ſhe Friend.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yes, if he ſhou'd indeed.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: D'ye queſtion that?— D'ye know any one of ſuch a baſe and poor Spirit, as to ſuffer his own Miſtreſs before his Face to be.— Men.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ha— ha— he. Why not? That I might the eaſier be impoſed upon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: D'ye jeer me, Sir?— Now what reaſon have I to curſe my own Stupidity? How many ſigns ha they given me to diſcover the Cheat, hadn't I been a down-right Stock? what things have I been an Eye-witneſs to? Fool that I am!— But as I'm a living Soul they ſhan't go off Scotfree: for immediately I'll— In a Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: interrupting. Ha' ye no Government? Ha' ye no regard to your ſelf? Methinks my Example might be of uſe t'ye.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: My Anger quite diſtracts me Menedeme.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: That you ſhou'd ſay ſuch a word now. Isn't that a great failing in you to adviſe others, and be ſo wi • e abroad, and yet can't help your ſelf at home?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What courſe ſhall I take?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The ſame which you ſaid I was ſo defective in— Make him ſenſible that you are his Father, that he may venture to truſt all his Secrets, wants and deſires with you alone, leſt he ſeek his redreſs elſewhere, and cry, Good bw'ye Father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ay, let him be jogging to Jericho for me, rather than here by his Debaucheries bring his poor Father to a Cruſt. For, Menedeme, if I go on thus to ſupply all his Extravagances, I ſhall quickly come to your Hedging and Ditching.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What a great many Troubles will ye pull down upo' your Head, if you don't look about ye: you'll ſhew your ſelf a rigid Father, and pardon him at laſt, when he won't give ye one good word for your pains.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! You can't conceive how much it goes to the Heart of me

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
VVhat you pleaſe for that.— But what
ſay ye to my propoſal? will you marry your Daughter to my Son? or ha' ye another in your Eye, that you like better?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: No; I like him for a Son-in-law, and I like the Alliance too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What Money ſhall I tell him you'll give with her?— What no anſwer?—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: pauſing. Money ſay ye? Shakes his Head.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! Sighing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Come Chremes, don't trouble your ſelf, tho' it be but a little; Portion ſhall break no Squares.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I deſign'd her indeed no more than Three hundred Pounds, being all my Eſtate wou'd bear: But if you tender the Welfare of me, my Eſtate, and Son, you may tell him I've promis'd to give all I'm worth for a Portion.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What Project are ye framing now?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You may pretend to wonder at it, and ask him too why I did it.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And ſo I may, for I can't conceive, why you ſhou'd do it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No?— Why to curb, and cool his Couage, now ſolely bent to Luxury, and Debauchery, and bring him to that paſs, that he ſhan't know where to turn himſelf.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me ha' my Humour in this thing.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Well!— But wou'd ye have me do ſo indeed?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Then I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well, Sir, let your Son get ready, and ſend for his Bride. As for mine I'll rattle him to ſome Tune, as Fathers ſhou'd do their Children.— But for that Dog Syrus.—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: VVhat will ye do to him?

p.stage: Whilſt Chremes ſpeaks the next Exit Menedeme.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: VVhat? If I live, I'll ſo lace his Jacket, and curry his Hide for him, that he ſhall remember • t as long as he has an hour to breath:— Damn'd Rogue, to think to make a Laughingſtock and May-game o' me; I'll be hang'd if the Raſcal dare ha' ſerv'd a poor friendleſs VVidow ſo, as he has ſerv'd me. Walks about in a huff.

p.stage: Re-enters Menedeme with Clitipho, and Syrus following after.

sp.speaker: Clit
sp.p: to Menedeme entring. I beſeech ye Mr. Menedeme, is't come to that then? that my Father ſhou'd ſo ſuddenly caſt off all natural Affection? For what Offence? VVhat grievous Crime have I miſerable Fellow committed? I do but what all • oung Perſons commonly do.

sp.speaker: Men
sp.p: to Clitipho. I'm ſenſible this is moſt hard and ſevere to you that bear the burden of it: but I my ſelf reſent it no leſs than you, tho' I know not why, and can give ye no reaſon for't, but only my extraordinary kindneſs for ye.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Didn't ye ſay my Father was hard by?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Yes, there he walks. Exit Menedeme.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
VVhat d'ye blame me for Clitipho? what I ha' done was to cure thee, and th • raſhneſs too: when I ſaw you of that ſluggiſh Nature, and were all for the preſent Enjo • ment, without conſidering the Future; I then took a Method to ſecure you from want, and my Eſtate from ruine. And ſeeing I cou'dn't make ye m •
• ei • , as by Nature I ought, I had recourſe to your higheſt Relations, making over and truſting all • o their Hands. There you'll ever find Sanctuary for you • Miſcarriages, meet with Diet, Cloaths, and a Houſe to hide. your head in.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: VVoe's me!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This is better than by making you my Heir, to let Bacchis run away with all.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'm undone! VVhat a Storm has my Rogueſhip raiſed before I was a ware— Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: VVou'd to God I were dead!

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Pray learn firſt what 'tis to live, when you've try'd that and don't like it, then die if you will.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Good Sir, will you hear me one word.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Speak then.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: But may I freely, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Speak I ſay.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: VVhat Injuſtice and Madneſs is it, that he ſhou'd be puniſh'd for my Offence,—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis done; don't you meddle nor make. No body impeaches you Syrus; therefore you needn't look out for a Sanctuary, or one to plead for ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, what's your deſign?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'm neither angry with you nor him, nor ought you to be ſo with me for what I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: He's flung away.— Pox! wou'd I had ask'd him.— Clit. VVhat Syrus?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: — VVhere I ſhou'd ha' had my Bellytimber, ſince he has turn'd us out of doors,— You it ſeems may mump it at your Siſters.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Am I reduc'd to this then, that I muſt ſtarve for want of Bread?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: However whilſt there's Life there's hopes.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: — Of a good coming Stomach.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Are ye ſo gameſome in time of Adverſity? And not give me one puſh at this dead lift?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I'm ready for't, and was hammering on't all the time your Father was Schooling of ye— And as far as I can perceive.—

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Prithee what?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: pawſing. You ſhall ha't preſently.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Pray what is't?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The Caſe is thus: For my part, I don't believe you are any of their Son.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: 'How's that Syrus? Art mad? Haſtily.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'll tell ye my Reaſons, judge of 'em as you pleaſe.— VVhilſt they had none but you, and you alone were all their Joy, they then cocker'd you up, and gave ye any thing. But now they have found a Daughter, they've found an occaſion to ſend you packing.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: That ſeem's very probable.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye think he'd ha' been ſo damn'd mad for a Peccadillo elſe?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I can't think he wou'd.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: There's another buſineſs to be well conſider'd: All Mothers you know are Pleaders for their Sons Faults, and conſtantly take their parts againſt their Fathers: But here we ſee no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Very true, Faith; therefore good Boy, tell me what to do.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: E • en put it to 'em to reſolve ye that Scruple, and don't mince the Matter: If it be falſe you'll work upon their Affections: If true, you'll know your own Parents.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Your Counſel's good, I'll follow it.

sp.speaker: Syrus
sp.p:
E • gad this was a lucky Hit: for the leſs hope the Spark has, he'll much the ſooner make his Peace with his Father, and at his own Terms too.— Perhaps the Toy may take him i • th' Crown to tye himſelf to a Wife; but God-a-mercy to Goodman Jobber Knowles here. Strikes himſelf on the Head. What noiſe is that?— Oh, 'tis the old Man coming again.— I muſt ev'n ſeamper for't—
Conſidering what has been done, I wonder he didn't order me to be truſs'd up with a Whip-ſtitch before now.— I'll betake me to Mr. Menedeme's, and get him beg me off. I'll never truſt this old Fellow. Exit Syrus.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Introth, my dear Husband, if you ben't very cautious, you'll make the Boy do himſelf ſome miſchief. And I can't but admire how ſuch a Whim came into your Head.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You'll be a Woman ſtill! Can't I do any thing but you muſt thwart me preſently, Mrs. Impertinence?— Put the Caſe I ſhou'd ask ye what's amiſs in't, or upon what account 'twas done, you can't anſwer me. Therefore why do ye ſo confidently oppoſe me, ye old Fool?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Can't I anſwer ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you can, I'd rather grant that, than tell the Story a hundred times over.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What an unreaſonable thing 'tis to make me ſtand like Mum-chance at ſuch a time as this?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I don't make ye, ſpeak your Heart out, I'll do as I pleaſe for all that.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Will ye ſo?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes by Cockſnowns will I.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: You don't conſider the ill conſequence of it. He'll think himſelf a Foundling.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: A Foundling ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Indeed, dear Husband he will.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And you may ſo too.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Oh I beſeech ye, let them ſay ſo that hate 's moſt: Shall I ſay he's none of my Son, that is my Son?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What? Are • e afraid you can't make it ou • he's your Son whene're you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What becauſe he's ſo like my new found Daughter?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No, but becauſe he's ſo like you in Humours, which is a more convincing Argument by half: That way you'll eaſily prove him your own: For he reſem bles ye extreamly: There's ne're an ill quality in him, but you have the ſame: Beſides there's not another Woman upon God's Earth, that cou'd ha' had ſuch a Son— But here comes the Youth.— How gravely he looks. When you view him throughly, you'll know what he is.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Soſtrata. If ever there was a time, Mother, you took delight or pleaſure in calling me Son, I'd entreat ye to bring it to remembrance, and take pity upon a Wretch: who craves and deſires to know who are his Parents.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake dear Child, ne're ſo much as think you had your being from any but us Clit. I can't help it. Sighing.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: weeping Ah me! How cou'd ye find in your Heart to ask me ſuch a queſtion? As I hope for your Proſperity when we are dead and gone, you are mine, and his And look to't (if you've any kindneſs for your Mother) that I never hear ſuch a word from you again.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: And, Jackanapes, if you have any Reverence for your Father. Let me ſee any more of theſe Tricks, and you had better eat your Nails.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: What Tricks, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: If you muſt needs know, I'll tell ye. The Tricks of an • impertinent, idle, cheating, drinking, whori • g, con • uining Debauchee.— Believe what I ſay, and don't donbt but that I am your Father.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Does this come from a Fahter's Mouth?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
No! Tho' you had ſprung out o • my fertile Brain, as Pallas they ſay did from mighty Jove's,
I'd not endure my ſelf to be diſgraced by your lewd Tricks. Angrily.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: The Gods forbid that.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I know not what the Gods will do, but I'll do my endeavour to prevent the worſt.— to Clitipho. You look about for Parents, which you don't want, but not at all for what is moſt wanting, as how to obey your Parents, and to preſerve what they by Induſtry have got. How cou'd ye ha' th' impudence to cheat your Father, and bring before his Face your— I am aſhamed to, name the filthy Word before you Mother; tho you were not ſo to do the baſer Act.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Alaſs! How mad am I with my ſelf! How aſham'd of my ſelf! I can't ſo much as ſee which way to begin to pacifie him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: to himſelf entring. Introth, Chremes handles the poor young Gentleman too ſeverely, and too roughly; Therefore I'm come to make up the Breach again.— Oh, beſt of all; there they are.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Menedeme, Why isn't my Daughſent for to your Houſe? And the Writings drawn about the Portion we agreed upon?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: For God's ſake Husband never do that.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: kneeling. Dear Father! I beſeech ye to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray do, Mr. Chremes; let his Repentance win upon ye ſo far.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Shall I in my right Senſes part with my whole Eſtate to a Baggage.— I'll be twice advis'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: That we'll take care to prevent.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: ſtill kneeling. Sir, if you tender my Life, forgive me.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Come, come ſweet Husband do.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Prithee Mr. Chremes don't be ſo obſtinate.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What means all this?— Well, I perceive, I muſt not do what I deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Now you do like a worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But then upo this Condition, that he ſhall do as I ſhall think moſt proper for him.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, Sir, pray command me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'd ha' ye Marry.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: But Sir.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'll take no Excuſes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'll engage for him, he ſhall do't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But he himſelf ſays no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: My Caſe is deſperate. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What d'ye boggle for Clitipho?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nay let him e'en take his own way.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He ſhall do as you'd have him.
Soſt. Marriage is a Bug bear to Fools, but they that ha' try'd it find it a Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Clitipho
sp.p: to Chremes. Well, I'll obey your pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: to Clitipho. In good Faith my Boy I've a fine Girl in my Eye for thee, which you can't chooſe but be pleaſed with; 'tis our Neighbour Phanacrates's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: Pho! That Carrat-pated, Wall-eyed, Pimple-faced, Hook-noſed Creature? It goes againſt me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Loy ye now, how nice he's grown!— You may gueſs what his Mind has been moſ • upon

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: to Clitipho. I'll tell ye of another then

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: No need of that: Since I muſt marry, I've juſt one in m • own Eye, which I like very well.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: That's my good Boy!

sp.speaker: Clit
sp.p: Archonides's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: That's as well as I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: to Chremes. Now, Sir, I've one Favour to beg.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.p: To pardon Syrus all he has done for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Well, I will. Turns to the Spectators.
Gentlemen,
Fare ye well, and give us your approbation.

div.trailer: The End of the Self-Tormenter.

div.p: THE BROTHERS. A COMEDY, Acted at the Funeral-Games of L. Emilius Paulus. WHEN Q. Fabius Maximus, and P. Cornelius the African were Curule Edil's, By the Company of L. Attilius of Preneſte, and Minucius Protimus.
Flaccu's made free by Claudius, Compos'd the Mu ••• , which was perform'd on Tyrian FLUTES.
It was taken from the GREEK of Menander;
And ACTED Under the Conſulſhip of L. Anicius, and M. Cornelius.
A. U. C. 583. Ante Chriſt 168.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Micio, A Rich Citizen of Athens, a mild, ſweet-natur'd old Gentleman, and a Batchelour; extream loving and kind to his Nephews Eſchine and Cteſipho; the firſt of which he adopts for his own.
Demea, His Brother, Father to Eſchine and Cteſipho, a Countrey Gentleman, and a violent, angry, fretful, buſie, medling Fellow; ſtrict and ſevere to his Sons, and a great pretender to Education.

Eſchine, Demea's Eldeſt Son, adopted by Micio, and in Love with Pamphila; a wildiſh, looſe Spark of the Town, generous and free hearted, who by reaſon of Micio's Indulgence often runs into open Extravagancies.
Cteſipho, His Brother, as naturally vicious as the other, but for want of Incouragement is very fearful and ſecret, concealing all from his Father, whom he lives with in the Countrey.
Hegio, Soſtrata's Kinſman, a down-right, true-hearted, honeſt Athenian.
Syrus, Eſchine's Servant, a jubtle, inſinuating, ſh, ingenious Fe • low, bold and ſawcy, almoſt always bantering, impoſing and putting upon Demea.
Dromo, Another of Eſchine's Servants.
Ge • a, A very honeſt, true and faithful Servant of Soſtrata's.
S • nio, A Fooliſh Woman-Merchant, alias a Bawd.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Soſtrata, A decay'd old Gentlewoman of Athens.
Pamphila, Her Daughter, Debauch'd by Eſchine.
Gautha •• , Nurſe to Pamphila.

list.head: MUTES.
list.item: Parmeno, Storax, and other Servants of Micio's, t • e Muſick-Girl, Rabble, Attendants, &c.

div.p: Scene, ATHENS.
TIME, about Eight or Nine Hours

div.head: THE BROTHERS.
ACT I.
div.opener: SCENE, The Street before Micio's Door. TIME, Betimes in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Micio
sp.p: ſpeaks within Storax, I ſay!—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p:
entring. O! No News, I ſee, of Eſchine ſince laſt Night's Entertainment, nor of any of the Servants that went to bring him home.— VVell, 'tis true, as they ſay, if a Man be but out of the way, or outſtays his time a little, he's leſs concern'd at the Scolding and Suſpicions of a jealous VVife, than a fond Parent is for a Child upon the like occaſion For ſhe, if you don't come in at your Hour, takes it for granted, that you have pick'd up a Girl, or a Girl you; or elſe that you're at the Tavern, or
ſome other place of Diverſion, or ſo; however that you fare well, whate're becomes of the poor Soul at home. But for me now, what a VVorld of Thoughts, and what a rabble of Whimſies have I i' my Head, for this Boys lying out laſt Night? Leſt he ſhould be ſtarved with Cold, •• mbl'd into a Cellar, or ha' broke a Leg or an Arm.— Lord! That a Man ſhould ſet his Heart upon any thing, and make it dearer to him than himſelf. And upon the whole Matter, this Boy is none of my Son neither, but my Brother's, who is of a quite different Humour from me. For my part, I always choſe the quiet Life of the Town, to live at eaſe, and (what the Wits count a Happineſs) have never been troubled with a Wife. But my Brother o'th' other hand has always liv'd in the Country, pinching and taking a world of Pains; committed Matrimony, and was the Father of two Sons: The Eldeſt I have adopted, brought up, eſteem'd and lov'd as my own; I pleaſe my ſelf in him, the only Creature I dote upon. Then I do all I can • o make him think as well of me: I deny him nothing, let him ev'n do what he will himſelf, and don't think it fit upon every turn to make uſe o' my Authority. In ſhort, I ha' brought him to • his, that he'll conceal none of the Levities of his 〈◊〉 , which others ſo induſtriouſly hide from their Fathers. For he that won't ſtick to falſifie to his own Father, or will put upon him, will be •• ne to make bolder with other People. Twas always my Opinion, That 'tis much better to • eep Children in order by Shame and Generoſity of • nclination, than by Fear, My Brother and I can't agree in this Point, and my way of Breeding won't down with him. Ever and anon he comes open Mouth to me.— Why Micio! What d'ye m • an? Will ye be the Ruine of our Child? Why does
he whore? Why does he drink? Why d'ye maintain him in all this? You let him go too fine: You are extreamly ſilly in't. He's extreamly ſevere, ſay I, beyond all Right and Reaſon: And truly, in my Mind, that Man is very much out, that believes that Government purely by force ſhould have more Authority, and a better Foundation, than when 'tis accompanied with Tenderneſs and Reſpect. This is my Logick, and I argue thus. He that's compell'd by Threats to do his Duty, will be wary no longer than you've an Eye over him, but when he ſees he ſhan't be found out he'll ev'n follow his own Inclinations. But he that's govern'd by Love obeys moſt chearfully, ſtrives to make his due returns, and is the ſame whether you are preſent or abſent. 'Tis a Father's part to uſe his Child ſo as his own choice rather than outward conſtraint, ſhould put him upon doing well. Here lies the difference between a Father and a Maſter: and he that does otherwiſe, let him own that he underſtands not at all how to govern Children. ſeeing Demea at a diſtance. But isn't that the Gentleman I am diſcourſing of?— 'Tis he for certain.— He knits his B • ows, but I know not why. I believe he's upon the Railing pin, as he uſes to be.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Brother! You are welcome to Town.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh! Well met! You're the Man I want.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What makes you ſo off the Hooks?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is that a Queſtion for me? when we have got ſuch a hopeful Youth as Eſchine?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I ſaid, twou'd be ſo. Aſide. What has he done now pray?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
What has he done? He's aſham'd of nothing, afraid of no body, and looks upon himſelf to be a lawleſs Man. I have nothing to ſay to
old Stories, but what a prank has he juſt now plaid?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What's that I pray?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why? he has gone and forc'd open a Man's Door, broke into his Houſe, beat the Maſter and and all his Family moſt barbarouſly, left 'em for dead, and carry'd off a Wench he had a fancy for, by force of Arms. Every body cry d ſhame on't: What a world of People told me on't, as I came along! Nay, the whole Town rings on't. To ſay no more, if he wou'd but take Example, does he not ſee how cloſely his Brother minds his his buſineſs, lives ſparingly and ſoberly in the Country? He wou'dn't do ſuch a thing for the World. But, Brother, in blaming Eſchine, I blame you too, tis you have been the ſpoiling of him.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: There's nothing more unreaſonable than a Man unacquainted with the World; that thinks nothing well done, but what he does himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why that pray?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: 'Cauſe you take things much otherwiſe than ye ought. Believe me Brother, 'tis no ſuch mighty buſineſs for a young Fellow to wench and drink a little: No, nor • et to break a Door: If you and I were leſs extravagant, twasn't for want of Will, but Money: And you count that your Vertue, which is only owing to Neceſſity; which is not fairly done. For had we had where-withal, we ſhou'd ha' been as wild as others: And had you but common Senſe, you wou'd give that fine Son of yours the ſame liberty, whilſt he's young: rather than he ſhou'd, when your Bones are laid (which he has often pray'd for) take the ſame wild Courſes at an Age, when they will leſs become him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Sbud! You're enough to diſtract one! Then, be like there's no harm in a young Man to live at this mad rate!

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Patience, good Brother! Prithee don't deafen my Ears with old Stories. You gave me your Son, and by Adoption he's mine; if he be extravagant, I ſhall bear the blame on't, and pay for't over and above. He treats, he drinks, he dreſſes! 'Tis all at my Charge. He keeps a Miſs too! I'll ſupply his Pocket as long as I'm able, and when that fails, perhaps they'll turn him out. Has he broke any Doors? They ſhall be made good. Torn any Cloaths? They ſhall be mended too. I thank my Stars I've where-withal to do it, and as yet not uneaſie under it. In ſhort! Either leave off complaining, or chooſe who you will be judg'd by: and I'll make't appear, that you're more to blame than I.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! Learn to be a Father by them that are ſo indeed.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: You are his Father by Nature, but I have the care of him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, ſpecial care! Scornfully,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Nay, if you're at that Sport, I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will ye ſo?—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVhat ſhou'd I ſtay for to hear the ſame thing a thouſand times over.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis only from my concern for him.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: And I'm concern'd for him too; but, good Brother, let's each concern our ſelves as we ought; you for one, and I for t • other: For you to take care of both, looks as if you revok'd that grant which made him mine.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ah! Brother. Shakes his Head.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I'll have it thus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVill ye ſo?— VVell, if that's your reſolution: Let him ſquander all, damn all, himſelf and all, tis all one to me. If ever I • ſpeak a Syllable more.—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Now you begin to be angry again.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Don't ye think there's reaſon for't. Do I deſire to ha' your rare Son from ye? It grieves me, I muſt confeſs, for he's my own Fleſh and Blood ſtill. If I oppoſe, I ſhall— But I ha' done. You'd ha' me take care of one, and ſo I will. Heavens be prais'd, he proves after my own Heart. Your Profligate will feel the ſmart on't at laſt.— VVell! But I won't be too hard upon him. Exit Demea.

sp.speaker: Micio
sp.p: I believe part of what he ſaid is true, but not all: And truly I'm a little mov'd at it, though I wou'dn't ſhow my ſelf concern'd before him: For He's ſuch a ſtrange Man, that to pacifie him you muſt cr • ſs, and out-hector him, though then he can ſcarce contain himſelf. But ſhou'd I chafe him, and blow the Coal, I ſhou'd ev'n be a Madman for Company. Yet I muſt confeſs my EſchiM has been a kind of a naughty Boy in this buſineſs What Courteſan has not he viſited? Or what pretty Face has not he preſented ſome Toy or other to? In fine, not long ago (ſick I thought of theſe Creatures) he told me he wou'd take up and marry. I was in hopes the Heats of his Youth had been abated, and was heartily glad on't: When on a ſudden a new Fires broke out. But I'll know't whate're the Matter is, and go ſee whether I can meet with my Gentleman at the Change.

div.trailer: End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.

p.stage: Enter Eſchine with a Sword drawn leading in the Muſick-Girl, and attended by Parmeno and Storax, after comes Sannio, running with the Rabble at his Heels.

sp.speaker: S • n.
sp.p: as out of Breath. HElp— good Neighbours,— I beſeech ye • Help— a— miſerable, innocent— helpleſs Creature.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to the Girl. Stand your ground my pretty Rogue, and don't be afraid. Why doſt thou look behind thee? There's no danger at all: And while I'm by, let him touch thee if he dare.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'll have her again, in ſpight of the World.—

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Tho' he's a very Raſcal, yet he ſhan't provoke me to give him another beating to day.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Hark ye, Sir, that you mightn't pretend to be ignorant of my Profeſſion, I tell ye I'm a Woman-Merchant.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: A Cock-Bawd you mean.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: And one of the greateſt Repute in Town. And don't you fancy now that you ſhall get off by ſaying, 'Twas againſt my will that you were abus'd: By the Lord Harry, I value it not a Straw. Aſſure your ſelf, I'll trounce ye to ſome Tune; your fine Words ſhall never make amends for the Blows you gave me. I know theſe will be your Tricks and Excuſes. I'm extreamly ſorry for't, I'll take my Oath you did not deſerve this uſage. When the truth on't is, I've been us'd worſe than a Dog.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to Parmeno. Run quickly before, Sirrah, and open the Door.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: You had as good ſtay where you are.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to the Girl. Step in quickly with him, my dear Rogue.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: ſtepping between. But I forbid that tho.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Come hither Parmeno.— You are too far.— Stand cloſe to that Son of a Whore.— So, that's well. Take care to keep your Eye full upon mine, that when I tip the wink, you may be ready to give him a ſlap in the Face.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'd fain ſee that. Eſchine gives the Girl to Parmeno, which Sannio ſeeing, runs & catches hold of her.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Have a care, Parmeno. Parmeno ſtrikes him.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to Sannio. Dog! Let go your hold.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh, monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: You ſhall ha the ſecond part o'th' ſame Tune, if you han't a care. Parmeno ſtrikes him.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to Parmeno. Hold, you go beyond your Commiſſion. But better too much, than too little.— You may march off now you've got your black and blue Livery, Mr. Sannio!

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? Do you reign Lord and Maſter here?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: If I did, I'd reward your Bawdſhip according to your deſerts.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Pray what Authority have you over me?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: None perhaps.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: How! D'ye know who I am, Sir?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Nor yet deſire it.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Did I meddle with any thing of yours pra?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: If you had, Sirrah, it ſhou'd ha' been a dear meddling.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Then how comes it to be more lawful for • ou to take my Goods, which I honeſtly bought • nd paid for? Anſwer me that pray.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: You hadn't beſt ſtand bawling at this rate • efore the Door; if ye plague us any more, I'll ha' •• dragg'd in, and whipp'd as long as ye can ſtand.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Bleſs me! Free-born, and whipp'd!

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: That's your Doom.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh the Wickedneſs of the Man! Is this the eneral Freedom they talk of, with a Pox?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p:
Worthy Mr. Pimp! If your mad Fit's • ver, hear me a word, if your Honour's ſo diſ
• os'd.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Was't I that was mad, or you?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Let that paſs, now come to the point.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What point? Whither ſhall I come?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Will ye give me leave to ſpeak about your • uſineſs?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: With all my heart, provided it be juſt.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p:
Heigh toſs! The Bawd's turn'd Puritan,
• nd wou'd teach me Juſtice.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Tho' I am a Bawd, the common bane of • outh, a forſworn Wretch, a publick Nuſance; • et I never did you any wrong, Sir?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: That's kept for an after-clap.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Eſchine, return to your firſt • ropoſal.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: The Girl coſt ye about Fifty Guineas, may •• never thrive with ye! The Money ſhall be paid • e again.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What if I won't part with her, who a plague ſhall force me? Will you? Eſch. No.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I was afraid you wou'd.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p:
Truly, Friend Sannio, between you and •• , ſhe's not to be ſold at all; for ſhe's a Gentlewoman, and ſo I'll prove her to be. Now, Block
• ead, chooſe whether you'll take the Money, or
try it out at Law.— Chew upon this, till co • back, worthy Mr. Pimpwell.
Exit Eſchi •

sp.speaker: Sanni •
sp.p:
alone. Heavens! Now I don't won • to ſee a Man's Brains turned by Oppreſſion. T • Son of Thunder has raviſhed me out of my Caſ • beat me to Mumm, took a Girl from me vi armis, and given poor Sanny above Five hund • Baſtinadoes. After this ſweet uſage he'd ha' ſurrender up my Right and Title to her witho •• Intereſt. Faith he ſhall have her indeed, ſince deſerves her ſo well, and requires nothing •• what's juſt.— Studies. Well I wiſh it mi •• be ſo, ſo he pays me down the Ready.— B • my Mind miſgives me, damnably, that whene • I do but ſet the Price, he'll preſently bring W •
neſſes to ſwear 'twas a direct Bargain between Then for my Money I may go whilſtle for't, He ſay, Come again an hour hence, to Morrow. Th • I can bear too, ſo I may be ſure on't at laſt, th • it be ſome damage to me.— 'Twill be ſo, ſure as a Gun. Since Friend Sanny thou haſt take up ſuch a naſty Trade, thou muſt be content bear and Pocket up the Affronts of ſuch hectori • Gallants. But ſince no body's here to pay •• I do reckon my Chickens before they are ha •••

p.stage: Enter Syrus at a little diſtance.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
to Eſchine within. Huſh! Not a w •• more, I'll go to him my ſelf, and make him sk • at the Money, and ſay, He's rarely well dealt by, •
[Goes at Sannio.] What's the News with yo • Mr. Sannio? I hear my Maſter and you have ha' kind of a Scuffle.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: ſhrugging. A Scuffle d'ye call • t; Never •• like ſurely! We were both ſufficiently tir'd: • with beating me, and I with being beaten.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You may thank your ſelf for't.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: How cou'd I help it?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You ſhou'd ha'born with the young Genman's Humour a little.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What cou'd I do more? I'm ſure I bore the blows upon my Face, he was pleas'd to • e me

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Well, dye know what I'm going to ſay? balk an Ace ſometimes is the beſt play.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Heigh ho!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You are ſo timorous like a ſenſeleſs Sot: •• w if you had parted with a little of your Right, •• humour'd the Gentleman, you'd ha' got the • vil and all at the long run.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I don't love to buy a Pig in a Bag.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ah, thou wilt ne're be worth any thing. •• t upon ye, as if you hadn't a Spring to catch • oodcocks.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I believe that might be the beſt way, but • ad never the Grace to follow it, nor to refuſe •• Ready, when I cou'd get it.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Go to, I know your generous Spirit: As • ugh you regarded half a hundred Gu • nea's, ſo •• cou'd ſerve my Maſter b •• : Beſides they ſay, • u re making a Voyage to Cyprus.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: And have bought up ſeveral Commodities Tranſport thither; the Veſſel's hi • ed: I know • ur Mind's a little wavering about this Money, •• en you come back I hope to ſee an end of the •• ineſs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I've no Voyage to make.— Faith I'm adone! Tis upon this they have built their Plot.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The Fellows upon th' fret, I've put a Flea • his • ar. Aſide.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p:
to himſelf. Oh horrid! See how he has •• ked me in the Critical mi •• te! When I've juſt 'd in a Stock of Fema •• , • nd other wares to
carry to Cyprus. If I loſe my Fair it will ha' break me: And if I leave this buſineſs at ſix an • ſevens, the time will be over when I come back. There'll be no Remedy, and I ſhall have a plagu • cold Welcome. Are you come now, they'll ſay,
•• proſecute? Why did ye let it run ſo long? Where h •• ye been all this while? So that I had better lo • every croſs on't, than tarry ſo long before I ſu • for't?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Clapping him on the Shoulders. Well! Ha • been caſting up all the Gains of this Voyage?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Is this like a Gentleman? Is this Mr. Eſ •• chine's Conſcience to take away a Girl by mai • force?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: aſide. He ſinks a main.— I've one thin • more to propoſe, ſee if you like it. Come, compound for half, rather than run a hazard of ſavin • or loſing all; we'll make a hard ſhift but we' • ſcrape up about five and twenty Guinea's ſome where or other.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Oh miſerable! Now poor I am in dange • of loſing part o'th' very Principal. Is he pa •• all ſhame? He has beat all my Teeth down my Throat; and my Head into an an entire Gelly • Then he'd trick me o'th' Money into the Bargain.— I have no Voyage to make.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That's as you pleaſe.— Ha' ye any further Commands.— I'm going.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Ay, pray good Mr. Syrus, however thing • ha' been, rather than ſue and quarrel, let him pa • me my own: at leaſt what ſhe coſt me. I know • ye little Rogue, you never had occaſion, as yet • to make uſe of me as a Friend: But if you ſhou'd • you'll ſay I'm no forgetful or ungrateful Perſon.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
I'll do my beſt.— Oh, yonder come •
Cteſipho, I faith as brisk as as a Body-louſe for hi • Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Well, will ye do as I deſired ye?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Have a little Patience.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: to himſelf. When a Man ſtands in need of a good turn, he's glad to receive it from any hand. But it does him a double pleaſure, when it comes from one he has reaſon to expect it from. Oh, Brother, Brother! How do I adore thee now! This I'm ſure of, that the very beſt Words I can give thee are ſhort of thy deſerts. And I am happy in this particular beyond all Mortals. that I've the moſt accompliſhed Brother in nature.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Cteſipho!

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Dear Rogue Syrus, where's my Brother?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Look ye, he's at home waiting for ye.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Oh brave!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What's the Matetr, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: The Matter old Boy? I ſhou'd ha' been cold in my Grave, but for his means.— Ah, he's an honeſt Soul! he neglected his own Intereſt to ſerve mine. He has taken upon himſelf all the Curſes, Scandals, Love-Matters and Miſcarriages that belong to me; And what cou'd he do more? But who comes there? What makes the Door go?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay, here he comes himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Where's the Scoundrel Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Does he want me? Has he got any Money? I'm broke: the Devil a Penny do I ſee.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Hah! This is lucky, 'twas you I was wiſhing for— Well, how is't? All's well; off with that ſowre Look.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Now I have reaſon, having ſuch a Brother as you O Eſchine! My true Brother indeed! I dare not praiſe ye any more before your Face, leſt you ſhou'd think it proceeded rather from Flattery than Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Leave your fooling, as tho' we were meer Strangers to one another: But this troubles me that we cou'dn't know o'th' buſineſs ſooner; for the Matter was come to that paſs; that all the World cou'd ſcarce ha' help'd you, tho' they had deſired it. Cteſ. Modeſty hindered me.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Pſhaw! 'twas folly, notmodeſty. What! to be upon running your Country for ſo ſmall a Matter? Fie upon't: Heavens forbid that.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: 'Twasn't well I own.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to Syrus. What has Sannio concluded on? Syr. He's grown very tame.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: I'll to the Piazza and diſcharge him.— but do you brother ſtep in to your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Good Mr. Syrus, puſh on the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Let's be quick, Sir. For the Man's in haſte for Cyprus.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I'm in no ſuch haſte.— I've nothing to do, but to wait for the Money.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: You ſhall have it man, nver fear't.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: What all?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes all. Say no more about it but follow us. San. So I will.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: to Syrus going off. Hark ye Syrus.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Well, Sir your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Prithee ſee that paltry Raſcal diſpatch'd as ſoon as poſſible, leſt upon farther provocation the buſineſs come to my Father's Ears; then I ſhall be ruin'd to all Intents and Purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That ſhan't be: Take Heart Sir. Do you toy away half an hour or ſo with your Miſt • eſs, the mean time within. Order the Butler to lay the Cloth, and all things to be got ready. As ſoon as the buſineſs is over, I'll march home with plenty of Proviſions.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Prithee do: and ſince things have fallen out ſo luckily, let's e'en make a day on't.

div.trailer: The end of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: PRithee my good Nurſe, how is ſhe like to do?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: How! Troth I hope ſhe'll have a good time on't. Her Pains, my good Miſtreſs, are juſt beginning: You're as fearful now, as if y' had ne're been at a Labour, nor cryed out your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Alas-a-day! I've no body at home: and we are all alone. Our Man Geta's out o'th' way too; and there's never a Soul to ſend for the Midwife, or to call Eſchine.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Without doubt, Eſchine will be here anon: never a day goes over his Head, but we have his Company.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: He's the only Comfort I have in my Affliction.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: As the Caſe ſtands, Miſtreſs, the buſineſs cou'dn't fall into better hands: ſince ſhe had the miſchance by ſuch a Gentleman, of ſuch a Parentage, ſo generous, and ſo nobly deſcended.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: You're much in the right: Heavens keep him ours for ever.

p.stage: Enter Geta as out of Breath at a great diſtance.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
to himſelf. We are now brought to that paſs, that if all the World laid their Heads together,
to find out a remedy for this miſchief that has happen'd to my ſelf, my Miſtreſs and her Daughter, they cou'd do us no good.— Oh miſerable! Such a Flood of Difficulties o're whelm us, that tis impoſſible to keep above water. Raviſhment, Poverty, Oppreſſion, Deſertion, Infamy.— Is the Age ſo debauched?— Abominable Villains! Curſed Wretches! This Devil of a Man.—

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Bleſs me! What makes our Geta in ſuch a Fright, and in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf.— Whom nothing cou'd reſtrain or move: Neither Promiſes, Oaths, nor Pity, nor yet the approaching Travail of her he had ſo ſhamefully abus'd.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: I can't well underſtand what the Fellow ſays.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Pray, Miſtreſs, let's go a little nigher to him.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf Ah poor Geta! I'm ſcarce Compos mentis, my Paſſion has inflam'd me. I'd deſire nothing more than to meet the whole Family of em, that I might diſgorge my rage upon em, now my Blood's up. I'd be contented to ſuffer any thing, ſo I might have a ſwinging Revenge upon em. Firſt, I'd tread out that ſtinking Snuff his Father, that gave being to the viſe Raſcal. Then for that Dog Syrus, that put him upon't.— How I'd tear him piece-meal! I'd give him ſuch a toſs, daſh his Skull againſt the Stones, and ſtrew the Streets with his Brains. That Boy Eſchine too, I'd tear out his Eyes, and after that break his • eck.— The reſt I'd down with em, drive em, drag em, pound 'em, and trample em under m • Feet. But what makes me loiter, when I ſhould • e telling this damn'd News to my Miſtreſs. Go.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Let's call him back.— Why, Geta! ing off.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Piſh, prithee don't trouble me, whoſoever you are.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: 'Tis your Miſtreſs calls.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ay, where is ſhe?— turning about. I was hunting for you, Miſtreſs, 'twas you I look'd for.— You've met me as luckily as may be.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What's the Matter? Why doſt pant ſo?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Why in ſuch haſte my poor Boy? Come take Breath.—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: We are abſolutely—

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What abſolutely?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: — Undone— paſt all recovery.—

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: For Heavens ſake, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Juſt now.—

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What juſt now, Geta?—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: This Mr. Eſchine.—

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: — Has quite— thrown off our Family.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Alas! Undone indeed! But how ſo?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He's run mad after another Face.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Wretch that I am!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He didn't do things in the dark, but forc'd her from a Bawd in the Eyes of the World.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Are you ſure of this?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Moſt ſure, theſe very Eyes ſaw it.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: weeping. Oh unfortunate Soſtrata! what canſt thou truſt to? Or whom canſt thou truſt? Our dear Eſchine do this; The very Soul of us all; in whom we plac'd our Hopes and Happineſs? How oft he ſwore he wou'dn't live a day without his Pamphila? And ſaid, he'd put the Infant on his Father's Knees, and in that ſort beg his leave to marry her.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
Pray, Miſtreſs, forbear weeping, but rather conſider what's fit to be done: whether we
ſhou'd put up the Affront, or tell it to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Hold, hold Man; Haſt loſt thy Senſes? D'ye think this a buſineſs fit to be blaz'd abroad?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Nay, I'm for huſhing of it againſt the World. Firſt, The Caſe is plain, he has left us for good and all: Now if we make it publick, ten to one but he'll diſown it, then your Reputation, and your Daughter's Honour will be call'd in queſtion. But put the Caſe he confeſſeth all, 'twou'dn't be Prudence to give him your Daughter, whilſt he keeps another: Therefore take the thing which way you pleaſe, Concealment is my Opinion.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Ah, by no means: I'll not agree to • t.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What will ye do then?

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Divulge it.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: How! Have a ſpecial care, Miſtreſs, what you do.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: The Caſe can never be worſe than 'tis; For firſt, ſhe has no Portion; then ſhe's robb'd of that which might ha' went inſtead of one; ſo that ſhe can't be put off for a Maid. I have one ſhift left, if he deny't, the Ring he loſt is proof enough. In fine, ſince my own Conſcience tells me, that this miſhap can't be charg'd either to my Covetouſneſs, or to any baſe Ends that I or my Daughter had in't, we'll ev'n venture a Tryal at Law.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: D'ye think ſo? Pray, think on't again.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Do you, Geta, make all the haſte you can to her Couſin Hegeos, and tell him the whole Story: for he was a choice Friend of my poor Husbands, and had always a great kindneſs for our Family.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ay faith, there's no body elſe looks upon us.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Good Canthara, do you run, and call the Mi • wife, that ſhe may be i'th way if need be. exeunt ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Undone, undone! They ſay my Boy Cteſipho made one with his Brother at the Rape: That he ſhou'd be able to debauch a Lad of his Sobriety is the only thing that cou'd add to my Misfortunes.— Where ſhall I ſearch for him? I'm afraid they've carried him to ſome Bawdyhouſe or other. The Rake-hell his Brother has drawn him in. I'm confident.— But yonder comes Syrus, I'll learn of him where he is. But i'faith he's one of their gang, and if he perceives I want him, the Rogue will never tell me any thing; therefore he ſhan't know my deſign.

p.stage: Enter Syrus at another part of the Stage, very merry.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf We've been telling the whole Exploit to the old Gentleman, and how • twas carried on: I never ſaw the old Man ſo tickled inmy whole Life.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: over-hearing. Bleſs me! What a Coxcomb's my Brother?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf. He commended his Son, and thank'd my Worſhip for adviſing of him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I can't hold any longer. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf. He told out the Money forthwith; and gave us a broad Piece overplus to be merry withal, and e • ded 'twas employ'd even as I'd have it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hah! If you'd have any thing done as it ſhou'd be, commend me to this Gentleman. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: ſtarting. Ha, Mr. Demea, I didn't ſee ye. How does your Worſhip?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How?— I can't but wonder at your fine way of living.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
Faith, Sir, tis pretty Silly, and, to ſpeak the truth, ſomewhat oddiſh— Turning to Micio's Houſe. You Dromo, gut and ſcale the reſt of o'th Fiſh, but the great Conger-Eel let him play in the Water a
little; when I come back, we'll bone him, and not before.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Are theſe ſcandalous Villanies to be allow'd of?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Demea. Truly, Sir, I don't like 'em at all, and do often cry out,— to him within. Stephanio, ſee that the Salt-fiſh be well water'd.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Does he do this on purpoſe, or does he think 'twill be for his Credit to ruine his Son? What a ſad Creature am I! Methinks I have the day before my Eyes when this Boy will be forc'd for want of bread to run his Country, and liſt himſelf a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! There's Wiſdom now! to ſee things at a diſtance, and not only what's juſt before ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, have ye got the f • ddling Wench at your Houſe?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: She's there within.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: The Devil! ſurely ſhe's not to dwell there?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I believe, they're mad enough to ha't ſo.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ah the foppiſh Fondneſs and pernicious eaſineſs of a Father!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: In good truth, I'm aſham'd, and heartily griev'd, for my Brother.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: There's too much; Ay, a great deal too much difference, Sir, between you two (tho' I ſhou'dn't ſay ſo much before your Face) you, Sir, as much as there's o'ye, are Wiſdom all over: but he's a meer Gimcrack. Wou'd you ha' ſuffer'd your Son to ha' done thus!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Suffer'd him? Zooks! I ſhou'd ha' ſmel • him out ſix whole Months, before he had been concern'd in ſuch a buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ah Sir, you need not tell me what a wary Man you are.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Heavens grant he may continue, as he i • .

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Children prove as their Father's make 'em.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But hark ye Syrus, Prithee didſt ſee him to day? Fawning •• .

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
Mr. Cteſipho, Sir! (I'll ſend the old Foo •• packing into the Country) Aſide. He's gone into the Country, and hard at work by this time▪
to Demea.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Are you ſure he's there?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Sure? Why I ſaw him out o'Town my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That's well. I was afraid he had loiter'd hereabout ſtill.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: And was in a plaguy Huff too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: At what prithee?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: He fell out with his Brother i'th' open Market about the Muſick Wench.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'faith he ſpoke his Mind freely; for when we were paying the Money, in drops he unawares upon the back on's: and ſets up an outery; Arn't ye aſham'd Brot • er Eſchine to commit ſuch Villanies? That you ſhou'd diſhonour our Family at this vile rate?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: E'dad he makes me weep for Joy.

p.hi: You don't only weaken your Eſtate, but your Reputation too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Heavens bleſs him! I hope he will never • degenerate.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Who queſtions it?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: O Syrus, he poor Boy has his head full of theſe Morals.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: And well he may, when he has ſuch a Father at home to fill it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I do my beſt, and leave no Stone unturn • d, but exerciſe him in all that's good. Above all I charge him, Look into Mens Actions as into a Glaſ • , and take Example by 'em. Practice this, ſay I.—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Very well indeed.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Shrew • d.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: There you hit it again.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That won't be allow'd at all.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Moſt admirable.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: interrupting. Your Pardon, Sir, I am n't at leiſure for your Moreovers: I've got an excellent Diſh of Fiſh to my Tooth, and I muſt take ſpecial care that the • ben't ſpoil'd: For that is as ſcandalous a buſineſs among us, Sir, as the neglect of your Duty is among them. And according to my Abilities I give my fellow Servants Inſtructions after the ſelf-ſame manner. This is too Salt (Say I • ) That's too much, this isn't done cleanly enough; that's well done, pray remember to do ſo another time. I inſtruct 'em diligently, as well as my Palate will ſerve me. Laſt of all too, I bid them 'em look into their Diſhes as into a Glaſs, and there learn their Duty. I confeſs theſe are all meer Toys: but what ſignifies that? We muſt ſuit our Morals to the Perſons we deal with.— Pleaſe to command me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, to get a little more Wit among ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye deſign for the Country, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, to rights.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ay, what ſhould you do here, Sir, where all your good Morals are but thrown away?

Ay, truly, I'll to my Country-Farm, ſince he that brought me hither is gone back again.— That Boy's all my care, he's my true Son; ſince my Brother will have his own way, let him look to that Rake-hell.— But who comes yonder at a diſtance? Mr. Hegio, one of our own Ward?—
If my Eyes don't fail me, 'tis he indeed. Ah, we've been Cronies from our Cradles. By Jove, ſuch honeſt Citizens are very ſcarce now a-days! A Man • o'th' right old Stamp for Vertue and Fidelity, and wou'dn't do the Government any harm for the World. How glad am I to ſee the remains of the old Stock! Ah, Life is a Pleaſure to me now. I'll wait for him here, and bid him Good-morrow, and have a little diſcourſe with him.

p.stage: Enter Hegio and Geta at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Ye Powers! A diſhonourable Action! What is it you ſay, Geta? Hah!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Juſt as I told ye.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: That ever that Family ſhould be guilty of ſuch an ungenteel thing. Oh, Eſchine! You didn't learn this of your Father, I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: overhearing. Yes, he has heard of this ſinging Wench too, and it nearly touches him tho a Stranger: but his ſweet Father takes no notice on't. Oh diſmal! Wou'd he was but by a little that he might hear all theſe Complaints.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: If they won't give ſatisfaction, they muſtn't think to carry it off thus.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: We all rely upon you, Sir: We ha' none elſe to ſtand by us: You are our Guardian, and Father too. The old Gentleman upon his Deathbed bequeathed us all to your Care, and if you forſake us, we're utterly undone.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: No more of that: I'll not forſake ye, nor can I do't with a ſafe Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll to him.— Honeſt Hegio, I'm heartily glad to ſee ye.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Demca, I'm your humble Servant, you are the Man I wanted.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Why your Eldeſt Son Eſchine, whom your Brother has adopted, has done neither like an honeſt Man, nor a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: You knew one Simulus, a Friend and Cotemporary of ours.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Why, he has debauch'd his Daughter?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh! Sigh • .

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, the worſt is to come yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What more Miſchief ſtill?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Yes, truly; for that was, in ſome meaſure excuſable. He had Opportunity, Heat, Wine, and Youth to prompt him to't; 'twas but a humane Frailty. But when he was ſenſible of his Fault, he comes forthwith to her Mother, weeping, praying, intreating, promiſing and ſwearing he'd take her home and marry her: Upon this all was pardon'd, huſh'd and rely'd upon. The young Woman prov'd with Child upon this; has gone her Forty Weeks. But this ſweet Youth is got to a Ballad-ſinger, in the Devil's Name, keeps her at his Fathers, and has left the t'other to ſhift for her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is all this true are you ſure?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: The Mother is ready to prove it, the young Woman and the Buſineſs ſpeaks it ſelf: Beſides, here's Geta, as Servants are now, none of the worſt, a painful Fellow, who maintains 'em all, and keeps the whole Family himſelf; take him, bind him, force the Truth out of him.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Yes, verily Sir, rack me to death, if all ben't true: Beſides Mr. Eſchine himſelf won't deny it, pray, Sir, bring us Face to Face.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'm horribly aſham'd, and can't imagine what to do, or what anſwer to make him.

sp.speaker: Pamphila
sp.p: within. Oh me! I'm torn in pieces,— Help ye Powers above, and eaſe me for Heaven's ſake.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: to Geta. Hah! Prithee was that ſhe that cry'd out?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Without doubt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Demea, ſhe calls upon your Honour now; and begs ye to do that freely, which the Law wou'd elſe oblige ye to. I beg Heaven to inſpire ye to do as you ought; but if you are otherwiſe minded, Mr. Demea, I'll maintain her and her dead Father's Cauſe to the laſt Penny in my Purſe. He was my Kinſman, we were bred up Children together, we were together at Wars abroad, and Peace at home, and together we under-went the ſtraits of Poverty: Therefore I'll about it, do my utmoſt, and bring it to a Tryal, and rather loſe my Life than deſert theſe poor Women.— VVhat anſwer will ye return?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll go talk with my Brother, Sir; what Advice he gives, that I'll follow.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: But, Mr. Demea, do but conſider with your ſelf, that the more you live at Eaſe, the more Powerful, the more Rich, the more Happy, and the more Noble you are, ſo much the more Honeſt and Juſt ought you to be, if you'd be thought Men of Honour.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Away! No more, you ſhall have all Right and Juſtice done you.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Spoken like a worthy Gentleman.— Geta, bring me to your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Demea
sp.p: This was no more than I foretold. I wiſh to my Soul this was the laſt mad Prank! But this allowance of ſo much Liberty will end at laſt in ſo me ſad Story or other.— Well I'll go hunt for my Brother, and diſcharge this News in his very Face. Exit Demea.

p.stage: At the ſame time re-enters Hegio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p:
to Soſtrata within. Chear up, good Coz, ANd comfort your Child's poor heart as much aS
you can. I'll go diſcourſe Mr. Micio, if he be at the Piazza, and let him know how the Caſe ſtands; if he deſigns to do us right, well and good; If not, let him declare it plainly; that I may know how to take my Meaſures accordingly. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: entring.— MY Father gone into the Country ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Above an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Prithee tell me true.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: He's at his Grainge, ſlaving himſelf moſt horribly by this time, I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Faith, if it might not endanger his health, •• cou'd wiſh heartily he might be ſo miſerably tir'd, as to be laid up theſe three days.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: So ſay I: and a longer time too, if poſſible.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Ay, ay: for I'd very fain, now I've begun the day merrily, make an end of it merrily too▪ The only Quarrel I have with our Countty-houſe is, that tis too, nigh the Town: Were it farther • ff, before he could get thither and back again, ' • would be Night firſt. But now when he finds no Cteſipho at home, I'm ſure he'll be upo' th' ſpur back again in an inſtant. Then to Catechiſ • ng he goes: Pray where ha' you been, Sir? What? Can't a Man have a glimps of ye, in a whole day's • ime? What excuſe. ſhall I have?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Han't ye got one ready?

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: The Devil a one have I.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: So much the worſe: Why if you had but, one of your Domeſticks, a Friend, or a gueſt, that were better than no body yet.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: I have, what then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pretend you had haſty buſineſs to diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: What when I had none?— 'Twon't do.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: 'Twill tho.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Ay for the day: but if I lie out all Night, what excuſe then Syrus?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: 'Tis pity it is not more the Faſhion to ſerve a Friend in the Nights as well as day.— But however, ſet your heart at reſt; I know your Father's humour to a hair. VVhen he rages like a Lyon, I can preſently make him as quiet as a Lamb.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: As how, I prithee?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh, he's mightily tickled when any body commends you: I make ye a very Saint before▪ him, and reckon up all your vertuous Qualities.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Mine?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ay, yours: Then of a ſuddain the good Man cries like a little Child, for Joy.— Look to your ſelf there.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: ſtarting. VVhat d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Talk o'th' Devil and his Horns appear▪

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Is't my Father?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Prithee, Syrus, what ſhall we do now?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Run in quickly, I'll ſet my VVits to work.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: If he ask for me, ſay you han't ſeen me, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Can ye hold your Tongue?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
to himſelf. I'm the unluckieſt Creature •• at ever was born▪ In the firſt place, my Brother is not to be found above Ground: Then as I was
looking for him, who ſhould I ſee but a VVorkman juſt come from my Country-houſe, and ſays my Boy isn't there neither. Nor can I tell for my Life what courſe to ſteer.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Does he enquire for me?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Yes, Faith.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Come, don't be diſcourag'd.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. How great is this my Miſfortune! I can't ſufficiently underſtand it, unleſs I was predeſtinated to be miſerable. Is there any miſchief happens to our Family, to be ſure I'm the firſt that am ſenſible on't, the firſt that knows it, the firſt that reports it, and the only Man that feels the weight when it falls.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith I can't but laugh at him, to hear him ſay, that he's the firſt that knows every thing, when he's the only Man that knows nothing. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'll ev'n go again to ſee if my Brother be come back.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Prithee, good Syrus, take care he don't break in upon us unawares.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Peace I ſay, I'll take care about it.

sp.speaker: Cteſ.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, but I ſhan't truſt my Concerns in your hands to day: For I'll ſecure my Girl and my ſelf in ſome by Cloſet or other; E'dad that will be the ſureſt way by half. Cteſipho retires.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Away! I'll clear the Coaſt of him in a trice Syr. moves towards Demea ſhrugging his Shoulders, and ſnivelling.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh, there's the Hell-hound, Syrus.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to him ſelf. If this Trade laſt long, there'll be no enduring the Houſe. I'd fain know of their Worſhips how many Maſters I am to have; what a damnable thing is this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What a yelping this Cur makes? What does he ail?— What ſay you honeſt Man? Is my Brother at home? Hah!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Pox o'your honeſt Men, I'm a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: The Matter with a plague? Your ſober ſtay'd Son Cteſipho has almoſt beaten poor me and the Muſick Girl to death.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhat's that you ſay? Hah!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: See how he has ſlit my Lip up to my Noſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How comes this to paſs?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: He ſays, I was the occaſion o'the buying of her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Didn't you juſt now tell me, he was gone into the Country, and you brought him part o'th' way.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: True, Sir. But after that he came raving like a Mad-man, ſparing never a Mothers Son of us. He might ha' been aſham'd to fall upon the Bones of a poor old Man, who t'other day dandled him in my Arms, when he was no higher than this. Shews how high.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ha— ha— he— God-a-mercy Cteſipho: Old Demea right. Well! thou'rt a Man every Inch of thee.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye commend him? but i'faith he had beſt keep his flippant Fingers to himſelf another time, if he underſtands himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis bravely done!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Very bravely indeed! To Cock-crow over a ſilly Woman, and a poor Servant, that daren't hold up a Finger againſt him?— Yes, 'twas wonderful brave i'faith.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He cou'dn't ha' done better. He's o' my Opinion in thinking you to be the Ring-leader of this Roguery.— But is my Brother within?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, he's abroad.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'm thinking where a-duce I may look for him.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I know where he's gone, but ſhan't tell till to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What's that you ſay, Sirrah? hah!

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Juſt ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll crack your Skull preſently ye Dog.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: bantering. I know not the Man's Name where he is; but the Place I do.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Then tell me the place, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: ſtill bantering. Do you know the great Portico, that overlooks the Butcher-row as you go down there?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVell, what then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: ſtill bantering. Go ſtrait along this Street up there. pointing with his Fingers. When you are got there, you'll find on this hand a Deſcent, make a civil ſtep down there. After that you'll ſee a little Chappel on that hand, and hard by that a little narrow Lane.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhereabouts is that?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: There, where the great wild Fig-tree ſtands, d'ye know it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Keep directly through that.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But that narrow Lane is no Thorow-fare.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ud • s my Life 'tis true: I ſee I'm a ſilly Block-head, I was out. You muſt come back again to the great Protico: E • dad here's a nigher way, and eaſier to hit on. D'ye know my Lord Cratine's great houſe?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: When you are paſt that, turn to the Lefthand down the ſame Street: and when you're come to the Temple turn to the Right-hand: before you come to the Cit • Gates hard by the H • rſepond, there's a certain Mill, right over-againſt that is a Joyner's Shop, and there you'll find the G • ntleman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhat buſineſs has he there?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: To ſpeak for little Oaken-ledg'd Tables to ſet in the Sun.—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: For your VVorſhips to drink about— Fine work I faith. But why amn't I gone to him?

sp.speaker: Syrus
sp.p: Go thy ways for a Fool: I'll work thee off thy Stumps, as thou deſerveſt, thou old doting Chu • l.— But Mr. Eſchine ſta • s a bloody while: Dinner will be quite ſpoil'd: As for C •• ſipho hes wholly taken up with his Miſtreſs: but I ••• take care of my own ſweet Corps; and will pi •• out all the good Bits I can f •• d, take off my Cups of my leiſure, and ſo make the day as long as I can. Exit Syrus.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: entring.— Indeed, Mr. Hegio, I can ſee nothing i'th' whole buſineſs that deſerves ſuch mighty Commendations. I diſcharge but my Duty, and give ſatisfaction for the Faults of my own houſe: Perhaps you took me to be one of thoſe Men that think they receive an Injury when they do't themſelves, and ſo call Whore firſt: Now 'cauſe I didn't ſerve you ſo, d'ye think your ſelf oblig'd to me for't?

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Far be it from me! I never imagin'd ye to be otherwiſe than I really find ye: but let me engage ye ſo far as to ſtep over with me to the Girl's Mother; and tell her the very ſame you told me: that their Jealouſie was falſe grounded, and that he took away the Muſick Girl for his Brother.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: If you think it convenient and neceſſary let's be going.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p:
You do well, Sir! For you'll lighten the poor creature's heart that's ready to ſink with Grief and Vexation, and keep up the character
of a worthy Gentlemen. But, Sir, if you don't think it ſo proper, I'll tell her what you ſay my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No, no, I'll go with ye.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: You oblige me, Sir: For howſoever it comes about, all that are a little down in the world are very ſuſpicious; take every thing at the worſt hand, and fancy themſelves ſlighted, cauſe of their Misfortunes: Therefore twill give great ſatisfaction to clear Mr. Eſchine your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: You ſay nothing but what's tru • e and reaſonable.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Be pleas'd, Sir, to come this way.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I will.

p.stage: Exeunt Hegio and Micio at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Eſchine
sp.p:
Enter alone. I'm quite diſtracted! That I ſhou'd be ſo ſurpriz'd with this unlucky Misfortune, that I know not what to do or undertake! Fear enfeebles my Limbs, Amazement ſhakes my Soul, and my Heart's uncapable of Advice. Alas! how ſhall I wind my ſelf out of theſe Incumbrances, ſince their Jealouſies are ſeemingly wellgrounded? Mrs. Soſtrata believes I bought the M • ſick Girl for my ſelf: Old Canthara gave me to underſtand as much. For by chance I ſaw her as ſhe was going for the Midwife, I preſently made up to her, and ask'd her how my dear Pamphila did, whether ſhe was near her time; and whether ſhe was then going for the Mid-wife? She preſently let flye upon me. In another Tone. Away, away Mr. Eſchine; you've befool'd us long enough, you've cajol'd us ſufficiently with your fine Promiſes. Alack-a-day (ſaid I) prithee what doſt mean? You may go now (continued ſhe) and take up with the Girl you are ſo enamour'd with. I immediately perceiv'd their Jealouſie: But yet I kept my Tongue between my Teeth, that I might not blab out any o' my Brother's Secrets to that tattling Gipſie,
to have it • laz'd about the Town in an inſtant— But what ſhall I do now? Shall I go and ſay ſhe's my Brother's? A thing that ought not ought not to be reveal'd for the World.— Well! Let that paſs, perhaps they won't diſcover it. Then I am afraid they wont take things as they are, there are ſo many Probabilities againſt me. Twas I,u ſelf that took her away, I my ſelf that paid the Money for her, and twas I that furniſh'd her with Lodgings. I muſt own the Fault of all this lies at my door: For not telling my Father how Caſes ſtood between me and my Miſtreſs; and not begging his Conſent to take her home and marry her. We • ve been in a dead ſleep till now, but now Eſchine rouſe thy ſelf up. Firſt of all I'll go to'em and clear my ſelf.— I'll up to the Door ſtrait. Goes and ſteps ſhort. Oh my heart! how ſadly it pants whenſoever I knock at this Door Goes and knocks. Soho! 'Tis your Friend Eſchine; ſome body open the Door quickly.— But, ha'! I can't imagine who comes out there?— I'll ſtep a one ſide.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: to Soſtrata within. Do as I order'd ye Mrs. Soſtrata, I'll find out Efchine to acquaiut him how Matters are carried on.— But where's he that knock'd at the Door?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: S'death! My Father's Voice! I'm at a curſed Nonplus. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: What buſineſs has he here? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Waſt you that knock'd at the door?— He's mute: Suppoſe I ſhould banter with him a little, I believe 'twou'dn't be amiſs, ſince he'd never truſt me with this Secret.— Aſide,

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What can't ye ſpeak? To Eſchine.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: I didn't knock as I know of.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Indeed? Nay, I wonder'd what buſineſs ſhou'd bring you hither. He bluſhes: that's ſign good enough Aſide.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Good, Sir, (if I may be ſo bold) what buſineſs had you at that Houſe?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: None o' my own. A Friend o' mine brought me from the Change to be his Spokesman in a Concern of his.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: VVhat was the Concern, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: •• l tell ye: In this Houſe dwells an ordinary VVoman or two; which I ſuppoſe •• u don't know, •• , I'm ſure you don't; for they han't liv'd long in theſe parts.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: VVell, Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Here's an old VVoman and her Daughter.—

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: — The Daughter has buried her Father: Now this Friend o' mine is the neareſt Relation, and by Law is forc'd to marry her himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Undone! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: partly hearing. What's • he Matter?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Nothing, very well.— Proceed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: You muſt know he's juſt now come to take her away with him: For he dwells at Miletus.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: How! To take the Girl away with him?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: What as far as Miletus, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Eſch
sp.p: aſide. It ſtabs me to the Heart.— And the Women, Sir, what ſay they to't.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What ſhould they, think ye? Ev'n juſt nothing: Only the Mother pretends her Daughter has a Child by another Man (I can't tell who, for ſhe nam'd him not) that he was the firſt comer, therefore the Kinſman muſt go without her.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: So, Sir: And wasn't that a ſufficient Demurrer?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Why ſo, I beſeech ye? Will he take her away in good earneſt?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Ay, why ſhou'dn't he?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, this was extream ſevere and cruel, (if I might take the Liberty) I might ſay ungenreely done.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: How ſo? What d'ye think will become o'th' poor young Man her firſt Lover (who for ought you know loves her moſt deſperately) when he ſhall ſee her raviſh'd before his Face, and hurried away from his ſight for ever? Oh, 'twas a very diſhonourable thing of you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why d'ye talk at this rate? Whoſe Promiſe had he? Or whoſe Conſent? When, and how were they married? Pray who's the Man? What made him encroach upon another Man's Right?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Was it fit for a Girl of her age to ſit croſs-legg'd at home waiting for a Kinſman's coming the Lord knows when? Indeed, dear Father, you ought in Juſtice to have alledg'd that, and ha defended it.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Very good! Shou'd I ha' pleaded againſt my own Client?— but prithee Boy, what's all this to us? Or what ha' we to do with them?— Come let's be going— How now Boy! why in tears tho? Eſchine weeps.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Hear me one word, Sir, I beſeech ye.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Poor Boy! I've heard and know all: For loving thee I cou'dn't but be concern'd in whate're thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Dear Sir! I'd fain deſerve your Love as long as you live. This Fault grieves me to the Soul; and I'm quite aſham'd to look you in the Face.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p:
I believe it ſincerely: For I well know
thy generous Temper: but I'm afraid you don't mind your own Concerns. What kind of Government is it that you think you live in? Thou haſt debauch'd a Girl, whom by Law thou oughteſt not to have touch'd; that's a great Fault, and tho' very great tis but a common failing: Others ha' done it often, and Men of Repute too. But when that was done, tell me, did you take the leaſt care about it? Or did you forecaſt in ſuch a caſe what ſhould ha' been done? Or how it ſhould ha' been done? And if thou hadſt been aſham'd to tell it me, cou'dn't I ha' know on't by others?
