In this you were in doubt of for ten Months together: So you have betray'd your ſelf, the poor young Woman, and your own Child too, as much as you were able. What? D'ye think that the God's ſhou'd do your work for ye, and you ſleep the while? Muſt ſhe be brought to your Bed-ſide, as if ſhe were not worth the fetching? I wou dn't ha' thee ſo miſerably careleſs in other things for the World.— Come don't be caſt down however, thou ſhalt marry her.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Don't be caſt down, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, are ye in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: In earneſt: Why not?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: That I can't tell, unleſs 'tis 'cauſe the more paſſionately I deſire to have it ſo, the more I'm afraid it won't be ſo.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Get thee home, and ſay your Prayers, and then ſend for your Wife, go, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: VVhat ſend for her preſently?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Yes, preſently.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: What preſently?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Preſently, as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Let me never ſee good day, Sir, if I don't love ye better than my very Eyes.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Than your Miſtreſs too?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Full as well.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: That's much, indeed.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: But what's become of the Miletian Spark?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: He's vaniſh'd, ſhipt off, and caſt away by this time.— But why don't ye go, I ſay to your Prayers.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: It wou'd be better for you to do that, S • ir. I'm ſure your Prayers will be heard ſooner than mine, ſince you are the better Man o' th' two.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I'll in, and take care of what's wanting. Do as I bid thee, if thou know • ſt what's beſt for thy ſelf. Exit Micio.

sp.speaker: Eſchine
sp.p: What Happineſs is this? wou'd any one think he's my Father, or I his Son? If he had been a Friend or a Brother cou'd he ha' been more kind or obliging! Ought I not to love him? To wear him next my Heart? His wonderful Complaiſance has oblig'd me to be ſo cautious, as imprudently to do nothing that may diſpleaſe him; wherefore I'll now be always upo' my Guard.— But why don't I go in, that I may not defer my Marriage! Exit Eſchine.

sp.speaker: Demea
sp.p: I'm quite foundered with trotting up and down.— A plague confound thee, Syrus, for thy damn'd Directions.— I've hobbl'd over the whole Town, been at the Gate, at the Horſe-pond, and where not? The Devil a Joyner's Shop cou'd I find; or any Soul that ſo much as ſaw my Brother.— But now, I'm reſolv'd I won't ſtir a ſtep out of his Houſe, till he comes back.

p.stage: Going off, and then enters Micio.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: entring. I'll go and tell 'em for our parts we are ready.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh, here he comes.— I've been looking for you theſe two hours.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What's the buſineſs now?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I've freſh News to tell ye: horrid Villanies of that fine Son of yours.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Look ye now. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: New Villanies, damnable Villanies!

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Prithee no more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ah, you don't know what a fine Blade he is.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: But I do.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Poor Simpleton! I warrant thou dreameſt I'm about the Singing-wench: No, the Raſcal has debauch'd a Citizen's Daughter.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: That I know too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Bleſs me! D'ye know it and ſuffer it too?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Ah, why ſhou'dn't I?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What? Methinks you ſhou'd bellow and run mad at it.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No: But I could wiſh it otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He has got a Baſtard too.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Heavens bleſs it, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And the Woman's not worth a Groat.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: So they ſay.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And ſhall he be married to a Beggar?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Yea verily.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, and what's to be done next pray?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why ev'n what ſhould be done next, have the young Woman brought home.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Monſtrous! And will ye ſuffer't?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: How can I avoid it?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Avoid it? Why, if you were not really concern'd at it, 'twou'd become ye to ſeem ſo however.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I've given conſent already: The buſineſs is concluded on: The Wedding's as good as over: Every thing is ſecure, and I think this becomes me better.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Then this Adventure pleaſes you wonderfully?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No, if I knew how to help it: ſince I can't, I muſt bear't patiently. Man's Life is like a Game at Tables, if you miſs the Caſt you've moſt need of, you muſt correct that by Skill which fell out by chance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your Servant, Mr. Corrector! Your Skill as you call it has fool'd away Fifty Guinea's upon a Ballad-ſinger; who in three or four days time muſt be pack'd off; if not for a Piece of Money, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: There's no body to buy her, nor do I deſign to ſell her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What a-duce will ye do with her then?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why keep her at home.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Mercy upon my Soul • l A Whore and a Wife under the ſame Roof?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why not, prithee?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And you are ſure you arn't mad?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Let me die, if e're I ſaw the like Folly • I'faith I believe thou thy ſelf haſt a mind to have a me • ry ſtrain with her now and then.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Why ſhou'dn't I?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And the Bride, won't ſhe be for learning the ſame Tune too?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And thou pretty Child wilt hobble out the Hay amongſt 'em too?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Like enough.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Like enough with a Pox?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: And rather than fail, Brother, thou ſhalt make one o' th' Company.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: S • death! Are ye paſt all ſhame?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p:
Prithee, Brother, throw off this ſullen Humour of thine, and like a civil Perſon be free
and merry at your Son's VVedding.— I'll juſt ſtep and ſpeak a word at that Houſe, and then I'll come back again. Exit to Soſtrata's.

sp.speaker: Demea
sp.p: Here's a ſweet Life! Here are fine Morals! Here's mad work with a witneſs!— Let me ſee, a Wife not worth a Groat; a Ballad-ſinger under the ſame Roof: Every thing running to riot i' th' Houſe: A profligate young Rogue, and a doting old Sot into the Bargain: Why Providence it ſelf, if it ſhou'd go about it, wou'd never be able to ſave this Family.

p.stage: Enter Syrus, at a diſtance almoſt Drunk.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to himſelf. Faith and troth my little Rogue Sy, thou haſt junketted thy pretty ſelf deliciouſly, and play'd thy part very ſumptuouſly. Go thy ways for a Wag.— ſtrokes himſelf. Since I've ſtuff'd my ſweet Corps with the Dainties within, 'tis my Honour's Pleaſure to take a turn i' th' freſh Air without. Walks and ſtruts.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: There goes a rare Model of their Education.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Oh here's our old Stingo i'faith— How is • t old Gentleman? Why ſo alamort?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh damn'd Raſcal.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: How now old Wiſdom, are you come to vent more Morals here? Belches.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Wou'd I were thy Maſter,—

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: E'gad you'd be the richeſt Man under the •• n, and your Eſtate would be improv'd to a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'd make thee an Example to all Rogues.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Why ſo? What have I done?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Done, Raſcal? In the heat of a diſturbance, • nd in the midſt of a moſt horrid crime, ſcarce yet •• tled, you've got drunk ye Swine, as if all were • ell and over.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Faith, wou'd I had kept my Poſt. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: D'ye hear Syrus? Mr. Cteſipho wou'd pray ye to come to him.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Away with a Pox. Softly. Exit Dromo.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What's that he ſaid of Cteſipho?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How ye Goal-bird! Is Cteſipho neſted there •

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: No, Sir; no.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How came the Boy to name him then?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: That's another of the Name, a young Smell feaſt; d'ye know him?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I will know preſently. Going off.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: holding him. What d'ye mean, Sir? Whither are ye going?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Dog, let me go.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I ſay, don't go.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hands off ye Hell-hound; or by Heavens I'll brain ye. He holds up his Cane, and Syrus let's go. Exit in a Fury.

sp.speaker: Syrus
sp.p: The Devil go with him: I'll be ſworn he'll be no welcome Reveller to any of them, eſpecially to poor Cteſipho.— Zookers! where ſhall I beſtow my ſelf?— The time this plaguy Storm is blowing over, I'll ev'n ſlink into ſome by-corner, and there ſleep out this Doſe of Tipple. I think that will be beſt. Exit ſtaggering.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Mie.
sp.p: to Soſtrata within. EVERY thing's ready with us, as I ſaid before: And the Wedding ſhall be when you pleaſe— Coming forward. But who's that makes our Doors fly ſo?

p.stage: Enter Domea from Micio's raving and in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. Hell and Furies! What ſhall I do?— What will become of me? Heavens, Earth, Seas! Whether am I to direct my Exclamations or Complaints?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Here's a Man for ye! He has ſmelt out the Intrigue, and that makes him bellow ſo.— 'Tis ſo, I muſt expect a ſmart bruſh: But the Boys muſt be help'd. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Oh here comes the common Bane and Ruine of our Children.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Pray Brother moderate your paſſion, and be a little cool.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, I am moderate; I am cool.— I'll not give ye an ill word. Let's reaſon the caſe calmly— Wasn't it a plain Bargain between us (and that of your own propoſing too) that you • hould ha' nothing to do with my Son, nor I with ye • rs? Anſwer me directly now.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: True; I don't deny it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
What makes him a guzzling at your Hou • e then? Why d'ye entertain my Child? Why 〈◊〉 procure him a Wench, Brother? Is there not the •• me reaſon for you to deal as fairly by me, as I do
by you? Since I neither meddle nor make with your Son, methinks you ſhou'dn't with mine.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: There's no reaſon for that: None at all. The old Proverb ſays, Among Friends all things are common.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Very pretty I faith! Are you come to talk at that rate at laſt?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p:
Good Brother, hear me a word if it be'nt too great trouble to ye. Firſt of all, if your Son's Charges are ſuch a woeful burden to ye, pray conſider a little with your ſelf, that formerly you maintain'd both of 'em according as your Eſtate would bear it; and thought it then ſufficient for both; looking upon me as likel • enough to marry: Why ev'n follow that old courſe ſtill, •• ard, ſcrape, pinch, do all you can to raiſe their Fortunes, and take the credit of it to your ſelf. But then let the poor Rogues make uſe of my Purſe freely, ſince that comes to 'em over and ••• ve— 'T won't diminith one Furrow of ••• Land, and what they have from me, you may look upon as clear Gains. Now, Brother, if you do but impartially weigh all this, you'd eaſe m •
• our ſelf, and the poor Boys, of a world of tr ••••

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I don't 〈…〉 Money, 'tis their Morals—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p:
Hol • , 〈…〉 . That's it I was going upon Many 〈…〉 may be made, Brother, upon 〈…〉 ſame thing; by which a Man ma concl ••• , 〈◊〉 be the ruine of the one, and no great hur • to the 〈◊〉 : Not that there's any difference in the thing, 〈…〉 the Perſons that did it. Truly, by what I 〈◊〉 the Boys, I'm confident they'll prove to our 〈◊〉 deſire: I find they have Wit, Diſcretion, and Modeſty enough upon occaſion, and love one another entirely: ſo that 'tis eaſie to perceive the •• gen •
rous
Nature and Spirit: You may reclaim 'em when you pleaſe: But perhaps you are afraid they aren't Husbands good enough. Ah, Brother, Age has always this ill Property with it; as i • makes us wiſer, ſo it makes us more worldly: And that will ſufficiently incite 'em to be good Husbands.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Have a care Brother, theſe your fine Reaſonings and gentle Nature don't ruine us all.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Peace, ne'r fear that: Lay aſide this Diſeaſe, and be rul'd by me to day:— Come, 〈◊〉 up your countenance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: more pleaſantly. Well, ſince things require •• , I muſt do ſo. But to morrow I'll into the Country with my Son by break of day,—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: At Midnight if you pleaſe, ſo you be but merry to day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: — And take that ſinging Wench along with me too.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Beſt of all; by that means you'll keep 〈◊〉 Son from rambling: Only take care ſhe don't 〈◊〉 ye the ſlip.

sp.speaker: D • m
sp.p: I'll warrant • ye.— And then between the Oven and the Mill, I'll ſo beſmear her with Cinders, Smoak and Meal.— Beſides in the heat of the day, I'll ſend her to rake up Stubble till ſhe be Sun-burnt, and as black as a Coal.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: That's excellent: Now methinks you have ſome Prudence in ye; and whilſt ſhe's in this curſed pickle, make your Son lie with her Nolens-Volens.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: D'ye rally? well, you are a happy Man, to bear things ſo well, for m • part I muſt—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: interrupting What always in the ſame ſtrain?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ha done, I ha done.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Pray walk in then, and ſince the Day's deſign'd for Mirth, let's as merrily ſpend it.

sp.speaker: Demea
sp.p:
Never did Man caſt up the buſineſs of his Life ſo exactly; but ſtill Experience, Years and Cuſtom will bring in ſome new particulars that he was not aware of, and ſhew his Ignorance of what he thought he knew, and after trial make him reject his former Opinions. This is plainly my caſe at preſent; for ſince my G • aſs is almoſt out, I renounce this rigid Life I have always led. But why ſo? Becauſe Experience ſ •• ws me there's nothing like gentleneſs and good nature: And this truth appears plainly to all that know me and my Brother. He always ſpent •• s time in Eaſe and P •••
ſure; always courteous, complaiſant, ſpeaking ill of no Man, but careſs'd all: liv'd as he plea • 'd, ſpent as he thought ſit, the World bleſs him, and love him too: But I, that ruſtick, rigid, mor • ſe, pinching, bruitiſh, griping Fellow, muſt need marry; and how have I ſmarted for't! I had C •••
dren too, thoſe were new Troubles: And truly, in raiſing up their Fortunes, I've worn out my Li • e and beſt Days; and now I'm juſt a marching •• the Stage, the Fruit of all my Labour is to be ••
ted like a Toad. But my Brother enjoys all 〈◊〉 Pleaſures of a Father without the drudgery; they love him, and flye me like the Plague. Him 〈◊〉 truſt with all their Secrets, dote upon him, l •• e with him, but me they ſlight: They both pray 〈◊〉 his Life, but long for my Death: Thoſe I have brought up with the greateſt Labour, he has g ••• d with a little Coſt; ſo I take all the Pains, and he reaps all the Pleaſure.— Well, well, for on • e we'll try what can be done, whether we can ſpe • k obligingly, and act the Gentleman too, ſince my Brother urges me to • t I'd willingly have my C •• ldren love and reſpect me too; if Gifts and Complements will do the Feat, I'll not be behind w •• h
beſt of 'em: but my Eſtate muſt go to wrack: What care I for that, ſince I've one Foot in the Grave already.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: D'ye hear, Sir, my Maſter deſires you wou'dn't be out o • th' way.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Who calls there?— Honeſt Syrus, I'm glad to ſee thee: How is't? How goes the World?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Very well, Sir. Yawning.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: aſide. Excellent! This is the firſt time Ie'r us'd theſe expreſſions, Honeſt Syrus, How is't? How goes the World? They came out plaguily againſt the grain.— To Syrus. Thou haſt ſhown thy ſelf an admirable Servant, and I will do thee a good turn with all my Soul, I fack I will.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I'm very much oblig'd to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I fack Boy 'tis true; and thou ſhalt find it ſo ere long.

p.stage: Enter Geta at another part of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Soſtrata within. I'll go find em, Madam, and haſten em to carry over my young Miſtreſs.— Coming from the Door. O here's Mr. Demea.— Your humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Prithee Lad what may I call thy Name?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Geta, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Honeſt Geta, why I look upon thee at preſent to be worth th' weight in Gold; I'd never deſire to be better ſatisfy'd in a Servant, than that he ſhould be as truſty to his Maſter, as I have found thee to be, Geta. For that reaſon, when it lies in my way, I'll do thee a good turn with all my Soul, I fack I will— I'm acting, Sir Courtly, and I do't rarely methinks. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That's more your Goodneſs than my Deſerts.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ſhall do't by degrees: Firſt of all I'll make theſe Scoundrels my own Aſide.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: to himſelf. Theſe delays kill me: That they ſhou'd trifle away the time with their formal Ceremonies, and tedious Preparations for the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Eſchine, Boy, How wags the World?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Hah! Are you here my dear Father?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, i'faith Boy, I am thy Father both by Inclination, and by Nature too, and tender thee more than my Eyes— But why doſtn't thou ſend for thy ſweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: I deſire nothing more; I only ſtay for the City-waits and Singing-men.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ho, Wilt thou take an old Fellow's Counſel for once?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Let's hear't pray, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hang your Songſters, your Hubbubs, Flambeaux and Scrapers: And order the great Stone Wall i'th' Garden to be pull'd down immediately, and convey her home that way: Run both Houſes into one, and bring over the Mother, and her whole Family to yours.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: With all my heart. The pleaſanteſt Father i'th' World!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: aſide. Hey brave! I'm call'd pleaſant now: My Brother's Houſe will be a Thorow-fare to all Comers, the whole Town will be there preſently: His Purſe muſt ſmoke for't, and to ſome Tune too. But what's that to me? whilſt by my complaiſance I oblige all. Aloud to Eſchine. Go bid Babylo tell out half a hundred Guinea's quick.— But, Syrus, why don't you do as you are bid?

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Break down the Wall.— And do you Geta go, and bring 'em hither.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ay, God bleſs your Worſhip for being ſo kind to our poor Family. Excunt Geta and Syrus.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis no leſs than you deſerve.— What ſay • ſt thou Boy, hah!

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: I'm o' your Opinion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Tis forty times better than bringing a Lying-in-Woman along the Streets.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir! I know nothing like it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: This is my way.— But here comes my Brother. Enter Micio.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: to Syrus within. My Brother order it, ſay ye?— Where is he? Ha, Brother, waſt you that order'd this?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, that I do: And in this, and all other things, I'm ready to do what may conduce to the uniting, ſerving, helping, and joyning both Families together.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let it be ſo. To Micio.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVell, I've nothing to ſay againſt it.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Troth 'tis no more than we are oblig'd to.— For firſt, ſhe's your Son's VVife's Mother.—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVhat then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: A very vertuous and modeſt Woman.—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: So they ſay indeed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pretty well in years.—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: She is ſo.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And paſt Child-bearing, a loneſome Woman, and no body regards her.—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVhat a-duce wou'd he be at? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: — Therefore you ought to marry her, and you Eſchine to do what you can to bring it about.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVho I marry? Dem. Yes, you.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I prithee? Dem. Yes, you I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Po, you do but fool ſurely.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to Eſchine. If thou haſt any Life and Soul in thee, make him do't.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Dear Father—

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: interrupting. VVhat? And doſt thou Blockhead mind what he ſays?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Tis in vain to refuſe, it can't be avoided.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Po, you dote ſurely.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Good Sir! Let me obtain that Favour.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Ar't out of thy VVits, let me alone. angrily.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come, come, hearken to what your Son ſays for once.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Han't ye play'd the fool enough yet? Shall I marry at Threeſcore and Five? And to an old VVoman that's ready to drop into the Grave? This is your wiſe Counſel, is't?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Pray Sir do, I've promis'd it.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: You promiſe with a Miſchief! Promiſe for thy ſelf, Chit.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fie, fie! What if he had begg'd a greater thing at your hands?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: As if there was any thing greater than this.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pray grant his Requeſt.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Good Sir, ben't ſo hard to be entreated.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Po, promiſe him for once

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Will ye never leave baiting me?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Not till I've prevail'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Troth, this is downright forcing a Man.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come, Micio, be good natur'd and do't.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Tho' this be the moſt damn'd, fooliſh, ridiculous Whim, and the moſt averſe to my Nature that can be; yet ſince you are ſo extreamly hot upon't, I'll humour ye for once.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: This is excellent, I'm oblig'd to ye beyond meaſure.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: aſide. Well, what's next?— What ſhall I ſay next? This is as I'd have it.— What's more to be done?— to Micio. Ho! there's Hegio our poor Kinſman, and nigheſt Relation; in truth, we ought in Conſcience to do ſomething for him.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVhat pray?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: There's a ſmall piece in the Suburbs, which you Farm out, pray let's give him that to live on.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: A ſmall one ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
VVere it a great one you might give it to
him: He has been as good as as Father to Pamphila: Is a very honeſt Man, our Kinſman, and you can't beſtow it better: Beſides, Brother, there's a certain Proverb none of my own (I aſſure ye) which you ſo well and wiſely made uſe of: That Age has always that ill Property of making us more Worldly, as well as more Wiſe. VVe ſhould do well to keep clear of this Scandal. 'Tis a true Proverb, Brother, and ought to be regarded.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What's all this?— VVell, let it be ſo, if he muſt needs have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Brave Father I vow.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Now you are my true Brother, both in Body and Soul.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I've ſtabb'd him with his own VVeapons • ſack. Aſide laughing.

p.stage: Enter Syrus with a Pick-Ax upon his Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Demea. The Job is done as you order'd, ••• .

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Thou art an honeſt Lad.— And o' my Conſcience I think Syrus deſerves his Freedom.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: He his Freedom? For what Exploit?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: O for a thouſand.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: O dear Mr. Demea, you are a rare Gentleman, e • dad you are. You know I've look'd to the young Gentlemen from their very Cradles: I taught em, advis'd 'em, and inſtructed 'em all I could poſſible.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Nothing more evident: Nay more than that, he catered for 'em, pimp'd for 'em, and took • are of a Debauchee i'th Morning for 'em. Theſe are no ordinary Accompliſhments, I can aſſure ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Your VVorſhip's very merry.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Beſides he was Adjutant-General in buying this Muſick-Girl; 'twas he that manag'd the whole Intrigue, and 'tis nothing but Juſtice to
reward him, that it may be an Encouragement to others: In ſhort, Eſchine deſires it too.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: to Eſchine Do you deſire't too?

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Yes, if you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Since 'tis ſo, come hither Syrus. Thou'rt free. Syrus kneels down, Micio lays his Hand on his Head, after that gives him a cuff on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: riſing up. Generouſly done: A thouſand thanks to ye all, and to you Mr. Demea.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'm well ſatisfied. Eſch. And I too.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: I don't queſtion it, Sir: But I wiſh heartily my Joy were more compleat, that I might ſee my poor Spouſe Phrygia to be made free too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Troth ſhe's a mighty good VVoman.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: And the firſt that gave Teat to your Grand-Son to day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Faith, in good earneſt, if ſhe were the firſt, ſhe deſerves her Freedom againſt the VVorld.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: VVhat? For that Service only?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, for that: In fine, I'll pay for her Freedom.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: God's bleſſing light upon your VVorſhip, and grant all your wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Syrus, thou haſt made a good days work on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Beſides, Brother, 'twou'd be a Deed of Charity to lend him a little Money before-hand to begin the VVorld withal: I'll engage he'll ſoon pay it again.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: Not a Souſe.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: He's a very honeſt Fellow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Upo' my word I'll pay ye again: Do but truſt me.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Pray do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: I'll conſider on't firſt,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He ſhall pay ye.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: to Demea. E'dad you're the beſt Man alive.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: And the pleaſanteſt i • th' World.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this Brother? How comes this change of Humour all of a ſudden? What a Fit's here of Squandring and Profuſion!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll tell ye.— That you may know, Brother, theſe Sons of yours don't reckon you a ſweetnatur'd and pleaſant Man, cauſe you live as you ſhould, or do what is juſt and reaſonable, but you fawn, cocker, and give em what they II ſpend. Now, Son Eſchine, if you are diſſatisfied at my courſe of Life, cauſe I wou'dn't follow your humour in all things right or wrong; I'll not trouble my Head any further, ſquander, buy Miſſes, and do what you will. But if you wou'd ha me inform ye, and ſet ye right, and upon occaſion ſerve ye too, in ſome things which by reaſon of your Youth you underſtand but little, are over fond of, and don't much conſider of, ſee here I'm ready to do't for you.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: Dear Sir, we commit our ſelves wholly to your diſpoſal; for you know what's fitting to be done far better than we.— But what will ye do in my Brother's buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well: Let him take the Muſick-Girl; and ſo bid adieu to Wenching.

sp.speaker: Eſch.
sp.p: That's very reaſonable. To the Spectators.
Gentlemen, Your Favour.

div.trailer: The End of the Brothers.

div.p: THE Tricks of Phormio.
A COMEDY, Acted at the Roman Sports, WHEN L. Poſthumius Albinus and L. Cornelius Merula, were Curule Edil's, By the Company of L Ambivius Turpio, and L. Attilius of Preneſte,
Flaccus made free by Claudius, Compos'd the Muſick, which was perform'd on Unequal FLUTES.
It was taken from the GREEK of Apollodorus, call▪d Epidicazomenos, and Acted four times,
Under the Conſulſhip of C. Fannius and M. Valerius.
A. Ʋ. C. 592. Before Chriſt 159.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Demipho, A rich old Citizen of Athens, ſomewhat Covetous, Miſtruſtful and Peeviſh.
Chremes, Demipho's Brother, another Citizen of Athens, an old Ʋxorious, Wife ridden Gentleman, and one who in his younger days lov'd a Girl in a Corner.
Antipho, Demipho's Son, a Good-natur'd, Modeſt, Well bred young Gentleman; very fond of Phanie his Wife.
Phedrie, Chremes's Son, an amorous Gentile Spark of the Town, paſſionately in Love with a Maſick-Girl.
Phormio, The Paraſite, a bold, cheating, ſubtle, intriguing Fellow, and one of ſingular Impudence.
Geta, Servant to Antipho, an ingenious, deſigning, plotting Fellow, true. o the Intereſts of Antipho, and his Cozen Phedrie.
Davus, A Servant and intimate Friend of Geta's.
Dorio, A Covetous, Ill-natur'd, peeviſh Villanous Bawd, Owner of Phedrie's Muſick Girl.
Hegio, Cratine, Crito, Three fooliſh Advocates, Friends to Demipho.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: N • utiſtrata, Chremes's Wife, a haughty and Imperious Woman, a great Talker, always awing her Husband.
Sophrona, Nurſe to Phanie, an honest harmleſs old Woman.

list.head: MUTES.
list.item: Dorcio, A Servant of Demipho's.
• havie, Marry'd ſecretly to Antipho.
Servants, Attendants, &c.

div.p: Scene, ATHENS.
TIME, about Six or Seven Hours.

div.head: THE Tricks of Phormio.
ACT I.
div.opener: SCENE, The Street before Demipho's Door. TIME, The Forenoon.

sp.speaker: Davus
sp.stage: alone, with a Bag of Money in his Hand.
sp.p:
MY very good Friend and Country-man Geta, came to me eſterday about the Arrears of a ſmall parcel of Money he had left in my Hands formerl: he begg'd me to get it up; ſo I have, and am juſt carrying it to him. His young Maſter has pick'd up a VVife I hear: And this looks as if 'twere a Preſent for Mrs. Bride. VVhat a confounded Cuſtom tis for thoſe who have but a very little, to be always feeding them that have abundance! All that this poor Fellow now, by ſtarving himſelf, has bit by bit, with much ado, ſcrap'd together out of his pitiful Allowance,
muſt go at one ſwoop, People never conſidering the pains it coſt him the getting. And then poor Geta muſt be ſqueezed over again, to give her Ladyſhip Joy of her Bantling: And after that again upon the Anniverſary of the Brat's Nativity, when 'tis dedicated forſooth. The Child is the pretended Cauſe of all the Preſents, but 'tis the Mother runs away with all— But isn't that Geta there?—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to them within. If a Red-hair'd Fellow ſhould enquire for me.—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: He's here, ſpare your breath.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: turning about. Ho, Davus! I was juſt coming to give ye the meeting.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Here, hold your Hand. Gives him the Bag. 'Tis all good and juſt what I ow'd ye.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Thou art an honeſt Fellow, and 'twas kindly done not to forget me.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Kind indeed, as the World goes now, I'll aſſure ye: For 'tis come to that paſs, that a Man muſt pray, and be thankful, to get his own again. But wh • ſo concern'd?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Who I?— If you did but know the dread and danger I'm in.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: As how pray?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You ſhall know upon promiſe of Secreſie.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Away Simpleton! What, truſt me with thy Money, and afraid to truſt me with a Secret? I ſhou'dn't get a Pin of my Sle • ve by falſifying with thee now.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Prithee hear me then.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Yes, with both Ears.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You know, Mr. Chremes, our old Maſter's elder Brother, don't ye?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ver • well.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And his Son Phedrie too?

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: As well as I know thee.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: It ſo fell out, that the old Gentlemen took a Journey both together, Chremes to Lemno, and our good Man to Cilicia, where an old Crony of his had wheadled him over, Letter upon Letter, promiſing him whole Mountains of Gold, with the Devil and all.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: What to him that had enough, and to ſpare already?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ne'r admire Man, 'tis his humour.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Pox of ill Luck! What pity 'tis I wasn't Grand Signior!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: When the old Gentlemen ſet out, they made me Tutor to their Sons.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ah Geta, that was a hard task for thee.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Troth ſo I found it by woful Experience: I remember my unlucky Genius bore very hard upon me that day. At firſt I began to be ſtrict with them: But what need many words? My faithfulneſs to my old Maſters coſt me many a ſore drubbing.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I thought as much: For what a madneſs is it to ſtrive againſt the ſtream?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Upo' that I let go the Reins, and contented my ſelf to drive as they'd ha' me.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: You knew how to make your own Markets.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
As for our Youngſter, he was very regular for a while: But Mr. Phedrie immediately pick'd up his Muſick-Girl, and fell up to the Ears in Love. She was kept, it ſeems, by a damnable griping Cockbawd.— The old Gentlemen had taken care to keep the young Mens Pockets at Low-water: So that our amorous Spark cou'd do nothing but look Babies in his Miſtreſs's Eyes, follow her upo' th' Scent, and perhaps lead her to the Muſick-School and back again. I and my young Maſter having little elſe to do, muſt needs bear the Spark company.
Right againſt the School was a Barber's Shop, there did we commonly ſtay her coming out. One day while we were dancing Attendance, in comes a young Fellow ſnivelling at ſuch a rate, as made •• all wonder, and ask him, What he all'd? Why (ſaid he) never till now did I take Poverty for ſuch a ſad grievous Burden: Ha • d by I ve juſt been ſeeing a poor Girl, crying and taking on moſt heavily for the Death of her Mother, by whoſe dead Body ſhe was then ſitting. She had neither Friends, Acquaintance, nor Relation, beſides one poor old Woman, to ſtand by her, or look after the Funeral. It griev'd me to the very Soul, for ſhe was an extraordinary Beauty. In ſhort, we were all ſet agog at the Story. Mr. A •
• ipho preſently cry'd, Shall we go and ſee her? Ay, ay, ſays▪ another, Let's go, prithee honeſt Man bring us to the place. Away we go, come to her, ſee her: A pretty Rogue i'faith ſhe was: And whats more, ſhe had nothing of Ornament to ſet off her beauty: Her Hair all about her Ears, her Feet bare, all out of order, her Cheeks blubbered, and dreſſed in ſuch a pickle, that if ſhe hadn't been lovely to a Miracle, theſe Circumſtances would have made her very diſagreeable. The Spark that was enam •• r'd with the Mu • ick-Girl only ſaid, She's well enough; but ours,—

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: interrupting Was ſmitten, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
Can ye gueſs how dee • ly?— But now pray obſerve what came on't. The very next day he goes right to the old Woman, and very fairly begs her leave for a Nights Lodging; which ſhe as fairly deny'd him, telling him, That his pretenſions were unreaſonable, that the Girl was a Citizen's Daughter, well-bred, and of a good Family; that if he wou'd take her for better for worſe, he had the Law to bear him out in't; but if not, ſhe had no more to ſay to him. This put my Gentleman to a ſad
Non-plus▪ Marry her he would with all his Heart, but was afraid of the old Gentleman abroad.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Wou'dn't his Father have allow'd on't, think ye, when he came back?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What? to have married a Girl, who had • either Fortune nor Honour? Not whilſt his Eyes were open.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Well, and what came on't at laſt?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
What?— Why a certain wheadling Raſ
• al, Phormio by Name, an audacious Fellow, would • h • Devil had him for me.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: What of him prithee?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
He put this damn'd Project into the young Man 〈◊〉
• ead I'm juſt about to tell ye— You know 'tis the • aw here, that all Orphan-Girls muſt be married to the next of Kin, and the ſame Law 〈◊〉 the next of kin to marry them. Now, ſays he, I'll ſay you are the Girl's Kinſman, and commence • S •• agai • ſt ye, pretending to be a Friend of her Fa
••••
〈◊〉 and bring it to a Tryal; as for who was her 〈◊〉 who her Mother, and how you came to be her 〈◊〉 let me alone for forging all, to the beſt advan ••• e • oo. When you diſprove none of all this, I ſhal •
〈◊〉 ye. When your Father comes home, he'll be for t ••••• ing o • me: But what care I? the Girl will be 〈◊〉 own.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: A very pretty piece of Roguery in troth!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Antipho was perſwaded, the Buſineſs done, the Cauſe • ry'd, we Caſt, and he Married.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: What's that you tell me?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Tis ev'n as I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Ah poor Geta, what will become of thee then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith I can't tell; only thus much I know, that fall back, fall edge, we muſt bear it.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Now I like ye: Spoken like a Philoſopher!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I've no hopes but in this Inventing-Noddle of my own.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I commend thee.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Should I go now and fee ſome petry Friend to plead for me thus! Good, Sir, pardon him this once, but if he ever does the like again, I'll not open my Mouth for him. 'Twere well if he didn't add, But when I am gone; Hang him Dog

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: But now for this Muſick-Wench's Gentleman-Uſher, how he comes off?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Poorly enough, Jove knows.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: I warrant he has but little of the Ready to beſtow on her.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Not a Sowſe: Only fine Words and gay Promiſes.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Is his Father come home or no?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: When d'ye look for your old Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I can't tell poſitively; but I hear there s • a Letter from him at the Cuſtom-Houſe, that came up by the Packet-Boat: I am juſt ſtepping for't.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: D'ye want any thing elſe with me, Geta?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Nothing, but good bu'y t'ye. Exit Davus

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p:
To them within. Soho Sirrah!— What's there no body at home? Enter a Foot-Boy.
• ere take this, and carry it to Dorcio. Gives him the Money. Exeunt ſeverally.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: entring. BUT Phedrie, is it come to that paſs now, that I ſhould be afraid of my own Father, when I think of his return • and a Father that loves me ſo! If I had not been a raſh Block-head, I might have expected his coming home as became me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What d'ye mean by all this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A pretty queſtion! When you your ſelf were my chiefeſt Confident in this mad Prank. Well, I could wiſh Phormio's Tongue had been out before he had given me ſuch Counſel, and preſs'd my willing Mind on to what has been the Foundation of all my Miſeries. If I hadn't enjoy'd her at all, it might ha' made me melancholy for three or four days or ſo; but then I ſhou'dn't have had this perpetual vexation upon me,—

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I give ye the hearing

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: — Whilſt I am in hourly expectations o'my Father's ſudden return, who will pluck me from her Embraces.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p:
Others are griev'd for want of Enjoyment, but you for being glutted with it. The God of Love has been too too liberal to ye, Couſin: For my part, your's is a Life I'd as ſoon wiſh for, and deſire, as any whatever. I ſhould thank the Gods did they bleſs me with ſo long a Banque • of Love as you've been bleſt withal, and wou'd be content to die the next mom • nt. Pray conſider with your ſelf what trouble I endure by being debarr'd from
the thing I love, and what comfort you might take in your plentiful Enjoyment. I'll ſay nothing of your having got a civil well-bred Women without any charge, and of your being married to your own liking, to a Perſon of an unſpotted Reputation. 'Tis manifeſt you're happy, and only want a Mind that can tell when things are well. Had you to do with a Bawd as I have, you'd feel how 'tis then. But 'tis the humour of us all, never to be contented.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But tis you your ſelf, Couſin, that are the happy Man in my Opinion, who have Power to conſult at large, whether you had beſt keep her, love her ſtill or leave her: But I've brought my ſelf into ſuch an unhappy ſtrait, that I neither know how to quit mine, nor keep her.

p.stage: Enter Geta at a diſtance in great haſte.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: in a ſurprize. But what's the Matter now? Isn't that Geta in ſuch haſte?— 'Tis he for certain.— Alas! my poor Heart forbodes that he's the Meſſenger of ſome bad News or other.

sp.speaker: Get
sp.p: to himſelf. Introth, Geta, thou'rt a dead Man, if thou doſt not find ſome cunning ſhift or other to ſave thy ſelf, and that quickly too, ſo many Misfortunes are ready to ſeize thee, before thou • rt prepared for em. I can neither tell how to eſcape em, nor how to get rid of them. Our Fool-hardineſs can never be concealed any longer. If my Noddle doesn't befriend us at this pinch, either I or my poor Maſter muſt ſmart for't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What makes him in ſuch a Chafe trow?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. Then I've but a Minute's time for Projection: M • old Maſter's upon our Backs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What ill Luck is come to Town now?

sp.speaker: Get
sp.p:
to himſelf. When he comes to hear on't, how is't poſſible to pac • e him? If I ſpeak, he'll be Cholerick; ſay nothing, 'twill fret him; and
for excuſing my ſelf I had as good talk to the Wind.— Poor Geta! Alas for thee!— Then beſides my own trouble, Mr. Antipho is a great vexation to my Spirits: 'Tis him I pity, and am now ſo much concern'd for: 'Tis he that keeps me here; elſe I'd ha' made a ſhift for one well enough, and been reveng'd of the old Man's peeviſh Temper: I'd ha' finger'd away ſomething, and ſhewn him a fair pair of Heels for't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: partly hearing. What Fingering and Heels is the Fellow talking of?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. But where ſhall I find my Maſter Antipho? Or where ſhall I go look him?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to Antipho. He names you, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I expect to hear of ſome ſhrew'd Misfortune by this Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Pho! Are ye out o' your Wits?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'll ev'n get me home; ten to one but he's there. [Going off.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to Antipho. Let's call him back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You, Sir, ſtay.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: not knowing him. You take upon ye ſufficiently, whoe're you are.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Geta, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: turning about. Od's me, 'tis the very Man I wanted.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee what's the News? Diſpatch it in a word if ye can.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Out with it quick.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Juſt now at the Water-ſide I ſaw—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My Father?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You've hit it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then I'm a dead Man.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: S'death!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to Geta. How's this?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I tell ye I ſaw his Father, your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
What courſe ſhall I take to help me out in this ſudden Misfortune? Ah! Should my unlucky
〈1 paragraph〉

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
Ti •••
〈◊〉 ſince things 〈◊◊〉 are, you oug ••
〈◊〉 the more upon your Gu ••••
〈◊〉
Terfaint 〈◊◊〉 fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
But conſidering your preſent Circumſtan
••• , you've great reaſon to be otherwiſe; for if you •• Fame, ſees ye once down i'th' mouth, he'll conclude you are guilty of all.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: He's i'th' right on't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can't change my Nature.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Suppoſe you were put to a worſe ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, not being able to do this, I ſhou'd ne'r do that.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Pſhaw! He's good for nothing, Mr. Phedrie: Condemn'd already: Why ſhould we ſtand trifling away our time with him? I'll ev'n be jogging.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: And ſo will I too. They are going off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee, Geta!— Suppoſe I look thus?— He tries to look pleaſantly. Is this well?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Not worth a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do but look on me now. Here he makes
What d'ye think o'this? grimaces a good while, at laſt compoſes his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What ſay ye to't now?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Somewhat thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Will this?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That will do't— Keep ye there: Beſure you anſwer him Word for Word, and let not his nuſſing and hectoring daſh you out o'Countenance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well enough.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Say you were forced to't by the Law, and the Rules of Court; d'ye mark me.— He looks to one corner of the Stage. But what old Man's younder, at the further end o'th' Street?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: peeping. 'Tis my Father, I amn't able •• ſtand my ground. going off.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What ha'ye a mind to do, Sir? VVhither ſo faſt? Stay, ſtay, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know my own frailty, and fault too well: I give up my Phanie, and my Life into your hands. Exit Antipho.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Prithee, Geta, what ſhall we do now?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: VVhy, you muſt expect a rattling, but poor Geta (if my Stars don't deceive me) will be truſs'd up to rights. Troth, I think we muſt ev'n follow the ſame Advice we gave to Mr. Antipho.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Hang your Muſt! VVhat you'd ha' me do, command me freely.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Don't ye remember, when we began this Enterprize firſt, how ye agreed to manage it? That their Plea was juſt, fair, ſure; in fine, the cleareſt Caſe in the World.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: VVhy this you muſt make uſe of: If you can think of a better or a ſiner, take it.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'll do what I can.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Do you give the firſt on-ſet, I'll lie in ambuſh as a reſerve for ye when you begin to give ground.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well enough.
Phedrie and Geta move on one ſide, obſerving him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf.— Is't come to that then?

My Son Antipho marry without my conſent? Sure a Father's Authority.— But why did I name Authority? Methinks the fear of my Diſpleaſure might ha' created ſome Reſpect; what has he no ſhame in him? O impundent wickedneſs! And that Hang-dog Geta, the Tutor too.—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: aſide to Phed • ie. So, I'm brought in for a ſnack.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. Suppoſe they pretend, Twas done againſt his Will, the Law ſore'd him to't. Well, I underſtand, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That's well enough.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. But to give up his Cauſe ſo willingly, and without one word to the contrary, did the Law force him upon that too?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to Geta. That's a hard Chapter.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Phedrie. Let me alone to clear that.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'm at a ſad Non-plus, things have happen'd ſo contrary to my expectations and belief. Then my Paſſion runs away with me, ſo as I can't bring my mind to the common uſe of thinking. VVherefore in a Calm we ſhou'd be always ſure to provide for a Storm: So he that comes home from a long Journey, ought to think of the Dangers, Loſſes and Baniſhment, that may befal him: He may find his Son debauched, his Wife dead, and his Daughter dangerouſly ill. All theſe are common Accidents, and ſhou'd be no News to him, if they happen: But if things fall out better than he expected, he may look upon't as clear Gains.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: aſide to Phedrie. Troth, Sir, you wou'dn't think how much wiſer I am than this old Fox my Maſter. Iv'e fore-caſted all my Misfortunes: Videlicet, When my Maſter comes home, I muſt expect to beat Hemp in Beidewell all the days of my Life, to be whipp'd and ſhackled, or ſent to the Plough-tail. All this will be no News to me, if any thing happens better than I expect, I ſhall look upon't as clear Gains, introth.— But why • on't you go to him, and ſweeten him up a little.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: ſeeing Phedrie. Younder comes my Couſin Hedrie to meet me.

sp.speaker: P • e.
sp.p: Dear Uncle your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee thee, Coz; but where's P • ripho?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You're welcome home, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I thank ye;— but pray anſwer my Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: He's very well, Sir; within call.— But your Affairs, Sir, do they ſucceed to your deſire?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: ſighing. I wiſh they did.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Why what's amiſs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Amiſs, Phedrie? You've made a fine Match among ye in my abſence, han't ye?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Oh, ho! Is't that you are ſo angry with him for?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: A rare Actor i'faith. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And han't I reaſon to be ſo? I wiſh in my Soul, I could but ſet my Eyes upon him, he ſhould ſee what 'tis to provoke a good-natur'd Father

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he has done nothing to deſerve your Anger.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Look ye here! They're all of a plece, hang all on a ſtring; know one, know all. Angrily.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Not ſo neither, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Does one commit a Reguery, whip, th. other's ready to bear him out in't. Does this do it? Then that's ready to plead for him: So they help one another by turns.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: The old Man has hit upon both of their Humours better than he's aware on. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: If it wasn't a Bargain between ye, you wou'dn't take his part ſo much as you do.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Sir, if my Couſin Antipho had committe a fault to the prejudice either of his Honour a Eſtate, I d ſooner die than plead for him, but ſhould leave him to ſuffer the juſt demerit of •• Crimes. But o'th' other hand, if ſome Chea, emboldned in his Knaveries, ſhould lay his Snares t' entrap unwary Youth, and ſhould compaſs his deſigns, is the fault ours, or the Judges? Who •• through Envy take from the Rich their Right, and for pity give it to the Poor.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Weren't I privy to this whole Affair, I ſhou'd think what he ſays to be as true as an Oracle. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Can any Judge 'th' World know a Man's Right, when he ſtands like a Poſt as he did?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: He did like a modeſt Gentleman: For when he came in the open Court, Fear and Modeſty ſo ſurpriz'd him, that he cou'dn't utter a word of what he had premeditated.

sp.speaker: Get:
sp.p: aſide. An Orator i'faith!— But why don't I go and have a touch alſo with the old Mumpſimus.— Goes to Demipho. Dear Maſter, your humble Servant, welcome home with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ho! Mr. Governour! The very prop of our Family! The Truſtee o'r my Son in my abſence! I'm yours too. Jecringly.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I hear, Sir, you're pleas'd to blame us all▪ undeſervedly, and me too that deſerve it leaſt of all: For what wou'd ye had me ha' done i • th' caſe, when you know, Sir, the Law won't admit a Slave to plead or be a Witneſs?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Piſh! I grant all this; and more, than that I own the Boy was baſhful, and you a Slave. But let her be never ſo much a-kin, there was no neceſſity for his having her: the Law only obliges him to give her a Portion, and let her look out for another Husband. Your reaſon pray, why he rather choſe to marry a Beggar Wench?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Nay 'twasn't Reaſon, but Money that was wanting.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He might have borrow'd it any where.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Any where, ſay ye? Sooner ſaid than done.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Rather than fail he ſhould have taken it up on Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ho, bravely ſpoken! As tho' any one wou'd have truſted him while you are alive.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well 〈◊〉 It ſhall never go thus, it muſt not be. Shall I ſuſter em to live together one day to an end? No, I wou'dn't do't for the World.— but I'd fain •• a • this pal • y Raſcal brought before me, or elſe direct me where he lives.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You mean Phormio, Sir, don't ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, the Woman's great Spokes-man.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I'll fetch him ſo ye preſently.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But where's Antipho now?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Gone out, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Good Coz, do ſo much as ſeek him out for me, and bring him hither.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'm going to rights. Exit Phedrie.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: To his Miſtreſs he means. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Demipho
sp.p: I'll juſt ſtep in and return my Thanks for my ſafe arrival; from thence I'll to the Piazza, and call ſome Friends to ſtand by me in this buſineſs, that I mayn't be unprovided when Phormio come • .

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: entring. HOW! Mr. Antipho play at Bopeep for fear of his Father, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: So: Then poor Phany's left in the Lurch?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ev'n ſo.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: And the old Man's upo' th' fret?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: to himſelf So then! the burden lies all upon thy ſhoulders, poor Phormio. Thou muſt take what comes on't, and ev'n brew as thou haſt b • k'd.— To work then, old Boy.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Prithee about it then.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: not minding Geta. Suppoſe he ſhould ask me.—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: 'Tis you we only truſt to.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: ſtudying That's right.— What if he ſhould reply?—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: 'Twas you put us upon't.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: ſtill in a ſtudy.— Ay, that will do.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: pulling by the Sleeve Prithee help us out then.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: turning quick to Geta. Prithee, trail the old Fox hither: I've all my Traps ready laid for him.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What deſign are ye upon now?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: What would ye have me, but to let Phanie be his Wife ſtill, clear Mr. Antipho of all, and turn the whole ſtream o' th' old Man's Rage upon my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Spoken like a couragious Man, and a true Friend! But i'faith, honeſt Phormio, I'm afraid this Lion's Heart of yours will bring that pretty Face to look thro' a Pillory at the laſt.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Never fear that; I amn't to learn my Trade now; I know where to take ſure footing. How many Men d'ye think I have in my time beat, and left for dead, Towns-men as well as Strangers? The oftner I exercis'd my Hand, the more Skill I had. And pray when did ye ever hear of an Action of Battery clapp'd upon my Back?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: How comes that about?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Pho! your Fowlers never aim at a Hawk • r Kite that do miſchief; but 'tis your harmleſs Birds they are for. In one there's Profit, in the other only Powder and Shot thrown away. Juſt ſo they who have any thing to loſe are in the moſt danger: 'Tis well known I've nothing to loſe but my Skin. You'll ſay perhaps, They might ſeize my Perſon: They'd be hang'd before they'd maintain ſuch a devouring Glutton, as I am. And troth, I fancy they are i'th' right on't, not to do me ſuch an excellent good turn for a bad one.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith, my young Maſter will n • r be able to make ye amends for this kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: 'Tis we Vaſſals ow more than our Lives are worth for the Favours of our Princes. Isn't a rare thing to feaſt it at free-coſt, to perfume and bath ones ſelf, to have no trouble upon your Spirit, whilſt another • ear • the Trouble and Charge of all? For you to have all things to your liking, to laugh and take • ou • pleaſure, whilſt he 〈◊〉 himſelf; to be honour'd with the firſt Cup, and ſet at the upper end of the Table, to eat of the puzzling Banquet!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What d'ye mean by the Word puzzling?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: When there's ſuch a Plenty as would puzzle ye which Diſh to chuſe firſt, ye little Rogue: And conſidering how delicious and coſtly all theſe Bleſſings are: How can ye call the Founder of 'em leſs than a God on Earth?

p.stage: Enter Demipho at a diſtance with Hegio, Cratine and Crito.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Our old Gentleman's juſt upon us: Mind your hits, the firſt Onſet will be the bloodieſt of all: If you can bear the brunt of that, you may manage him as you pleaſe afterwards.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to his Followers. Hark ye, my Friends, was ever Man treated at ſuch a contemptuous rate as I?— Your Opinion, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: The Man's in wrath.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: ſoftly. Hold your Tongue; S't!— I'll rowſe him, I ll warrant ye. Very loud. O wonderful! Does Demipho deny Phanie to be his Kinſwoman? Heavens bleſs us!— What, deny his own Kindred?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He does, what then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I think yonder's our Antagoniſt.— Keep thoſe Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: aloud. Doesn't he know who her Father was?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Nor yet Stilpho neither?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: No marry doesn't he.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: aloud. Ay, becauſe ſhe had nothing left her, her Father's diſown'd, and ſhe ſlighted. See what it is to be a covetous old Hunks.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You'd better be hang'd ye Dog, than c • ll my Maſter covetous. Seeming in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.p: over-hearing. Abominable Impudence! What is he come to call Whore firſt?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p:
aloud. Now I can't blame the young Gentleman indeed, for not knowing Stilpho, 'cauſe he
was an old poor Man, that lived by his Labour, and was for the moſt part i'th Country, where he hired a ſmall piece of Ground o' my Father: The poor old Man has oft complain'd to me how baſely Demipho his Kinſman had ſlighted him; but what a Man did he ſlight thus? Why one of the honeſteſt Men that ever wore a Head.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: See that he and you prove as good as ye pretend.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You be hang'd: If I hadn't found him to be as I ſay, I wou'd never have engaged our Family in ſuch terrible feuds upon her account, who is now ſo ungenteely ſlighted by your Maſter.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What, ſtill abuſe my Maſter behind his back? Ye foul mouth'd Va • let.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: 'Tis no more than he deſerves.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Say ye ſo, Jail-bird? Ʋnbottons his Collar, and clenches his Fiſt at him.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: not minding Demipho Abominable Thief! Damnable Che •••

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: ſoftly to Geta. Prithee give him an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: turning about. Who's that calls?— Oh, Sir—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Don't Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: This Vari • t has been laying ſuch baſe things to your Worſhip's Charge, that none but this Scoundrel wou'd • a been guilty of.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, ſay no more on't— To Phormio But, hark ye, young Man, by your good leave I'd ask ye one civil Queſtion, if you pleaſe to give an Anſwer to't. Pray who was this Friend of yours that you were talking of? Tell me plainly, and how near did he ſay he was related to me?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You are for pumping, as tho' you didn' • know him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I know him?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Moſt certainly.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I deny't, you that affirm it, prove it, and rub up my Memory.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I warrant you don't know one of your own Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You make me ſtark mad: Can't ye tell me his Name?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: His Name? with all my heart. Studies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why don't ye out with't then?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Pox on't, 'tis ſlipt out of my Head. Sofly to Geta.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hah! What's that you mutter?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: ſoftly to Geta. If you remember the Name we mention'd juſt now, prithee prompt me.— Aloud to Demipho Ha, ha, he,— You ſhall have none of the Name for me, as if you didn't know it already: You're upo'th catch I find Here Phormio laughs, and ſpeaks as loud as he can, that Geta may tell him the Name, and Demipho not hear • t.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ſcorn your Words.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: The Name, Ha— ha— he— But what care I? The Name's Stilpho.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Who, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I ſay Stilpho; as if you didn't know him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ll take my Corporal Oath I know no ſuch Man, nor was I ever a-kin to any of that Name.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? Arn't you aſham'd to ſay ſo? Had he left you a ſowſing Sum of Money—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: The Devil take ye.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: — You'd ha' been the firſt that ſhould ha' trac'd him, and his Pedigree, from the Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo: If I had undertaken it, I muſt have made it out, which way ſhe was my Kinſwoman: Therefore prithee do you the ſame: Tell me which way ſhe's related to me.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith well urg'd, Sir— Aſide to Phormio Look to your ſelf, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I made it out as clear as the Sun in open Court, where 'twas to be done: If 'twere Forgery, why didn't your Son make it appear to be ſo?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Tell not me of my Son; he behav'd himſelf worſe than a Changling.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: But you, Sir, that are ſo wond'rous wiſe, may go into Court, and procure a ſecond Hearing o • th ſame Cauſe, ſince you play Rex here, and take upon ye the ſole Prerogative of having the ſame Cauſe tried twice over.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Tho' I've been much abus'd in this buſineſs, yet rather than be plagu'd with Law-Suits, and your impertinent Tongue, let her go for my Kinſwoman, I'll give her a Portion as the Law requires— Here, take half a ſcore Pieces, and away with her. Offers him Money.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Ha— ha— he— : A very pleaſant Man i'faith!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What wou'd the Man have, don't I offer very fair? Can't I claim the Priviledge of the Common Law?

sp.speaker: • hor.
sp.p: Is it ſo, ſweet Sir? When you've made uſe of a Citizen's Daughter, does the Law allow ye to give her a Whores Pay, and ſend her packing? Or doesn't it rather require ſhe ſhou'd be married to the next of Kin, and keep to one Man, leſt want ſhou'd make her do that which might be a Scandal to her Quality? And you are againſt that, are ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to the next of Kin: But what is ſhe a-kin to us? Or how pray?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Enough, enough: We needn't try it over again.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I don't deſign it; but I ſhall puſh hard till I've made an end on't,

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You'd as good catch Butter-flies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ſay, I will do't.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Beſides, Sir, 'tis none of your Concern: 'Tis your Son is caſt, and not you: Your Dancing days were over long ago.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Then you may ſuppoſe 'tis he that ſays all this to ye; if not, I'll turn him and his Trull out of Doors.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Now his Back's up. Aside.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You'd be twice advis'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You unlucky Dog, are ye reſolv'd to do me all the miſchief you're able?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: He's damnably afraid, tho he does all he can to conceal it. Aſide to Geta.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Phormio. Your deſign ſucceeds rarely.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: What? Can't ye endure with patience what can't be cur'd! Come, do like a Gentleman, that there may be a laſting Friendſhip between us. Jeering.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Piſh! Do I care a Fig for your Friendſhip? Or deſire to ſee, or be acquainted with ſuch a Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: If you two can agree upon't, you'll have a Comfortreſs in your old Age: Pray conſider what time a day 'tis with ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pox, let her comfort thee; take her and the Devil to boot.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Good Sir, moderate your Paſſion. Jeering.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Mark this then, without any more ado: If you don't make all the haſte you can, and take away your Jil • , I'll thruſt her out by Head and Shoulders: That's the Word for all, Mr. Knave.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: If ye o •• er her the leaſt Affront unworthy her Quality, I'll clap a ſwinging Action upon your back: That's the Word for all, Mr. Alderman!— Hark ye, if the want me, you'll find me at home. Aſide to Geta.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: ſoftly to Phormio. Well enough.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What a World of Care and Vexation has my Son brought me into, by entangling himſelf, as well as me, in this unlucky Match!— Then I can't get one glimps of him, to know what he can ſay, or how he ſtands affected.— Run in, Geta, and ſee whether he be come home or no.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You ſee, Gentlemen, how the caſe ſtands; What had I beſt to do? Your Advice, Mr Counſellor. To Hegio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Meaning me, Sir?— I think Mr. Cratine's the fitteſt Man to ſpeak firſt, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come on then, Mr. Cratine.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Who I, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I'd willingly adviſ • ye for the beſt; I am of Opinion, Sir, that what your Son did in your abſence, ſhould, in Right and Reaſon, be null'd and void ipſo facto; and the Law will allow it. Dixi.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Now for you, Mr Hogio.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: I believe Mr. Cratine ſpoke as he thought; but as the ſaying is, So many Men, ſo many Minds, every one as they like. In my Opinion, what the Law has once determin'd ſhou'dn't be cancell'd, and 'twou'd be a Scandal to offer at ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Now for your Opinion, Mr. Crito.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.p: I deſire time to conſider on't; tis a weighty Affair.

sp.speaker: Heg.
sp.p: Ha' • ye any further occaſion for our Advice?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: You've made rare work on't i'ſaith.

Exeun •
Hegi • , • ratine and Crito.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: alone looking after 'em. So I'm more to ſeek now than ever.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: They ſay, Sir, he isn't come back yet.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll even ſtay till my Brother comes home; what Advice he gives in this caſe, that I'll follow. I'll enquire at the Water-ſide when they expect him. Exit Demipho.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And I'll go ſee for Mr. Antipho, and let him know how Squares go— But look yonder, he comes in Pudding-time.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: to himſelf. In good troth, Antipho, thou and this faint Heart of thine are mightily to be blam'd: What? run away, and leave thy very Life and Soul to the Management of Deputies? Cou'dſt think they'd take more care of thy buſineſs than thy ſelf? Let other Matters ha' gone how they wou'd, the dear Creature at home ought to ha' been look'd after, for fear the poor Soul, that has lodged all her Hopes and Fortunes in thy hands, ſhou'd, for truſting to thy Promiſes, come to any miſchief.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: goes up to him Faith, Sir, we were juſt praying heartily for ye, but the wrong way, becauſe you ſlunk away and left us ſo fairly i'th lurch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Twas thee I wanted, Geta.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: — But for all that we didn't flinch an Ace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee tell me in what poſture my Affairs ſtand, and what have I to truſt to; does my Father know any thing of the main buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Not a bit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is there any hopes left then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Indeed I can't tell—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dear • eart!.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: But Mr. Phedrie pleaded like a Counſellor for ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He has been always very obliging.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Then for Phormio, in this as in all other things, he has behav'd himſelf like a Hero,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What did he do?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He quite out-hector'd your Father, as huffing as he was.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: God-a-mercy Phormio, I faith.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And I alſo did my beſt.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: hugging him. Ah, honeſt Rogue! Faith I'm oblig'd to ye all.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: The firſt Encounter was juſt as I tell ye; at preſent Matters go on very ſmoothly; your Father, it ſeems, will let things reſt till your Uncle comes home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why till then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He ſays he'll be advis'd by him in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ah Geta! How I dread his coming home, ſince I underſtand 'tis his Sentence alone I muſt ſtand or fall by.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Look, yonder's your Couſin Phedrie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Look ye! He's juſt coming out piping hot from his old Sweating-Houſe.

p.stage: Enter Phedrie and Dorio; Antipho and Geta move on one ſide and obſerve them.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Nay, good Dorio, hear me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The Devil I will.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: But one word

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pox! don't teaze me ſo.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Do but hear what I've to ſay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'm ſick with hearing the ſame thing a thouſand times over.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: But I ha' ſomething to offer, that you'll be glad to hear of.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, let's hear it then.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Is't impoſſible for me to prevail upon ye, to ſtay but three ſhort days?— Dorio is going off, and Phedrie holds him Whither ſo faſt pray?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I'd ha' ſcored it up for a Wonder, if you had made me any new offer.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: to Geta. Alas, I'm horribly afraid the Bawd is working himſelf no good.

sp.speaker: Ge,
sp.p: to Antipho. And ſo am I too.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You won't believe me then.

sp.speaker: Dor
sp.p: That's we • gueſs'd.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Suppoſe I paſs my Word?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Meer Stuff!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You'd ſay 'twas one of the beſt days work ye er made in y •• r Life.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Idle Stories.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Do but truſt me, and you ſhan't repent it; you'll find it t • be as I ſay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Silly Phanſies!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Good now try me, the time isn't ſo long.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Cuckoo— Cuckoo.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: You are my Relation, you are my Father, you are my Friend, you.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: interrupting. Tattle on, tattle on.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Are ye of ſuch a barbarous and inflexible Nature, that neither Pity nor Intreaties can mollifie ye?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And are you, Sir, ſo ſenſeleſs and ſhameleſs, as to think your gay Words, and fine flouriſhes, ſhall chouſe me out of what's my own for nothing?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Geta. Troth I'm ſorry for him.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Alas! I am convinc'd he's i'th' right on't. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Antipho. I think they both come up each to his proper Character.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: And muſt this Misfortune needs light upo' me in a time when my Couſin Antipho is in the very ſame trouble himſelf?
sp.stage: Antipho and Geta go up to them.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Phedrie. Ha! Couſin, what's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: turning to him. My Couſin Antipho's the happieſt Man alive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Who I?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: In having what you love in your own Cuſtody; not tor •• ented like me, with ſuch a Villain as this.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In my Cuſtody ſay ye?— Ay, indeed, I have, as the ſaying is, A Wolf by the Ears: How to part from her I know not, and how to keep her I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My very Caſe, by the Mackins.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Dorio. Courage Man, don't play the Bawd by halves.— To Phedrie. But prithee what has he done?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: That Raſcal?— Why, like a hard-hearted wretch as he is, he has gone and ſold my deareſt Pamphila.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: How! Sold her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sold her, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: He has ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A mighty buſineſs indeed, for a Man to make Money of his own Wares!

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I can't prevail upon him to ſtay but three days for me, and break off the Bargain with him, till ſuch time as I ſhall receive the Money my Friends promis'd to lend me.— To Dorio. If I don't pay it ye then, you ſhan't ſtay a minute longer for me

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You'll crack my Brain-pan preſently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He deſires but a very little time, Dorio; Prithee ben't ſo hard-hearted. The favour ſhall be requited to you double, take my Word for't.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Meer Shams!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: to Phedrie. Can you ſuffer your Miſtreſs to be Raviſh'd from this pleaſant Town?— To Dorio. And can you ha' the heart to part ſuch fervent Lovers?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's neither my Fault, nor yours.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: A plague on thee for a Raſcal. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Look ye; many a month have I born with you againſt the grain; you 'ye brought me nothing but Court Promiſes, Crocodile's Tears, and a Beggar's Purſe: Now on the other hand, I've g • t me a Chapman that will pay me freely without ſnivelling. Therefore, Sir, cede majoribus, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In good earneſt, as I remember there was a day ſet for my Couſin to have her.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: There was ſo.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do I deny't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is that day paſt then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, but another's day came before it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Arn't ye aſham'd of your Knavery?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not as long as I can get by't.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Sordid Villain!

sp.speaker: Phe. Dorio,
sp.p: Is that your conſcience now?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo; if you like me, make uſe o'me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why ſhould you cheat him thus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Rather I faith, Mr. Antipho, 'tis he cheats me; he knew well enough what I was, but I took him for another ſort of a Gentleman; ſo that he has deceiv'd me: I am juſt for all the World as I us'd to be. But let that paſs; thus much I'll do. To morrow Morning the Captain ſays he'll bring me the Money: Now, Mr. Phedrie, if you'll bring it firſt, I ll follow my own Rule, Firſt come, firſt ſerv'd; and ſo good bu'y t'ye.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What ſhall I do now?— Where ſhall poor I now, that am worſe than nothing, ſcrape up ſuch a Sum at ſo ſhort a warning?— If I cou'd but ha' got him to have ſtay'd three days, the Money was promis'd me by that time. Walks to and fro dejectedly.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: to Geta What, ſhall we leave our Friend in ſuch a miſerable caſe, who but juſt now, as you told me, pleaded my Cauſe ſo handſomly? Shant we requite his Courteſie in time of need?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: 'Tis but right and reaſon we ſhould, I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come on then; you are the Man that can keep his Head above Water.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What wou'd ye ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Procure him the Money.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That I wou'd with all my heart; but where muſt I have it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My Father's at home.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That I know, but what then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Po! A word to the Wiſe is enough.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Is it ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Very pretty Counſel I faith! You may do't your ſelf if you pleaſe; ſhan't I come off with flying Colours, if I ſcape with a whole Skin upo' your account? But I muſt needs venture my Neck upon his account too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: That's true I own.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: What, Geta! Am I no body wi'ye then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Not ſo neither:— But is it nothing in your Eſteem, that we've ſtirr'd up the old Gentleman's Anger againſt us all, unleſs we provoke him again beyond all hopes of Reconcilement?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Shall my Rival carry away my deareſt beyond Sea, and I be the Spectator too?— Ah Couſin, ſpeak with me while you may; take one farewel Look before I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, Sir, what crotchet comes in your Head now? Prithee tell me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I'll traverſe Sea and Land after her, or periſh in the Attempt; that I'm reſolv'd on.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: A good Journey to ye, Sir; but ſoft and fair goes far.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee, Geta, ſee if thou canſt help him a little.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Help him, pray how?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Good now try however, for fear he do what may make us both repent, more or leſs, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
My Invention's upo'th' Tenter-hooks.—
• tudies. He's out o • danger, or I am miſtaken; but ſtill I'm afraid my poor Hide will ſmart for't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Don't be afraid; we'll ſtand and fall with thee upon all accounts. •

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Phedrie. Well, how much Money d'ye want? Tell me.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Fourſcore Guinea's or ſo: That's all.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Fourſcore Guineas? Whoop! Whoop! She's a plaguy dear bit, Mr. Phedrie.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No, ſhe's an extraordinary Penny-worth.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Come, no more; you ſhall ha the Mone • .

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: hugging him Rare Rogue!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Come let me alone.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I want it juſt now.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: And you ſhall have it juſt now; but I ſhall want Phormio, to ſecond me i'th' deſign.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: to G • ta Pray ſtep, and deſire him to be at home.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He's ready I warrant ye; lay what load you will upo' him he'll bear't. Hes the only Man of a thouſand that's true to his Friend.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Let's away to him, out of hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Can I do ye any kindneſs i' this Matter?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: None at all. Pray go and comfort the poor Creature at home, I know ſhes almoſt dead with fear— Why d'ye ſtay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know nothing I'd do with a more willing mind. Exit Antipho.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: How will ye go to work in this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I'll tell ye as we go along; therefore pray be moving. Exeunt Ambo.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.p: •••• ing.— WELL, ha'ye diſpatched the Buſineſs you went about to Lemno, Brother? Have ye brought your Daughter along with ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why didn't ye?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: After he, Mother ſaw I made a longer ſtay here than ordinary, and that the Girl's Age wou'd not admit of my farther delays, ſhe and her whole Family took Shipping, and (as I am inform'd) came hither in ſearch after me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: When you heard of this, how came you to tarry ſo long behind 'em?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Alas! I was ſick all the time.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How came that? Of what Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: that's a Queſtion! Above Threeſcore is Diſtemper ſufficient— But the Maſter of the Ship that brought 'em over, told me, they are all landed ſafe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But, Brother, ha' ye heard of the ſhrewd Misfortune that happen'd to my Son in my abſence?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Ay truly; and 'tis that has broke the Neck of all my deſigns: For ſhou'd I offer my Daughter in Marriage to a Stranger, I muſt tell the whole Story, how I came by her, and by whom; but you, I know, are as true to my Intereſt as I can be my ſelf. A Stranger, that wou'd be my Son-in-Law, wou'd hold his Tongue, as long as we were good Friends together; but if he once diſregarded me,
