he'll know more by half than I'd have him. Then I'm horribly afraid the buſineſs ſhou'd come to my Wife's Ear; if it does, my only remedy will be to take up my Heels, and be marching: For to ſpeak the Truth, I of the whole Family am the only Friend to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I m ſenſible of it Brother, and 'tis a great trouble to me; but Ill leave no Stone unturn'd, till I've prov'd my ſelf as good as my word. They walk aſide.

p.stage: Enter Geta, at a great diſtance.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. I ne'r ſet my Eyes on a craftier Whores-bird than this Phormio in all my Life. I came to the Baſtard to tell him that we wanted the Ready, and how we deſign'd to angle for't; and I had ſcarce open'd my Lips, but he knew my meaning by my gaping. He was tickled at the Phanſie, clappd me upo' th back fort, ask'd for the old Gentleman, and on his Marrow-bones thank'd the Gods a thouſand times, for putting an oportunity into his hands of ſhewing himſelf as much Mr. Phcdrie's, as he had been Mr Antipho's Friend. I bid him wait for me at the Piazza, where I'd bring the old Cully to him.— Seeing Demipho. Look there he is!— But whos that looking or his Left-ſhoulder?— O the Devil! Mr. Phedries Father? Piſh! What a Bru • e am I to be afraid of that? Ist cauſe thou haſt caught two Wood-cocks I thy Spring inſtead of one!— I'm ſure tis ſafeſt to have two Strings to one's B • w.— Ill try to get it of him I 〈◊〉 deſign'd; if he anſwers my expectation, well: If not, then have at the New-comer.

p.stage: Enter Antipho at another part of the ••• ge, obſerving the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
to himſelf. I look every minute for this Geta's coming back.— Hah! Yonder's my Uncle
wi' my Father, laying their Heads together S'death! How I dread what Deſigns his coming will put my Father upon!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: aſide. Ill go to them.— goes to that part of the Stage where Demipho and Chremes are. What my Maſter Chremes?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Honeſt Geta, how is't?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You're heartily welcome home, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: How goes the World with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Much at one, upon my arrival here I find a great many Alterations, as I uſed to do.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: So: Then you've heard of Mr. Antipho's buſineſs, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to Demipho. What did you tell him, Sir?— Wasn't it an abominable thing to be ſo put upon, Mr. Chremes?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Twas that point he and I were juſt diſcourſing on.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: In troth, Sir, I've been hammering upo' the ſame thing, and fancy I ve thought of an Expedient.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: haſtily. How, Geta! What Expedient?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Juſt as I parted from you, by chance who ſhould I meet with but Phormio?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Who, Phormio?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Yes; he that is the young Woman's—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Oh, I know him.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: The Toy came into my Head, to feel his Pulſe a little. I took him aſide, Prithee, Phormio (ſaid I) hadn't ye better make an end of this Quarrel by fair means, rather than foul? My Maſter's a free-hearted Gentleman, and one that hates Law: But I faith, if he had taken all his Friends Advice, he d ha' kickd her to the Devil before this time.— Antipho behind over-hearing. What does the Rogue mean? What would he be at?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: — I'll warrant ye you think the Law can take hold of him for that? Piſh! We • ve had Council upon the Buſineſs already: And take my word for't, if you once begin a Suit with this Gentleman— he has his Tongue ſo well hung, he'll make ye ſmoke for't. But ſuppoſe he be Caſt; 'tis no hanging Matter, and a little Money will put all to rights again. After this Diſcourſe, I found my Gentleman took down a Peg lower: Here's only you and my ſelf (continu'd I) Prithee, good Boy, tell me what you demand down and down, to ſecure my Maſter from hearing any more of this buſineſs, to take the Girl off our hands, and to plague us no farther—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What has Old-Nick bewitch'd the Fellow? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: — I'm ſure of this, if you'll but propoſe any thing that's juſt and reaſonable, he's ſuch a civil Gentleman, there won't be two words between ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Who gave you Commiſſion to ſay all this?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Po! He cou'dn't ha' ſpoken better to bring our deſign about.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's loſt. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: On with your Story.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: At firſt he talk'd like a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why, what did he ask?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What? The Devil and all: Ev'n what his wild Phanſie pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Let's hear't tho.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He talk'd of two or three hundred Guinea's.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: As many Devils take him: What, has he no Conſcience?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
I told him as much my ſelf: Good now (ſaid I) ſuppoſe he had a Daughter of his own to marry, wou'd he give any more! He's but little the better I ſ • d for having none, ſince one's clapp'd on his Back he m • ſt give a Portion to. To be ſhort, omitting his • dle Impertinencies, at laſt he came to this concluſion:
I've had a mind (ſaid he) from the very firſt, to marry my Friends Daughters, which was no more than Reaſon required. For I foreſaw the trouble the Girl wou'd be put to, by marrying into a rich Family, ſhe being poor wou'd be made a Slave, not a Wife. But to be plain with ye, I want a Wife with a little Money to pay off my Debts, now if Mr Demipho will give as large a Portion with her, as I'm like to have with one I'm already engag'd to, I'll chooſe her before any Woman alive.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A body don't know what to make on't, whether it be Foolery or Knavery, or whether the Man is ſilly or wilful. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What if he has pawn'd his Soul, muſt we redeem it?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I've mortgag'd (continu'd he) a piece of ground for 25 pounds—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, well! Let him take her, I'll pay the Money.

p.hi: and an old Houſe or two for as much more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pox on him, that's too much by half [angrily

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Make no noiſe then, he ſhall have as much as that of me.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Then (quoth he) my Wife muſt have a Maid, more Houſhold-Stuff muſt be bought, and a good handſome Wedding kept: Theſe things put all together will come to 25 pounds more.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He ſhall clap ſix hundred Actions upon my back firſt. I'll not part with a Groat: Shall the paltry Raſcal make a Property of me. Walks about in a paſſion

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Good Brother be pacified, I'll lay down the Money, get you but your Son in the Mood to marry the Woman we'd have him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alas for me! Ah, Geta, thy Treacheries have undone me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis upo' my account ſhe's turn'd out, and 'tis but reaſon I ſhou'd pay the Coſts and Charges.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Let me know (ſaid he) their Minds as ſoon as ye can, whether th •• deſign to let me have her or no, that I may get clear of the other, and know what to truſt to; for the other Girl's Friends are fully deſign'd this very day to lay me down the Portion.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He ſhall have it immediately, let him break off that Match, and take this Girl.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And the Devil take him into the Bargain.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I've very luckily brought with me the Rent of my Wife's Farm at Lemno: I'll take that, and tell my Wife you had an occaſion to borrow it. Exeunt Chremes and Demipho.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hark ye, Mr. Rogue!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Ha, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: D'ye know what you ha' been a doing?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Yes; nabb'd both the old Fools o' their Money.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is that enough think ye?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I can't tell, 'twas as much as you order'd me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dog! Are ye at croſs Queſtions with me?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: What d'ye mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Why, your Rogueſhip has brought Matters to that fine paſs, that now I may go hang my ſelf. To make an Example of thee to all Villains, Heaven, Hell and Earth confound thee. If you want any thing to be well done, I'll recommend ye to my Spark here.— What occaſion had you to rip up th' old Sore? And bring my Dear's Name into Queſtion? You've poſſeſs'd my Father with new hopes of turning her off: And, ſweet Sir, ſuppo
• ing Phormio ſhould accept o'th' Portion, he muſt marry her then to be ſure: And what will become of me then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Hell be hang'd before he marries her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I believe ſo: But when they come to demand their Money back again, he'll rather chuſe to go to Jail than betray us, I warrant ye. Scornfully.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: All Stories may be the worſe for telling: The beſt part o'this you've left out, and only mention'd the worſt. Now pray hear mine: If he receives the Portion, he's oblig'd to marry her, as you ſay; I own: But then there muſt be time allow'd for getting things ready for the Wedding, for inviting of Gueſts, and for the offering of his Oblations: The mean time Mr. Phedrie's Friends will procure him the Money they promis'd him, and out of this may Phormio refund to the old Gentlefolks.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why ſo? Or what pretence can he make?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Pretence? O he has a thouſand in his Budget. What Prodigies have I ſeen (may he pretend) ſince we made the Bargain? There came a ſtrange Black Dog yelping into my Houſe: A flying Dragon came down the Water-ſpout, my ſpeckled Hen crow • d; The Prieſt forbad it, and the cunning Man charg'd me to meddle with no new Buſineſs till Winter. Theſe are as good pretences as any I'th' World. Thus ſhall things be order'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Provided they were ſo—

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: So they ſhall, take my Word for't— But here comes your Father, withdraw and tell Mr. Phedrie the Money's our own. Exit Antipho.

p.stage: Enter at another part of the Stage Demipho with a Bag of Money, and Chremes.

sp.speaker: Dem
sp.p: entring. Be content I ſay, I'll take care he ſhan't cheat us: I'll not part with a Croſs to day but upon ſure grounds, and before ſufficient Witneſſes to teſtifie to whom, and for what I deliver it.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
over-hearing. How cautious our Sir Solomo •
is, where there's no need on't! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Troth, and ſo you had need, Brother: But make haſte whilſt the Fit is upon him. If the other Woman ſhou'd chance to be before-hand with us, he may throw us off perhaps.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You are i • th' right on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Bring me to him, Geta.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I am ready, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: When you've diſpatch'd that, ſtep over to my VVife, and deſire her to have ſome Diſcourſe with the Girl before we pack her off, that ſhe may tell her, She has no Cauſe to be angry that we'd have her married to Phormio, ſince he's the ſitter Match, being intimately acquainted with her: and that we haven't done contrary to our Duty, becauſe we have given him as good a Portion as he deſired.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Pſhaw! what a-duce is all this to you?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O, a great deal, Brother.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Isn't it enough for you to do your Duty, unleſs all the VVorld commend ye for't?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I'd willingly have her Conſent tho', that ſhe might not pretend ſhe was turn'd out o'doors

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I can tell her all this my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But 'twill come better from a VVoman tho'.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll call upo' your VVife then.

sp.speaker: Chremes
sp.p: I'm thinking now what corner o'th' Town to beat up for theſe VVomen of Lemno.
sp.stage: To him enter Sophrona out of Demipho's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
to her ſelf. VVhat ſhall I do?— VVhat Friend ſhall I make uſe of, poor Fool that I am? VVhom ſhall I truſt with a Secret of ſo great Importance? Or where ſhall I look out for aſſiſtance?— I'm ſtrangely afraid my poor Miſtreſs will be baſely dealt withal for following my Counſel, for
I hear the young Gentleman's Father takes it very heinouſly.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What diſconſolate old Creature's that which comes from my Brothers? A ••• .

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to her ſelf 'Twas nothing but Poverty that forc'd me to do what I did; tho' I knew the Match was ſcarce good in Law, yet I advis'd 〈◊〉 to't meerly to avoid ſtarving.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: In good truth, if I ben't mightily out I m • gueſs, and if my Eye-ſight don't deceive me, 〈◊〉 my Daughter's Nurſe. Aſ ••• .

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to her ſelf. Nor can we as yet—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What had I beſt to do i'th • Caſe? Aſ •••

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to her ſelf.— Find out her Father.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
Had I beſt go to her, or tarry here, an • pick ſomething out of her Diſcourſe?
〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: to her ſelf. If I cou'd find him out, m • fear wou'd be over

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis ſhe for certain— I'll go talk to her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Whoſe Voice is that trow?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nurſe Sophrona!
Soph And calls me too?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Look this way a little.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: turning. Mercy o' my Soul! Mr. Stilpho here?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: No. Winking on her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What deny your own Name?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Prithee, Nurſe, come a little this way from that Door; and not a word more of Stilpho Sof • ly.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: No, Sir: And like your Worſhip, arn't you he you always ſaid you were?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: S • t, S • t. going from his own Door.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: What? I hope, Sir, you arn't afraid of this Door.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p:
No; but I've a mad VVoman there in a Cage: and I formerly gave my ſelf a Nick-name
for fear ſome of you ſhou'd indiſcreetly blab it about, and perhaps my Wife ſhou'd ſmell a Rat.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And troth that's the reaſon that we poor Souls cou'd never hear any tale or tidings of ye in Town.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Prithee tell me what buſineſs you had at that Houſe you came out of? And where ha you left your Miſtreſſes?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: A-lack-a-day. Sighing.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Hah! What's the Matter? They arn't dead I hope

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Your Daughter is alive; but the poor creat •• e her Mother broke her Heart with grief. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That's bad News, indeed.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: But I, a forlorn poor old Woman, married your Daughter as well as I cou'd, to the young Gentleman of that Houſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What to Antipho?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, to him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How! Has he got two Wives then? angrily.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: How ſo, I beſeech ye? He never married any other but this.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What's become of her then that went for his Kinſwoman?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Your Daughter Sir's the Perſon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: 'Twas only a contrivance of ours, that ſince he lov'd her, he might marry her without a Portion.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Bleſs me! How often do things fall out by chance, which we have not the heart to wiſh for! Upo' my coming home, I've found my Daughter ſettled with the Perſon I deſired, and juſt as I wiſh • d. The very thing my Brother and I aim'd at, this old Woman, without any care of ours, has moſt carefully hit on. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p:
Now, Sir, you had beſt ſee what's to be
done i'th' caſe, the young Gentleman's Fa •••• now come home, who, they ſay, highl •
〈◊〉 the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: interrupting. All's ſafe enough.— But i'th' Name of Goodneſs, I conjure ye not to let any living Soul know ſhe's mine.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Not from me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come along, ye ſhall hear all within.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: WE can blame none but our ſelves, for Knaves thriving in their Knavery; for we muſt, forſooth, affect to be thought genteel and generous: But we ſhou'dn't have out-run the Conſtable, as the ſaying is. We cou'dn't be content to be cheated by him, but we muſt freely throw the Raſcal a good lump of Money into the Bargain, for him to live on till he can play us ſuch another Dog-trick.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Nothing more certain.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Now a-days, none are rewarded more than ſuch Rogues as wou'd perſwade ye black's white.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Nothing more ſure.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How like a couple of Fools we've manag'd our buſineſs with this Raſcal!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: 'Tis manag'd well enough, provided he keeps to his word, and marries her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is there any danger of that now?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, he's ſuch a wavering ſort of a Fellow, that I can't tell but he may recant.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: The Devil! He recant?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: That I can't tell, Sir; I only ſuppoſe ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll do as my Brother wou'd ha' me; ſtep and bring his Wife to talk with the young Woman.— Do you, Geta, go in and acquaint the Girl of her coming. Exit Demipho.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p:
We've Coyn'd Money for Mr. Phedrie: The old Gentlemen are as quiet as Lambs: Care is taken that Phany ſhan't ſtir a Foot out of our Houſe for the preſent.— ,But what next, Friend Geta? What's to be done now?— Thou'rt as deep in the Dirt as ever; and Tinker-like, in mending one hole haſt made two— 'Tis true, there's a ſound drubbing put off for a day or two longer; but i'faith thou wilt receive it, and with Intereſt too, if thou doſt not look about thee— Well, I'll go home and teach Phany her Leſſon, that ſhe mayn't be ſurpriz'd at Phormio's Behaviour, or Nau
• iſtrata's Diſcourſe. Exit Geta, and as he goes off,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
entring •
— Come on then; and pray, Madam, make uſe of your fine knack of ſpeaking, • ow, that the Girl may • 't think hardly of us, but be brought to do what we'd have her freely and willingly.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: So I will, Brother.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Let your Endeavours be as ſerviceable to me now, as before your Purſe was.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p:
I ſhould be glad to pleaſure ye: But in troth, Brother, 'tis all long of my naughty Man's
careleſneſs that I can't do ſo handſomly as I wou'd.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How ſo pray?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Why, in troth he doesn't manage the Eſtate, my Father left me, worth a Farthing; for he conſtantly made nigh Four hundred Pound a Year of his Land.— Bleſs me! to ſee the difference of Men

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Nigh Four hundred Pound a Year, ſay ye?

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Yes, indeed, when things were at a lower rate by far than now.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Very ſtrange!

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: You wonder At it I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: AY, and I can't forbear.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been a Man for his ſake, I'd ha' ſhewn him—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Ay, aY, ſo you would. Jeeringly.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: How I would have—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: interrupting. Spare your ſelf, good Siſter, to encounter the young Woman; perhaps ſhe'll be too hard for ye at your own Weapon elſe.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: I'll be ruled by ye:— But here comes my good Man from your Houſe.

p.stage: Enter Chremes, goes up to Demipho not ſeeing his Wife.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ho! Brother, have ye paid away the Money yet, or no?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I did that preſently.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I wiſh you hadn't.— Sees Nauſiſtrata and ſtarts. S'death my VVife! I had like to have ſaid too much. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhy d'ye wiſh I hadn't, Brother?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Nothing, all's well.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But hark ye, did ye tell the young VVoman upon what account your VVife was coming to her?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Every bit on't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVell, and what ſays ſhe?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: She can't be perſwaded to't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why can't ſhe tho?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Becauſe of the Love that is between 'em.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Piſh! What's that to us?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: O very much;— Beſides I've found her to be our real Kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How? Are you mad too?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You'll find it ſo as I ſay: I don't ſpeak but upon good grounds, pray recollect your ſelf a little.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Certainly you are mad.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Good Brother Demipho, you won't wrong your Kinſwoman, will ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: She's none of mine.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Don't ſay ſo; her Father has another Name, and that bred your miſtake.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What? Didn't ſhe know her own Father?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes marry did ſhe.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why didn't he call himſelf by his own Name then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Will ye never believe, nor underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How ſhou'd I, if you won't tell me—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: You • ll ſpoil all. Winks on him.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: I can't imagine what the buſineſs ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Faith, nor I.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Muſt ye needs know all? As I hope for mercy, there's none ſo nigh a-kin to her as you and I.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Bleſs my Soul! Let's all go in together; I'll know ſomething or nothing of her.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Hold! Dem. What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Have I got ſo little Credit with you, Brother?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Wou'd ye have me credit you without ſearching any further into the buſineſs?— Well, be it ſo then: But how will ye beſtow your Friend's Daughter the while?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: She'll do well enough.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Muſt we turn her off then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: And keep this Creature here?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Well, Siſter, you may go home again if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Nau.
sp.p: Troth, I think 'tis much the better way to keep her ſtill, than part with her; for when I firſt ſaw her, ſhe look'd very much like a Gentlewoman. Exit Nauſiſtrata.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Now what's all this buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: looking after Nauſiſtrata. Has ſhe ſhut to the Door? Fearfully.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Wonderful! The beſt Luck in the World. I find 'tis my own Daughter that's married to your Son.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Hah! Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: This is no ſafe place to tell ye.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Step into my Houſe then.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: But hark ye, I wou'dn't have ſo much as the two Boys know any thing of this. Exeunt Ambo.

div.stage: Enter at another part of the Stage alone.

sp.speaker: Antipho
sp.p: Let my own Concerns go as they will, yet 'tis a Comfort to me that Matters go ſo well with my Couſin. 'Tis a piece of Art for a Man to rule his Appetite ſo, that a ſmall Matter ſhall ſatisfie him when his Fortune is at the loweſt Ebb. No ſooner had my Couſin Phedrie receiv'd the Money, but his Cares are over, for my part I know no way to free my ſelf from mine. If this buſineſs be conceal'd, I ſhall be always in fear; if diſcover'd Infamy will be my reward.— I cou'dn't ha' the Heart to go home, if I hadn't ſome-ſmall hopes of enjoying my dear Phanie ſtill.— But where ſhall I meet with Geta. to know of him what may be the moſt convenient time of ſhewing my ſelf to my Father?

sp.speaker: Phor
sp.p:
to himſelf. I've receiv'd the Caſh, paid off the Bawd, brought away the Wench, and taken
care that Phedrie ſhou'd now enjoy her as his own; ſince ſhe's now out of her Slavery.— I've one thing ſtill in hand which muſt be diſpatch'd, that is, To get leave of theſe old Curmudgeons to go and tope it a little, for I've cut out a few odd days for my own diverſion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Look, here's Phormio.— What ſay'ſt?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhat's my Couſin Phedrie about? Does he pretend to play the Epicure in Love?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: He's going in his turn to act your part now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee, what part?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Of keeping out of his old Daddy's clutches, and he begs you'd act his, and plead his Cauſe for him; for he and I are to ſing Old Roſe together.— I am going to tell the old Gentlemen, that I am bound for Sunio-Fair, to buy the little Slave Geta told 'em of. That ſo when they ſee I'm not in Town, they mayn't imagine I make their Money fly.— But your Door goes there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prithee ſee who comes out.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: 'Tis Geta.

p.stage: Enter Geta from Demipho's in great haſte, with a Cloak in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. Thou bleſſed, bleſſed Fortune, how much is my Maſter Antipho oblig'd to thee for this Day's VVork.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: to Phormio. VVhat does the Fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. And out of how many cold Fits haſt thou freed us that are his Friends?— But why do I loyter? And not clap on my Cloak? VVhy don't I run to find him out, and let him know how things have happen'd? Puts on his ſhort Cloak and ſtruts about.

sp.speaker: A 〈◊〉
sp.p: • 'ye underſtand what he ſays?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: to himſelf. I'll go to old Dorio's, for there to be ſure they are. Going off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Soho, Geta!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Soho, to you too.— 'Tisn't ſtrange nor new for a Man o'my quality to be interrupted i'th' middle of his Journey.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVhy, Geta!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Faith he keeps his pace for all that. Your Impertinence ſhall never bring me back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: VVon't ye ſtay then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Sirrah you ſhall be kick • d— Some ſawcy Scullion or other that calls me thus. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You ſhall be ſerv'd the ſame ſawce, if ye don't ſtay, ye Dog.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: This muſt be one that knows me very well, that is ſo free of his Compliments. Turning about] But isn't it he I want?— 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: to Antipho. Step up to him preſently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: goes to Geta. VVhat's the News with you?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: O, Sir! The happieſt Man this day alive! without doubt you are the Darling of the Skies.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So I would be, and would have ye give me ſome reaſon to believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Isn't it enough if I plunge ye over Head and Ears in Joy?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You kill me with Impertinence.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Hang your Preambles, and ſay what you've to ſay quickly.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Oh!— Art thou here, old Rock?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Yes; But why this fooling?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: Obſerve then; Hem • hem!— As ſoon • as we gave you the Money at the Piazza, we went ſtrait home. To Phormio.— In the way home my Maſter ſent me to your Lady. To Antipho.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p:
Nay, there I leave ye • That's nothing to our buſineſs, Sir,— Juſt as I was going int •• ner
Apartment, her Boy Mida runs up to me, catches me hold by the Cloak, and pulls me back. I turned about, and ask'd him what he meant; he told me no body muſt come nigh his Miſtriſs; that Sophrona juſt now brought Mr. Demipho's Brother, Mr. Chremes; and that there they were all together. At that word, I ſteals me up to the Door a Tiptoe, I went and ſtood cloſe up to't, held my Breath, laid my Ear to the Key-hole, and very attentively liſten'd to their Diſcourſe, thus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O brave Geta!

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: There did I hear the pleaſanteſt Story in the World, that before George I cou'd hardly forbear huzzaing there.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: For what d'ye think?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I can't gueſs.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: And ſuch a prodigious wonderful Paſſage too.— 'Slid, your Uncle is found to be your Spouſe's own Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hah! What's that?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: He had formerly ſome private Acquaintance with her Mother at Lemno.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Meer Dreams! How came ſhe not to know her own Father then?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: You may ſuppoſe there was a Reaſon for that: But d'ye think I that was without Doors, cou'd underſtand ev'ry word that was ſpoke within?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Faith now I think on't, there was ſome ſuch flying Report.

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I'll give ye ſome further Proof.— Whilſt I ſtood liſt'ning, out goes your Uncle, and preſently after brought your Father in along with him; and bo •• ſaid you might keep her and welcome, In ſhort, they've ſent me to look for ye, and bring ye to em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
throws his Arms about Geta's Neck. Bleſs
my Soul! away with me in a moment:— Are ye mad to ſtay?

sp.speaker: Get.
sp.p: I'll do't, as I'm a living Man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dear Rogue, Phormio, farewel.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Adieu, adieu, Sir.
Phormio alone.

Let me die, if this be'nt a lucky hit. I am glad with all my Heart they've met with ſuch good Fortune, and ſo unexpectedly too. Faith now I've an excellent opportunity of bubbling both the old Fellows, and of taking the Money-care off Phedrie's hands: So that he needn't be beholding to any of his Friends for't: For the ſame Money I ſqueezed from theſe old Gripes, ſhall go for Phedrie's uſe: And e'gad I've found out a way will do it effectually: I muſt get me a new ſtately Gate, and a fine ſet Countenance.— But I'll ſtep into the next blind Alley, and pop out upon 'em as ſoon as they appear; for now I'm not for Sunio-Fair, as I pretended.
sp.stage: He retires to one ſide of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: entring. I bleſs my Stars with all my heart, for the good Luck my buſineſs has met with.— But let us make what haſte we can to Phormio, that we may recover our Money, before he makes it all go to wreck.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: comes from his covert, ſpeaks to himſelf, meets Demipho, then ſtarts I'll go and ſee whether Mr. Demipho be at home, that I may—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: We were coming to you, Mr. Phormio.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Upo'th'old buſineſs I warrant.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, truly.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p:
So I thought; but what need of that? A good Jeſt in troth. What, were ye afraid I ſhou'd not ſtand to what I ſaid? Hark ye, Gentlemen,
tho I am but a poor Fellow, I always took care to be a Man of my Word.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: to Demipho. Isn't ſhe a well-bred Girl as I told ye?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Yes, indeed

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: For that reaſon I'm come on purpoſe to tell ye, Sir, that I am ready, and you may give her away as ſoon as you pleaſe; for I've thrown off all my other buſineſs, as 'twas • eaſor▪ I ſhould, when I ſaw that you (Gentlemen) were ſo eager upon this.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: But my Brother here adviſes me to the contrary: For (ſays he) by doing this you'll become the common Town-talk; when you might ha' put her away with ſome Credit, then you wou'dn't: And 'twou'd be a Scandal to turn her off now ſhe's married to your Son. In fine, he uſed almoſt the ſame Reaſons, you urg'd juſt now, againſt me.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Marry come up, how merry you are upon me!

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: How ſo quoth a? Why now I can never marry the t'other. With what Face, think ye, can I go again to her I juſt now ſo bafely turn'd off?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: aſide to Demipho Tell him you find that Antipho won't endure to part with her.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Beſides I find that Antipho won't endure to part with her.— Therefore, good Phormio, let me deſire ye to ſtep to the Bankers, and order the Money to be paid me back again.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: What? When I've juſt paid it away to my Creditors?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: aſide to Chremes. What ſhall we do now?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p:
If you'll let me have the Woman according to promiſe, ſo be it; if you deſign to keep her Perſon, I'll keep her Portion, Mr. Demipho: For there's no reaſon I ſhou'd be fobb'd by ye for your pleaſure only, ſince to ſave your Credit I
threw off another that would have had as good a Portion to a Farthing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Old-Nick take thee with thy Rhodomontades for a Rogue as thou art; I warrant, you think I don't know you or your damn'd Tricks either.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: This puts me beyond all patience.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why, would you marry her if ſhe were proffer'd to ye?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Try me, try me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: That ſo my Son might Bed and Board with her at your Houſe: Was that your Plot?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Ha! What's that you ſa • ?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I ſay, give me my Money.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: And I ſay, give me my VVife.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Come before a Juſtice of Peace, Sirrah,

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: A Juſtice of Peace? Nay, if you be thereabouts, I'll—

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhat will ye do?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: VVho I, Sir? I warrant you ſuppoſe I've none but Portionleſs Clients; but I'll have ye to know, I've thoſe with Portions too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: VVhat's that to us?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir; only I know one of them in this Town, whoſe Husband had—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: The Devil. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: VVhat's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: — Another VVife at Lemno.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I am dead.—

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: — By whom he had a Daughter, which he brought up and no body e'r the wiſer.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: I am buried. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I'll juſt now go and acquaint the Gentlewoman with the long and the ſhort on't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: holding him. Pray now don't.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Ah, ha, Sir! Are you the Party concern'd?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How baſely the Rogue plays upon us? aſide

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Come, we'll diſcharge ye.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Meer Flams.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What wou'd ye have more? I tell ye we'll forgive ye the Money you've got of ours. Softly.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I hear ye.— What a plague d' • e play Childrens play with me? I wont, I will; I will and I won't again; Give, take; 'tis ſaid and unſaid, done and undone again.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: By what means? Or how the duce came he to know this? Aſide to Demipho.
sp.stage: Demipho and Chremes walk on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I can't imagine; for I am certain I never told any living Soul of it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: There's Witchcraft in't, I'll be ſworn, elſe.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I've given them a Bone to pick. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: a • ide to Chremes. S • bud, ſhall this Raſcal carry off ſuch a round Sum of Money, and abuſe us to the very Face too? By Heavens he ſhall have my Heart for his Supper as ſoon. Come pluck up a good Heart, Brother, and play the Man; you ſee your failing has taken Air, and 'tis impoſſible to keep it from your Wife now: Since ſhe muſt know it from others, 'tis the beſt way for quietneſs ſake to tell her of it our ſelves; then we may worry this dirty Raſcal as we pleaſe. They move nigher to Phormio.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: O lamentable! If I don't look about me I ſhall be trepann'd, as ſure as a Gun. They make towards me like a couple of Bullies to hector me. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: aſide to Demipho. But I'm afraid ſhe'll ne'r be reconcil'd to me.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: aſide to Chremes Take heart Man, I'll certainly make up the buſineſs: You may truſt to that, Brother, ſince the Woman you had this Daughter by is dead, and gone out of the way.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p:
Is this your dealings, Gentlemen? You come upon me very cunningly methinks: But in troth, Mr. Demipho,
• ou've done your Brother but little good by provoking me thus.— To Chremes And you, Sir, after you've taken your ſwinge beyond Sea, and ſhewed no regard to a Lady of Quality, but offer'd her the moſt ſenſible Affronts; d'ye think by whining and praying to expiate • our Fault? No, with this Story I'll raiſe her in ſuch Flames, that tho' you diſſolv'd into Tears, yet you ſhou'dn't be able to quen • h 'em.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Plagues and Fu • ies ſeize the Rogue, and caſt him into the deepeſt Pit of Hell! Was there ever ſuch an impudent Dog upon the Face of the Earth? Doesn't this R • gue deſerve to be tranſported at the publick Charge to ſome Deſart Iſland?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: He has got me ſo upon the hank, that I know not what courſe to take with him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I've found a way: Let's have him before a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: • hor.
sp.p:
Before a Juſtice? Ay, the She-Juſtice of this Houſe then. It going towards Chremes •
s.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Follow him and hold him faſt, till I call my Servants out.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: holding him I amn't able to hold him: Come and help me. Here they both hold him.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I'll clap an Action upon your back, Mr. Demipho. Dem. Do't then.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: And another upon yours, Mr. Chremes.

p.stage: Enter a Servant or two from Demipho's.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to the Servants. Here, take away this Raſcal. Here the Servants lay hold of Phormio, he ſcuffles with them, throws down Demipho that comes to aſſiſt them, but at laſt is over-power'd.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Are ye at that Sport? Nay then 'tis time to cry out; Nauſiſtrata, come hither a little.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Gag the Villain.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: panting. What— a confounded ſtrong Dog he— is.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: aloud. Nauſiſtrata, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Won't ye hold your Tongue, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Plague! I hold my Tongue?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: to the Servants. If he won't go along freely give him a punch i'th' Guts

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Or ſcratch my Eyes out; I've a way to be reveng'd for all that.
Phormio: Chremes looks very ſimply.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Zookers! Aſide.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Good Husband, what diſturbance is this?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Hah! What is your Mouth ſtopp'd now?

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: What Fellow's this? VVon't ye tell me?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: He tell ye, Madam? I'faith his Head is ſo giddy, he can't tell where he is himſelf.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Good Duck! Don't believe one word he ſays.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Do but go and feel him, Madam; and hang me if he ben't as cold as a Stone.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: That ſignifies nothing.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: What then? What does the Fellow talk of?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I'll tell ye, Madam, pray mind me.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Are ye reſolv'd to believe him, Duck?

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Prithee what can I believe, he has told me nothing yet.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: The poor Man's fear has put him out of his Wits.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: In troth this can't be for nothing that you ſhould be in ſuch a fright.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Who I in a fright?

sp.speaker: Pher.
sp.p:
Ay, for certain; for if you ben't, and if
this I'm going to tell, is of no conſequence, pray tell it y •• ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Y ••
• aſcal, ſhal • he tell it to humour you?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Oh you do ra • ely in taking your Brother's part

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: What, Husband, won't ye tell me the Buſineſs then?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: faultring. Po— but—

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Bu • , what But?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: There's no oc ••• on for't—

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Not for you, perhaps; but for her there is.— At Lemno.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: Ha! what ſays he?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Dog be ſilent

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: — Without your knowledge—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: — Undone Aſide.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: — He marry'd a Wife. Chremes looks

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Who, my Husband? Heavens forbid that.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: O'my Soul 'tis all true.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Alas-a-day I am utterly ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: And there he got a Daughter by her, which you never dreamt of.—

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: What will become of me now? Aſide.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! Baſe and treacherou • this. Weeps.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: 'Tis as I ſay.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch an unworthy Action heard of? When they come to their Wives, they pretend they are old, forſooth— • addreſs my ſelf to you, Brother, for I am 〈◊〉 to ſpeak to him. VVas it for this he we •• ſo oft, and ſtay'd ſo long at Lemno? Was this ••• low Price of Corn that made our Rents f •• l?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Indeed, Siſter, I own he was in ſome fault, but yet 'tis a venial one.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: He preaches to the Wind. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: It wasn't out of Contempt or Averſion to you he did this. About fifteen years ago, he, in his Drink, had to do with this Woman, and had this Daughter by her, but ne'r touch'd her ſince; ſhe's now dead, and gone out of the way, who was your only grievance. Therefore, good Siſter, take it patiently, as you us'd to do other things.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Take it patiently? No: I had rather part from him for ever: For what can I hope for now? Can I expect Age will teach him better things? If that would ha' don't, he was old enough then: Or is my Age and Beauty like to pleaſe him more than formerly? What reaſon can ye give to make me to look, or hope for his amendment?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: aſide Ha— ha— ha— Here's a caſt of my Office— If any one has a mind to come to Chremes's Funeral, now is the time. Now let any Man provoke my Honour that dares, I'll ſerve him the ſame ſawce I'll warrant him.— Let him be Friends with me now as ſoon as he pleaſe: I've ſwing'd him off ſufficiently for once; and ſhe has wherewithal to hit him i'th' Teeth as long as he has an hour to live.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: ſcornfully. I warrant ye, I deſerv'd all this.— But, Brother, what need have I to reckon up how Faithful I've been to him in every thing.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfy'd in that as well as you your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: D'ye really think I deſerv'd this ill uſage at his hands?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Not i'th' leaſt— But ſince all your Complaints can't undo what's already done, forget and forgive: He begs your pardon, owns his Fault, and promiſes amends. What can ye deſire more?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: aſide. But i'faith before the Pardon's ſeal'd there muſt be a Proviſo or two made for my ſelf and Mr. Phedrie.— Hark ye, Madam, let me put in a word before you anſwer.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Let's hear it then.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I cokes'd your Husband out of Threeſcore and Fifteen Pounds, which I gave to your Son to buy a Sweet-heart of his of an old Pandar.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.p: haſtily. Hah! How's that?—

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: interrupting. Is it ſuch a ſtrange think for your Son in his youthful days to keep one Miſtreſs, when you aren't aſhamed to have two Wives? With what Face can ye reprimand him? Anſwer me that pray.

p.stage: Chremes draws back and looks ſillily.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: He ſhall be ruled by you.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Well! that you may know my mind plainly, I'll neither pardon him, promiſe him any thing, nor give him any Anſwer till I ſee my Son, to whoſe determination I refer all; and ſhall do what he orders.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You've done very diſcreetly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: to Phormio. Will that ſatisfie you?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madam, I am come off rarely and beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Pray, honeſt Man, what may I call your Name.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p:
Mine, Madam? 'Tis Phormio, your whole Family's humble Servant, and eſpecially Mr Phedrie
• s.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Honeſt Phormio! VVhatever kindneſs I can do thee, and thou deſireſt, be't in Word or Deed I • il do it.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: You honour me too much, Madam.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Troth 'tis no more than your deſerve.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: Firſt then, Madam, will ye do ſomething that will pleaſure, me and fret your Husband.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: If you pleaſe invite me to Supper then.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Faith come and welcome.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Let's go in then.

sp.speaker: Nauſ.
sp.p: Agreed,— But where's Phedrie our Referee all this while?

sp.speaker: Phor.
sp.p: I hope he'll be here anon.—
Gentlemen,
Fare ye well, and clap.

div.trailer: The End of the Tricks of Phormio.

div.p: THE Mother-in-Law.
A COMEDY, Acted at the Roman Sports, WHEN S. Julius Caeſar, and Cn. Cornelius Dolabella, were Curule Edil's,
At that time it was not Acted quite through.
Flaccus made free by Claudius, Compos'd the Muſick, which was perform'd upon two Equal FLUTES.
It was taken wholly from the Greek of Apollodorus.
Acted firſt under the Conſulſhip of Cn. Octavius and T. Manlius.
It was Acted a ſecond time at a Funeral Solemnity.
Acted a third time, when Q. Fulvius, and L. Murcie, were Curule Edil's.
A. Ʋ. C. 588. Before Chriſt 155.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.head: MEN.
list.item: Laches, An old Gentleman of Athens; very honeſt and true hearted, lately retired into the Country.
Phidippus Another old Citizen of Athens; his Neighbour and Friend, indulgent to his Family, but ſomewhat Angry when ſtirred.
Pamphilus, Laches's Son; a very gentile, civil, obliging, good natured young Gentleman, and a great Reſpecter of his Parents, tho formerly ſomewhat debauched.
Parmeno, Servant to Pamphilus, and his Confident; a truſty, merry, inquiſitive Fellow.
Socia, Another Servant of Phamphilus's.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Soſtrata, The Mother in-law; Wife to Laches, a ſubmiſſive, peaceable, kind old Gentlewoman
Myrrhina, Wife to Phidippus; eaſie, gentle, and fearful.
Bacchis, A noted Courteſan, formerly Miſs to Pamphilus; very honeſt and generous conſidering her Circumſtances.
Philotis, Another Courteſan; of a merry, gentle, ſweet, Nature.
Syra, An old Woman of the ſame ſtamp, peeviſh, revengeful, and ill natur'd.

list.head: MUTES.
list.item: Philumena, Wife to Pamphilus, and Daughter to Phidippus.
Scirtus, A Boy of Laches's.
Two Servants to Bacchis.

div.p: Scene, ATHENS.
TIME, about Six or Seven Hours.

div.head: THE Mother-in-Law.
ACT I.
div.opener: SCENE, The Street, before Phidippus and Laches's Door. TIME, The Forenoon

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'Faith, old Syra, there's not one in forty of theſe young Fellows that keeps touch with a Miſtreſs— Why here's Mr. Pamphilus now, how many thouſand Oaths has he ſworn to Bacchis (and ſolemnly too, that one cou'dn't but believe him) that he'd never marry while ſhe lived. Very good, yet my Gentleman's marryed for all that.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p:
For that Reaſon, Girl, let me adviſe and conjure you as a Friend to pity none of the Sex; but fleece em maul 'em, pick the very Bones of every Creature of em, that you get in your Clu •
ches.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What all without exception? Sighing.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Ay ev'ry Mothers Son of em.— Take this from an old Woman, that there's none of theſe Sparks that are ſo ſweet upon ye, that has any other deſign than to have his will of ye, at as cheap a rate as he can. And prithee Child, ſhou'dn't thou in juſtice countermine 'em.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But to ſerve all alike is too cruel, I vow.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Cruel to be reveng'd of ones Enemies? Or to take Cheats in their own Traps? Ah! what pity 'tis, that I had not that Youth and Beauty of yours, or you thoſe Sentiments of theſe Matters that I have.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: to Scirtus within If the old Gentleman ask for me, tell him I'm juſt gone to the Water-ſide, to enquire when Mr. Pamphilus comes home— D'ye hear, Boy? If he asks for me, you may tell him ſo; if not ſay nothing; then this Excuſe will keep cold for another time.— He comes from the Door. But is that Philly there?— Whence comes ſhe, I wonder?— Goes up to 'em. Philotis, I'm heartily glad to ſee ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And I you, honeſt Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Syr.
sp.p: Gods-buddikins, Parmeno, how doſt thou do my Lad?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Uds fiſh, Grannum, how doſt thou? Ex. Syra. But prithee, Mrs. Philly, where ha' you been diverting your ſelf this live-long while?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But little diverſion, Heaven knows; e're ſince I march'd off with the Captain to Corinth, the meereſt Brute upon Earth, where I led a very Dog's Life for two whole Years together.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay faith! I warrant ye, you often ſighed for old Athens agen, and cou'd ha' wiſhed your ſelf hang'd for undertaking the Journey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
'Tis impoſſible to tell ye how eager I was to come home to get clear of my Spark, and to ſee
ye all once more; where I might ha' free liberty to enjoy my Friends and Merry-meetings as formerly. For there I cou'dn't utter a Word but what was ſhaped out by that raſcally Captain.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That ſame cutting ye ſhort of your tattle, I fancy, muſt needs go againſt the grain.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well: But what a buſineſs is this that Bacchis has been telling o' me within? I could ne're have imagin'd Pamphilus could ha' found in his heart to marry as long as ſhe liv'd.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Marry quoth a? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hey-day! Why isn't he married.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Married indeed: But I have a conceit this Marriage won't hold long.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray Heavens it may not, if it be to Baschis's Advantage.— But how ſhall I be certain of it? Good Boy, ſatisfie me in that.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: 'Tisn't a thing to be asked: Therefore pray don't be ſo inquiſitive.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You're afraid, I warrant, that I ſhould blaze it abroad: But let me periſh if I ask ye upon any ſuch deſign, but only for my own private Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: All your fine Wheadling ſhall ne're perſwade me to truſt my Back to your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well don't then, who cares? As if now you had not much more mind to tell me, than I to know. In a jaunting way.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: aſide, E'dad ſhe's i'th' right on t: Se has hit upo' my greateſt Weakneſs— Well, Madam, promiſe Secrecy upon your Honour, and I ll tell ye • all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: So: Now you're come to your ſelf again.— Upon my Honor then: away with't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Mind me then. Phil. Well.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Mr. Pamphilus was i'th' very height of his Paſſion for Mrs. Bacchis, when his Father began to
be earneſt with him to marry. He alledged the uſual Arguments of all Fathers in the like Caſe, namely, That he was an old Man, had no Child but him, and deſired that he might not be deſtitute of a Support in his old Age. At firſt he rejects the Propoſal; but when his Father came to preſs on the Buſineſs more zealouſly than ordinary, he was brought to ſuch ſtraits that he cou'dn't tell which to prefer either Love or Duty. At laſt the old Man by baiting and teazing his Son's Heart out, ſcrewed him up to his Pitch, and got him made ſure to his next Neighbours Daughter. Pamphilus didn't take it in ſuch dudgeon till his wedding-day came on; but when he ſaw all things ready; and without more ado, marry he muſt; he laid it ſo much to heart, that I'm perſwaded if Bacchis her ſelf had ſeen him in that plight, ſhe cou'dn't but have pitied him. For whene're he had any ſpare time of being by himſelf, he'd call me aſide to him and cry, Ah, Parmeno, I m a loſt Man What have I done? What a diſmal Condition have I brought my ſelf into? I an't able to bear the weight of it: Oh, 'twill break my Heart.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Devil and his Damm take this Laches for a baiting old Cur.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: To cut ſhort o' my Story, the Bride was brought home: The firſt Night he did not touch her: and the following was the ſame.—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Duce take ye: what, a young Fellow to have his Bride in Bed with him on the wedding-night, and pretty tipſie too, I warrant ye, and not— A likely buſineſs introth: Come, this ſounds like a Lye.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I know you can't tell how to beleive me, • cauſe none comes to you, but he comes ſharp ſet: But alas, our young Gentleman had no Stomach at all to his woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well, but what then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: A few days after, he takes me privately aſide, and tells me, She was as good a Maid as ever for all him; and that before he marry'd, he hop d a Wiſe might ha' gone down pretty well; but now (ſaid he) I m reſolv'd to part with her e're long. Twould be a buſeneſs in me, and much to the prejudice of the poor Gentlewoman to abuſe her ſo, as not to return her to her Friends, as I receiv'd her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: T was done like a Man of Principles and Modeſty.

Par. But then (continued he)
• wont be ſafe to publiſh my Intentions: and for me to ſend her back to her Father, and have nothing to ſay againſt her, wou'd be too peremptory. All my hope is, when ſhe finds there's no living together, that ſhe'll be gone of her own accord.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But all this while did he continue his Viſits to Bacchis.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As conſtantly as the day came about: But (as 'tis uſual for Women) when ſhe ſaw him anothers, ſhe became more peeviſh and pretending than formerly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I faith, and well ſhe might.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
And this indeed was the chief cauſe of their parting. For by this time he had recollected himſelf, and ſeriouſly conſidered his Miſtreſs's Temper and his Wife's; and well compared their Behaviours together. His Wife, he found, was a ſweetnatured Gentlewoman; vertuous and modeſt, patient under the Affronts and Incivilites of a Husband, and willing to wink at his Faults. So that partly touched with remorſe for his uſage of his Wife, and partly tired with the inſolence of his Whore; at laſt he gave Bacchis the ſlip, and ſettled his Affections upon this woman, whoſe Homour he found ſo agreeable to his own.— Mean time,
an old Kinſman of our Maſter dies at Imbros, and made him his Heir; and upon this unwilling Errand is our Love-ſick Pamphilus poſted away by his Father. He leaves his Lady with his Mother; for the old Gentleman lives retired in the Country, and ſeldom viſits the Town.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But where's this Flaw in the Match all the while?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'm going to tell ye: At firſt, for a few days or ſo, the Mother, and the Daughter-in-law agreed mighty well together. When all on a ſudden the young woman began to hate the old one moſt mortally, without any Quarrel or Complaint on either ſide.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How came it about then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: If at any time my old Lady Soſtrata came to have a little Chat with her, ſhe'd preſently avoid the Room, and fly the Sight of her: But when ſhe could away with her Company no longer, ſhe pretends her Mother had ſent for her upon ſome buſineſs of Devotion; and away ſhe goes. After ſhe had been there a while, my Lady ſends and deſires her Company at home, ſhe only returns her a lame excuſe of I know not what. She ſends a ſecond time, but no Gentlewoman comes: At laſt after many Meſſages they pretend ſhe is ſick. Upo' this, any Lady ſteps over her ſelf, to give her a Viſit, but no admittance could be got. When this came to my old Maſter's Ears, yeſterday he came out of the Country upo'this very account, and diſcourſes her Father about it. I can't learn as yet what paſs'd between them? but I'm in a peck of troubles to know what will come on't— Now you've the long and the ſhort o' my Story.— I muſt away to the place I deſign'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And ſo muſt I too: For I've made an Aſſignation with a Country Squire much about this time.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I'll throw an old Shoe after ye, and wiſh ye good Luck.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Farewel Parmeno.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: And farewel to thee, my little Philly.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: ACT II.

p.stage: Enter Laches and Soſtrata after him.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: entring. BLeſs my Soul! What a Strain's this? what a confounded Conſpiracy is this? That all Women ſhou'd take the ſame Byaſs, and do or not do every thing by conſent? when did you ſee a Mother-in-Law that did not hate her Daughter-in-Law? Their Endeavours to oppoſe their Husbands are the ſame, and their croſs-grain'd Stubborneſs the ſame. I faney they were all train'd up for Miſchief in the ſame School, of which damn'd place of Education (if there be any ſuch) I'll be ſworn my Dame is the Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: This is a hard Caſe, that I ſhou'd be accuſed of a buſineſs that I know nothing of?

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: You know nothing of this then?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: As I hope for merc • , I don't: And as I hope (my dear Laches!) we may live long together.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Heavens forbid that, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: That I'm wrongfully accus'd, time will diſcover.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: jeering. Yes, yes; you are wrongfully accus'd.— Can Words be ill enough to ſet ye out in your proper Colours? You that have diſgraced me, your ſelf and our Family, and are laying in ſufficient Matter to torment your Son? Then you've provok'd our new Friends and Relations to hate us, thoſe who were pleas'd to honour our Son with their Alliance: And you forſooth muſt ſtart up, and confound all, by your ill-condition'd Humors.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Who I?

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Woman, I ſay you: Why you take me ſurely for a Block and not a Man. Think ye becauſe I'm retir'd into the Country, that I know nothing of your Pranks and Tranſactions here in Town? But let me tell ye, I know much better what's done here than at the place of my own reſidence; and that becauſe my Reputation abroad depends upon your Behaviour at home. I heard indeed long ago that Philumena could not endure ye, and made no wonder on't; twould ha' been a greater Miracle if ſhe cou'd: But I little thought ſhe cou'dn't have endur'd the whole Family upo' your account; had •• been aware of that, ſhe ſhould have ſtaid, and you packed off i'faith.— Pray ſee, Wife, what ſmall rraſon ye have to vex me thus. I retired into the Country, gave way to ye, afforded ye enough for your Neceſſities, and your Pleaſures too; and that my Eſtate might the better bear it, I've weary'd and toil'd my ſelf more than's convenient for my Age; and cou'dn't ye after all this have took care that nothing diſturb'd my repoſe?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: By all that's good, what has happen'd was not through my means or fault.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p:
No? Yes, but 'twas: For you're ſele Miſtreſs here. and you're only to be blamed: Sure you might ha' looked after things in your own Houſe ſince I've taken all other Cares off your hands. An
old Woman to ſtand ſquabbling with a Girl? Fie, fie!— You won't lay the Fault upon her ſure?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: No: Dear Husband, I lay nothing to her charge.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: O' my Soul I'm glad o' that for poor Pam's ſake: But as for you, do the worſt ye can, I can't think worſe of ye than I do.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: But, good Husband, how d'ye know, but ſhe may only pretend a diſpleaſure againſt me, to be the more at home with her Mother?

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Ne're tell me that. Wasn't yeſterday's ſhutting the Door againſt ye ſufficient proof of her hatred?

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: They told me, ſhe was very faint and weak; therefore 'twasn't convenient to diſturb her.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: She's ſick, I fancy, of your ill Conditions more than of any thing elſe. And no wonder introth: for there's not a Mother of ye all but would have your Sons marry: And whoever is the Perſon that pleaſes you; they muſt have: And when to comply with your Humour they are married, to comply with your Humour again, they muſt turn their Wives out of doors.

p.stage: Phidippus appe • rs at his Door.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: to Philumena within. Tho' I'm ſatisfy'd I've Authority to force you to obey what I Command, yet my Fatherly Affection prevails with me rather to give way to ye, and not croſs ye in your Humour.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Oh! here's my Brother Phidi • pus in good time, I ſhall know all from him.— They meet one another. I confeſs, Brother, I'm as indulgent to all my Family as any Man; yet I ſuffer not my eaſineſs to corrupt their Morals. Were you as careful, I'm perſwaded 'twould be more for your advantage, as well as ours: But now I find you ſuffer 'em to ride ye as they liſt.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: Look ye there now. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Yeſterday I waited upon ye about your Daughter; you ſent me away as wiſe as I came: But let me tell ye, you don't do well to conceal the Cauſe of your Anger, if ye deſign a laſting Alliance between us. If any of us have offended ye, pray make it out; that ſo either by diſproving or juſtifying what's done, we may give as ample Satisfaction as you ſhall require. If Sickneſs' be the Cauſe of keeping your Daughter at home, let me tell ye, Brother, tis too great a Reflection upon us to imagine ſhe ſhou'dn't have due attendance at my Houſe. As I hope to be ſaved, tho you are her Father, you ſhan't out-do me in this: nor can you be more deſirous of her Health than I am; and that for my poor Boys ſake, who I perceive loves her more than his life, and am confident will highly reſent it, when he comes to know on't; therefore pray let's have her home before he comes back from his Voyage.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied, Brother, of your extraordinary Care and Affection for my Daughter, and am apt to believe ev'ry Word you've ſaid; but then I'd ha'ye believe me too, that 'tis my hearty deſire to have her to your Houſe, if I could prevail with her by any means.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Why what hinders ye?— Softly. Hark ye, does ſhe object any thing againſt her Husband?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: Nothing in the World; for when I urg'd it home to her, and ſeem'd as tho' I'd force her to return, ſhe vowed by all that's good, She wasn't able to endure your Houſe, while her Pamphilus was away. Every one has his failings, for my part I'm ſo ſoft-natured, I can't croſs and thwart my own Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Dye hear that Miſtreſs. Aſide to Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Ay, to my Sorrow. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Is that your Reſolution then, Brother?

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: As the Caſe ſtands, 'tis ſo.— But ha' ye any thing elſe to ſay? For I've a little buſineſs calls me in haſte to the Piazza.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: I'll bear ye Company if ye pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Soſtrata
sp.p: alone. In good faith we poor Wives have got a very ill Name with our Husbands, becauſe of a few bad Creatures, that make the World judge hardly of us all. For as I hope for Heav'n, I'm as innocent of what my Husband accuſes me of as the ſucking infant. Yet 'tis next to impoſſible to be believ'd, there's ſuch a common Scandal ſticks upon all Mother-in-Laws: But let me die if I'm one that deſerve it; for I've been as tender of this ſame Creature, as if ſhe had been a Daughter of my own. I can t imagine why this Misfortune ſhould light upon my head. However upon many accounts I am extreamly deſirous of my Sons return. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Enter Pamphilus and Parmeno, at the farther end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
— WAs ever Man ſo perplexed in his love as I? Unhappy Wretch! Have I been ſuch a good Husband o' my Life for this? Was't this which made me ſo deſirous of returning home? Thad been better for me to have ſpent my days any where in the World, than to come back hither, and find my ſelf ſo unhappy here: For whatever Misfortune befals a Man, the longer
'tis before he knows it, is ſo much time clearly gained.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: However, Sir, by your return, you'll be able the ſooner to make your ſelf eaſie. Had you ſtaid away, the Breach wou'd ha' been far wider. Now, Sir, I'm confident that your preſence will have a great Influence upon them all. So you'll learn the whole Buſineſs, rectifie Miſunderſtandings, and make all Friends again. All theſe dreadful Apprehenſions of yours are in themſelves but very ſlight things.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why d'ye pretend to comfort me, when I'm the greateſt Wretch alive? Before I marry d this Woman, my Heart was engag d elſewhere; how much I ſuffered upon that account, any one may eaſily gueſs, without my telling; and yet I never was the Man that dared to refuſe the Match my Father put upon me: I had but juſt weaned my ſelf from Bacchis, and diſengaged my Affections; but juſt fixed my Love on Philumena; when alas, a new Buſineſs happens which forced me to leave her too: Then I'm afraid I ſhall find either my Mother or Wife to blame; and if ſo, the Conſequence muſt be, that I ſhall be miſerable ſtill. For Duty, Parmeno, binds me to bear with my Mother's Failings; and for my Wife, I'm a thouſand ways obliged to her, not only for meekly bearing with my Humors, but alſo for concealing my unkind Uſage to her from all the World. Certainly, Parmeno, ſome extraordinary thing muſt have happe • e • , which gave occaſion to this Quarrel that has now laſted ſo long.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Some fri • olous thing or other I'll warrant ye, Sir: For upon cloſe examination you'll find that the greateſt Quarrels han t always the greateſt Occaſions. Tis frequent, S • r, to find the ſame thing make one Man ſta • k mad, and your mortal Enemy
for ever, when it doesn't move another. How do Childrenbite and ſcratch for the ſmalleſt Trifles! And why? Marry becauſe their Underſtandings are weak, and are not able to direct em: And your Women truly are e'en as ſoon moved as Children; one chance word perhaps or ſo has been the occaſion of all this Diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Well! go in, Parmeno, and let 'em know I'm here.
sp.stage: Parmeno going off hears a Noiſe and ſlops ſhort.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Hah! What,s here to do.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: S't! Liſtens

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Here's a ſad Buſtle, they run up and down like mad— Pray, Sir, come a little this way.— Pamphilus goes towards him. A little cloſer yet. They both liſten at Phidippus's Door. Ha! Dye hear, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Hold your prating.— Shrieking within. Bleſs me! I hear ſome body ſhriek.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: So, you enjoyn me ſilence, and talk your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Myr.
sp.p: within Doors. Prithee dear Child, as little noiſe as may be.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: That's like Philumena's Mother's Voice.— Ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why ſo.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Undone!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ah, Parmeno, there is ſome Miſchief more than ordinary has happen'd, which they conceal from me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: They ſaid indeed your Lady was out of order, whether that be it or no, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'm a loſt Man.— Why didn't ye tell me this before? Angrily.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I con'dn't tell ye ev'ry thing at once.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: What's her Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: How! Is no body gone for a Doctor?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I can't tell that neither.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: But why don't I go in my ſelf, that I may know for certain what's the Buſineſs?— Ah my dear Philumena, in what Condition ſhall I now find thee? Should thy Life be in danger; I ſhall certainly die with thee. Exit Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Parmeno
sp.p: alone. I don't think it convenient to venture in after him: For I very well know, they don't care for any of our Family. Yeſterday they ſhut the Door againſt my Lady her ſelf. If ſhe ſhould chance to grow worſe (which introth I wou'dnt have for my poor Maſters ſake) they'll preſently pretend (a plague on them all) that one of Madam Soſtrata's Servants came in, brought the Devil along with him, and thereupon that ſhe grew worſe immediately: So my Miſtreſs will be blam'd? but I ſhall ha' the worſt on't.

p.stage: Enter Soſtrata on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: to her ſelf. Alas, I think I ve heard a ſtrange ſort of a Buſtle in my Siſters Houſe, and for ſome time too. I vow, I'm extreamly afraid poor Philumenas Diſtemper grows worſe and worſe: But Heavens forbid it. Now I'll give her a viſit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Hark ye, Madam!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You ll meet with another repulſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: turning about. Ha, Parmeno! are you there?— Alas poor Wretch! What ſhall I do? Shan't I go ſee my Son's Wife, when ſhe lies ſick but at next door.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: If youd be rul'd by me, Madam, neither ſee her, nor ſend to ſee her: For to be fond of one that perfectly hates you ſeems a double piece of Folly. You'll beſtow your labour to no purpoſe, and be troubleſome beſides.— Then, Madam your Son went to ſee how ſhe did, as ſoon as he came to Town.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: How! my Son Pamphilus come aſhore?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Heavens be praiſed.— That word has reviv'd me, and ſet my Heart at reſt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Upo' this account eſpecially, I wou'dn't ha' ye go in: For if her Pains be a little abated, I'm confident, now they're together, ſhe'll up and tell him all that paſſed between you two; and how the Difference firſt began— But ſee where he comes.— He ſeems very melancholy upon't.

sp.speaker: Soft.
sp.p: Ah, my Dear, dear Child! Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Your Bleſſing, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Welcome home heartily.— But how is't with your Wife?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: O' the mending hand— Wiping his Eyes.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: Heavens continue it ſo.— But why in tears Son? Why thus melancholly.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Nothing at all, Madam.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What Buſtle was that? tell me: Was ſhe taken with a ſudden Fit?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: What's her Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: An Ague.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: A Quotidian?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: So they tell me.— Pray, Madam, walk in, I'll follow immediately.

sp.speaker: Soſt.
sp.p: So I will. Exit Soſtrata.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Parmeno, do you run and meet my Servants, and help them home with their Luggage.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: grumbling. What a-duce can't they find the way home without a Guide?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You ll be gone won't ye? Exit Parmeno

sp.speaker: Pamphilus
sp.p:
Where ſhall I begin now, to give an account of thoſe many ſurprizing Misfortunes that ha' befallen me? Part of which I heard, and part I ſaw with theſe very eyes; which made me run out of the
Houſe half diſtracted.— For when I haſtily went in juſt now, in great concern for my Wife (thinking to find her ſick of another-gates Diſtemper than what, alas! I found her in:) The Maids being ſurpriz'd at firſt ſight all of 'em o're-joyd, cry'd out, Hes come: But immediately after I perceived they changed Countenance, becauſe I happen'd to come at ſuch an unlucky Minute: mean time one of 'em ran up Stairs to give notice of my Arrival; and I, as eager to ſee my Wife, follow her directly. No ſooner was I got in, but immediately I perceiv'd her Ailment, unhappy Creature as I was: For they had no time i'th World to conceal the buſineſs, for her Cryings out did ſufficiently diſcover her Condition. When I ſaw this, Baſe and unworthy, ſaid I! And with that immediately flung out of the Room all in Tears, ſtruck with Horror at ſuch an unheard of diſmal Accident. Her Mother, poor Soul, followed me cloſe, catch'd me at the Door, and flung her ſelf at my Feet, melting into Tears: ſo that I cou'd not but pity her: And truly, I'm of Opinion, as a Man's Fortune riſes or falls ſo is he up or down. She thus addreſs'd her ſelf to me: My dear Pamphilus, you're an Eye-witneſs now of the Cauſe that made this unhappy Creature leave your Houſe: She was raviſh'd ſometime ſince by an unknown Villain; and is now fled hither to hide her ſhame from you and the World. He wipes his Eyes. But alas! the very Remembrance of her earneſt Intreaties makes me melt afreſh.— Whatſoever Chance or Fortune (continu d ſhe) has brought you hither at this juncture, by that we both conjure ye (if we may in Equity and Juſtice preſume ſo far) to bury and conceal this Miſchance from the Eye of the World. If ever (dear Pamphilus!) if ever you were ſenſible that ſhe had any Tenderneſs for ye, in requital ſhe begs ye not to think that ſmall Favour too much to grant her. As for taking her again,
uſe your own diſcretion. You're the only Perſon that knows of her Lying in, and that the Child is none of yours: For they ſay you had nothing to do with her the firſt two Months; and after you had, 'tis now ſeven and no more. Your Behaviour ſhows what your thoughts are about it: Now, if it be poſſible (my Dear!) I wiſh and endeavour nothing more than that her Lying in may be kept from her Father, and every Soul beſides: But ſhould it come out, it ſhall go for a Miſcarriage, I know none will think otherwiſe; but, what is moſt likely, will ſuppoſe you the Father of it. The Child ſhall immediately be expos'd, and you ne're the worſe for't; and by this means you can ſuffer no inconvenience, and ſecure the poor Girls Reputation beſides.— I paſſed my Word, and am reſolv'd to keep it: But for taking her again, I think it no ways for my Honour, nor will I do it; tho her Love and Converſation have a very great Influence o're me.— I can't but weep to think what a melancholy Life I muſt lead for the future— Weeps. O Fortune, Fortune, what a changeable thing thou art! But my firſt Love has inur'd me to this uſage; I conquered that by reaſon, and how I muſt endeavour to do the like—

p.stage: Enter Parmeno, Socia, and Porters at a great diſtance with Trunks, Portmantaus, &c.

sp.p: But yonder comes Parmeno with the reſt, there's no occaſion for him to be hereabouts at this time; for he's the only Perſon I made privy to my Behaviour to my Wife, when we firſt marry'd. I fear ſhould he hear her frequent Shrieks, he'll diſcover her to be in Labour: I muſt ev'n ſend him on ſome Errand or other till all's over.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: to Socia. Say ſo? Had ye ſuch a wretched Voyage on't? Hah!

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: In ſober Sadneſs, Parmeno, 'tisn't poſſible to tell thee what a diſmal thing 'tis to be a Ship-board.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: Troth thou'rt a happy Fellow, little doſt thou know what dangers thou eſcapeſt by keeping always on dry ground. To paſs over other Hardſhips, mark but this: Thirty long Days and Nights or more, was I on Ship-board; expecting evry minute to be ſows'd to the bottom of the Sea, 'twas ſuch plaguy ſtormy weather all the time, and the Wind againſt us.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Abominable!

sp.speaker: Soc.
sp.p: So indeed I found it: In ſhort, if I knew I muſt go back, rather than do't, upo my Soul I'd ſhew em a light pair of Heels for't.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay, old Boy, thou'ſt been ready for that ſport upon ſlighter occaſions than this:— But hold, yonder's my Maſter Pamphilus before that Door,— Go all in, and I'll ſtep to him, and ſee if he has any buſineſs wi' me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Are you here ſtill, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Yes, I ſtay for you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's your Pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You muſt run as far as the Tower.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Who muſt?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You muſt.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As far as the Tower? For what pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: To find out one Callidemides my Landlord of Myconia, who came over in the ſame Veſſel wi' me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: S'death! I'll be ſworn this Maſter o'mine has made a Vow, that if e're he got aſhore, he'd make me run my heart out. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Why don't ye ſtir?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Muſt I ſay any thing to him, or muſt I only give him the meeting?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Tell him I can't meet him to day as I appointed, that he mayn't ſtay to no purpoſe,— Fly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: But Sir, I don't know what manner of Man he is.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'll tell ye how to know him preſently.— He's a huge, fiery-fac'd, frizzled-crown'd fat Fellow, with wall-eyes, and looks as if he'd fright ye.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
aſide. Plague on him for a Son of Wh 〈…〉
Going off turns back. But ſuppoſe he ben't there, muſt I ſtay till Night for him?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Ay, ay: Run Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I beg your Pardon for that, I'm quite foundered already. Exit Hobbling.

He's gone,— Now what courſe ſhall poor I take?— I'm at a ſtrange loſs how to conceal Philumenas lying in, as her Mother deſir'd me. I profeſs, I can't but pity the poor Woman. Ill do what I can, but ſtill I'll diſcharge my Duty to my Parents, for my Love muſt give way to my Obedience.

p.stage: Enter Laches and Phidippus at ſome diſtance

sp.p: But lack-a-day there's my Father and Mr. Phidippus together,— They make this way too.— I can't deviſe what to ſay 'em.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: to Phidippus. Didn't ye tell me juſt now that your Daughter only waited for my Sons coming home.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: I hear he's come, let her be brought home then.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to himſelf. I can't imagine what excuſe to make to my Father for not taking her home again—

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: over-hearing. What Voice is that?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: to himſelf. Yet I'm fully reſolved to keep firm to my firſt deſign.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: O here's the Man we were talking of.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Your Bleſſing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: I'm glad to ſee thee.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: Welcome h • me, Pamphilus; I'm alſo glad to ſee ye ſo ſound and luſty after your Vo • age.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Im obliged to ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Are ye but juſt landed, Son?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Juſt now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Well! and what has our Kinſman Phanie left us? Hah!

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Wh 〈…〉 really, Sir, he was a Man given up to his Pleaſures in his Life-time, and ſuch as he ſeldom leave much to their Heirs: However they leave this Commendation behind 'em, that as long as they livd, they liv'd like Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Then thou haſt brought home nothing but that pretty Sentence inſtead of an Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: That little he has left, may do us ſome kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Ah! none at all.— I wiſh heartily he were alive and in health again.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: You may ſafely wiſh that: He's paſt wiſhing for.— I dare ſwear I know which you'd chuſe. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: to Pamphilus. Yeſterday my Brother here ſent to deſire his Daughter might come to his Houſe.— Say you did.

p.stage:
Aſide to Phidip pus
• hruſting him.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: ſoftly to Laches. Don,t punch me ſo.— So I did.— [Aloud to Pamphilus.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: But now he'll ſend her home again.

sp.speaker: Phid.
sp.p: So I will.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Sir, I know the whole buſineſs, how ev'ry thing has been managed ſince I went. I heard the whole Story as ſoon as e're I arrived.

sp.speaker: Lach.
sp.p: Hang thoſe envious Dev • ls, that were ſo officious as to tell it y • . In a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p:
Im ſure I took all poſſible care to • void giving an • of ye the leaſt offence: And had I • mind to't, I could here tell ye how faithful, loving, and
